3.  Corridors in educational occupancies where each room that is occupied for instruction or assembly purposes has at least one-half of the required means of egress doors opening directly to the exterior of the building at ground level. 
4.  Corridors that are in compliance with the building code. 
702.7 Dead end travel distance. All corridors that serve more than one exit shall provide direct connection to such exits. The length of a dead-end corridor shall not exceed 35 feet (10668 mm) where the building is not equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system. The dead-end travel distance limitation shall be increased to 70 feet (21336 mm) where the building is equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system. 
Exception: Dead ends that are in compliance with the building code. 
702.8 Aisles. Arrangements of chairs or tables and chairs shall provide for ready access by aisle accessways and aisles to each egress door. The minimum clear width of each aisle in assembly educational health care occupancies shall be maintained in accordance with the requirements of the building code. In all other occupancies, aisles shall have a minimum required clear width of 44 inches (1118 mm) where serving an occupant load greater than 50, and 36 inches (914 mm) when serving an occupant load of 50 or less. The clear width of aisles shall not be obstructed by chairs, tables or other objects. 
702.9 Stairways, handrails and guards. Every exterior and interior flight of means of egress stair serving any building or portion thereof and having more than four risers shall have a handrail on at least one side of the stair. Every open portion of a stair, landing, balcony, porch, deck, ramp or other walking surface which is more than 30 inches (762 mm) above the floor or grade below shall have guards. Handrails shall not be less than 30 inches (762 mm) nor more than 42 inches (1067 mm) high, measured vertically above the nosing of the tread or above the finished floor of the landing or walking surface. Guards shall be not less than 30 inches (762 mm) high above the floor of the landing, balcony, porch, deck, ramp or other walking surface. 
Exception: Guards are not required at any location where guards are exempted by the building code. 
702.9.1 Uniformity. Treads and risers shall be uniform with a variation between adjacent treads or risers not to exceed one-fourth inch. The first riser of an exterior stair which begins at grade shall not exceed 11 inches. 
702.11 Locked doors. All means of egress doors shall be readily openable from the side from which egress is to be made without the need for keys, special knowledge or effort, except as provided for in Section 702.11.1. 
702.11.1 Locks permitted. Locks or fasteners shall not be installed on egress doors except in accordance with the following conditions: 
1.  In mental, penal or other institutions where the security of inmates is necessary, in which case properly trained supervisor personnel shall be continuously on duty and approved provisions are made to remove occupants safely in case of fire or other emergency. 
2.  In problem security areas, special-purpose door alarms or locking devices shall be approved prior to installation. Manually operated edge or surface-molded flush bolts are prohibited. 
3.  Where the door hardware conforms to that permitted by the building code. 
702.12 Emergency escape. Every sleeping room located below the third story in residential and group home occupancies shall have at least one operable window or exterior door approved for emergency egress or rescue; or shall have access to not less than two approved independent exits. 
Exception: Buildings equipped throughout with an automatic fire suppression system. 
702.13 Accumulations. Rubbish, garbage or other materials shall not be stored or allowed to accumulate in stairways, passageways, doors, windows, fire escapes or other means of egress. 
702.14 Hazardous material. Combustible, flammable explosive or other hazardous materials, such as paints, volatile oils and cleaning fluids, or combustible rubbish, such as wastepaper, boxes and rags, shall not be accumulated or stored unless such storage complies with the applicable requirements of the building code and the fire prevention code. 
SECTION 703. FIRE-RESISTANCE RATINGS 
703.1 Fire-resistance-rated assemblies. The required fire-resistance rating of fire-resistance-rated walls, fire stops, shaft enclosures, partitions and floors shall be maintained. 
703.2 Opening protectives. Required opening protectives shall be maintained in an operative condition. All fire and smokestop doors shall be maintained in operable condition. Fire doors and smoke barrier doors shall not be blocked or obstructed or otherwise made inoperable. 
SECTION 704. FIRE PROTECTION SYSTEMS 
704.1 General. All systems, devices and equipment to detect a fire, actuate an alarm, or suppress or control a fire or any combination thereof shall be maintained in an operable condition at all times in accordance with the International Fire Code. 
704.2 Smoke alarms. Single or multiple-station smoke alarms shall be installed and maintained in Groups R-2, R-3, R-4 and in dwellings not regulated in Group R occupancies, regardless of occupant load at all of the following locations: 
1.  On the ceiling or wall outside of each separate sleeping area in the immediate vicinity of bedrooms. 
2.  In each room used for sleeping purposes. 
3.  In each story within a dwelling unit, including basements and cellars but not including crawl spaces and uninhabitable attics. In dwellings or dwelling units with split levels and without an intervening door between the adjacent levels, a smoke alarm installed on the upper level shall suffice for the adjacent lower level provided that the lower level is less than one full story below the upper level. 
Single or multiple-station smoke alarms shall be installed in other groups in accordance with the International Fire Code. 
704.3 Power source. In Group R occupancies and in dwellings not regulated as Group R occupancies, single-station smoke alarms shall receive their primary power from the building wiring provided that such wiring is served from a commercial source and shall be equipped with a battery backup. Smoke alarms shall emit a signal when the batteries are low. Wiring shall be permanent and without a disconnecting switch other than as required for overcurrent protection. 
Exception: Smoke alarms are permitted to be solely battery operated in buildings where no construction is taking place, buildings that are not served from a commercial power source and in existing areas of buildings undergoing alterations or repairs that do not result in the removal of interior wall or ceiling finishes exposing the structure, unless there is an attic, crawl space or basement available which could provide access for building wiring without the removal of interior finishes. 
704.4 Interconnection. Where more than one smoke alarm is required to be installed within an individual dwelling unit in Group R-2, R-3, R-4 and in dwellings not regulated as Group R occupancies, the smoke alarms shall be interconnected in such a manner that the activation of one alarm will activate all of the alarms in the individual unit. The alarm shall be clearly audible in all bedrooms over background noise levels with all intervening doors closed. 
CHAPTER 8. REFERENCED STANDARDS 
    Chapter 8, Referenced Standards, is amended to add this advisory: 
    The referenced standards in this chapter to some of the international codes have been changed to codes enforced by the City of East Lansing by definition changes made in Chapter 2. Refer to Chapter 2 for the proper referenced standards. 
CHAPTER 9 
    (Reserved for future regulations) 
    Chapter 9 is added and reserved for future regulations. 
CHAPTER 10. RENTAL HOUSING INSPECTION AND LICENSING 
    Chapter 10, Rental Housing Inspection and Licensing, is added to read: 
SECTION 1000.0 GENERAL PROVISIONS 
1000.1 Scope. This article shall regulate the lease or rental of every dwelling, with or without valuable consideration, by any person. 
1000.2 Purpose. The regulation, inspection and licensing of rental property is intended to: 
(1)  Protect the health, safety, and welfare of persons affected by or subject to the provisions of this article; 
(2)  Ensure that rental unit owners, legal agents, and tenants are informed of, and adhere to, all applicable code provisions governing the use and maintenance of rental units; 
(3)  Ensure that owners or legal agents inform tenants of their rights and responsibilities under written leases or other rental agreements before such leases and agreements are executed. 
1000.3 Administration. The department shall be responsible, as directed by the city manager to administer this chapter. 
1000.4 Official records. A separate file for each rental unit licensed by the city, containing no less than a copy of the application for the rental license, any license issued, inspection reports, code violation notices, site plans, floor plans, residential parking plans, the results of any actions taken regarding the license, and most recent renewal application, if any, and other appropriate records shall be kept for all rental units by the department and made available for inspection and copying through requests pursuant to Michigan's Freedom of Information Act. Any or all parts of this file may be stored on electronic medium. 
SECTION 1001.0 RENTAL HOUSING 
1001.1 Rental requirements. No dwelling shall be leased or occupied for rental purposes by any person unless it is first in compliance with the provisions of every section of this article. Occupancy of any dwelling by any person other than the owner of record shall be presumed to require a rental license. 
(1)  This presumption may be rebutted by evidence that the occupant has ownership equity of 25 percent or more of the fee or life estate evidenced by: 
(a)  A recorded deed; or 
(b)  A recorded land contract; or 
(c)  An unrecorded land contract with supporting evidence that it was not entered into in order to circumvent the requirements of this article, including subsequent recordation. 
(2)  Occupants of any dwelling, claiming any form of ownership in accordance with a land contract, option to purchase, exchange contract, or any other legal instrument shall provide proof that the transfer of ownership is supported by a substantial equity interest in the property by the person or persons claiming ownership. 
1001.2 Exceptions. A rental unit license is not required under the following circumstances: 
(1)  Family occupancy. Any member of a family, as defined by chapter 50 of the City Code, including nieces and nephews, may occupy a dwelling as long as any other member of that family is the owner of that dwelling. 
(2)  House-sitting. During the temporary absence of the owner and owner's family of a domicile for a period not to exceed two years in any five-year period, the owner may permit up to two unrelated individuals or a family to occupy the premises without a rental license by notifying the department, on a form provided by the department, of the address of the owner's temporary domicile, the projected duration of the owner's absence, and the identity of the unrelated individual or family who will occupy the premises during the owner's absence. 
(a)  An owner who is in active military service may request up to an additional two-year extension of the two-year limitation of this subsection if all of the following requirements are met: 
(i)  The owner's active military service requires the owner to remain away from the home for an additional period of time; and 
(ii)  The owner plans on returning to the home when the service allows it; and 
(iii)  The owner files a signed affidavit with the department attesting to the above requirements; and 
(iv)  The owner does not have any delinquent fees or taxes owed to the city. 
(b)  The chief code official shall grant a properly filed request for an extension if: 
(i)  The home would not otherwise meet the bases for imposing rental license sanctions pursuant to section 1008.0 of this article if the property were a licensed rental; and 
(ii)  There is no other reason to suspect the truthfulness of the affidavit. 
(c)  If the chief code official denies the request, the chief code official shall state each reason for the denial in a written correspondence to the owner. The owner may appeal that decision to the housing commission by filing a written request with the department within 21 days of notice of the denial. The housing commission shall grant the extension if, after a hearing, the housing commission determines the chief code official's basis for the denial was unfounded. 
(3)  One- and two-family dwelling sales. The sale of any one- or two-family dwelling intended for occupancy by the owner or owners of record which are to be occupied by the seller under a rental agreement for a period of less than 90 days following closing. The sale of any one- or two-family dwelling intended for occupancy under a lease with option to purchase agreement, life estate agreement or any other form of conditional sale agreement, shall require a rental unit license if legal or equitable ownership is not transferred in its entirety within 90 days of execution of the conditional sales agreement. 
(4)  Exchange student, visiting clergy, medical caregiver, child care. For an owner-occupied dwelling, additional occupancy by exchange students placed through a recognized education exchange student program, one visiting clergy and their immediate family members, or clerical aide to a local church or congregation, or one person to provide child care or medically prescribed care. 
(5)  Estate representative. Occupancy by a personal representative, trustee, or guardian of the estate and their family where the dwelling was owner-occupied for the last year prior to the owner's death, and the occupancy does not exceed two years from the date of death of the owner by notifying the code enforcement department on a form provided by the department of the owner's name, date of death, and name of the person occupying the premises. 
(6)  Domestic servants. Occupancy by a domestic servant with the owner or owner's family if the domestic servant is employed full time as a domestic servant for the owner or owner's family and the owner or owner's family is paying social security taxes for the domestic servant's employment as a domestic servant. 
(7)  Religious occupancy. Occupancy of property owned by a religious organization for two unrelated or a family if occupied by clergy, religious leaders, religious officials, or other persons integrally involved in the religious organization and no rent is either being paid by the occupants or collected from the occupants by the religious organization solely for the occupancy. For purposes of this provision, religious organization means an organization that presents sufficient evidence to the court or code official that the organization has been determined by the Internal Revenue Service to be tax exempt pursuant to IRC § 501(c)(3) because it is operated exclusively for religious purposes or a religious or apostolic association or corporation determined by the Internal Revenue Service to be tax exempt pursuant to IRC § 501(d). 
SECTION 1002.0 RENTAL UNIT LICENSE CLASSIFICATIONS AND EXPIRATION 
1002.1 Rental license classifications. There are six classifications of rental licenses: 
(1)  Class I rental license: A license that authorizes the owner of a one-family dwelling in which the owner resides to lease or rent room(s) to one person. 
(2)  Class II rental license: A license that authorizes the owner of a one-family dwelling in which the owner resides to lease or rent room(s) to two or more persons. 
(3)  Class III rental license: A license that authorizes the owner of a one-family dwelling in which the owner does not reside or a two-family dwelling to lease or rent the dwelling to a family or two unrelated persons per rental unit. 
(4)  Class IV rental license: A license that authorizes the owner of a one-family dwelling in which the owner does not reside or a two-family dwelling to lease or rent the dwelling to a family or three or more unrelated persons per rental unit. 
(5)  Class V rental license: A license that authorizes the owner of a class A multiple dwelling to rent or lease the dwelling units or rooming units contained therein. 
(6)  Class VI rental license: A license that authorizes the owner of a class B multiple dwelling to rent or lease the dwelling units or rooming units contained therein. 
1002.2 Class of rental unit license issued. The class of rental unit license issued to any owner shall be in accordance with the type of dwelling and the number of persons allowed to occupy the dwelling pursuant to the requirements of all the provisions of the City Code. 
1002.3 Rental unit license expiration by classification: 
(1)  A "class I" rental unit license shall expire 39 months from the effective date of the license unless one of the following occurs first: 
(a)  The license is revoked pursuant to this Code. 
(b)  The property is sold. 
(c)  There were conditions placed on the license and the conditions of the license were not met. 
(d)  The owner ceases to reside in the premises. 
(2)  A "class II" rental unit license shall expire 26 months from the effective date of the license unless one of the following occurs first: 
(a)  The license is revoked pursuant to this Code. 
(b)  The property is sold. 
(c)  There were conditions placed on the license and the conditions of the license were not met. 
(d)  The owner ceases to reside in the premises. 
(3)  A "class III, IV, V, and VI" rental unit license shall expire 13 months from the effective date of the license unless one of the following occurs first: 
(a)  The license is revoked pursuant to this Code. 
(b)  The property is sold. 
(c)  There were conditions placed on the license and the conditions of the license were not met. 
1002.4 Transfers of rental unit ownership. A rental license is issued to an owner of a rental unit and only permits the owner to lease the rental unit in conformance with the license. Upon transfer of ownership of a rental unit, any existing license to lease the rental unit expires. This includes transfers of ownership between corporations or other legal entities even where there is identical ownership interest in the acquiring legal entity as in the previous legal entity. 
1002.5 Effect of rental unit license expiration. For a license that expired as a result of the sale of the property or for failure to renew the license, application for reissuance of the license may be made immediately. For a license that expired for failure to comply with licensing conditions, application may be made only after the conditions have been met. Application for reissuance of an expired license must be made within one year of expiration of the license and shall be processed in the same manner as a renewal license application. Renewal or reissuance of a license within one year of expiration shall not be considered a change in use and shall preserve any prior legal non-conforming rental use or occupancy which the owner or prior owner has established. After a license has been expired for one year, any license application shall be processed as an initial license and any prior legal non-conforming rental use or occupancy which the owner or prior owner had established shall be deemed abandoned if the department presents sufficient evidence at the review hearing that the owner intended to abandon the non-conforming use. 
SECTION 1003.0 APPLICATIONS FOR RENTAL UNIT LICENSES 
1003.1 Application. Applications for a rental unit license shall be submitted to the department. 
1003.2 Initial application form and contents. The rental unit license application shall be made on forms provided by the department. The forms shall be signed by the owner and the owner's legal agent, if any, notarized, and include the following: 
(1)  The name, driver's license or state identification number (or in the case of a corporation, the corporate ID number), permanent home address, and business and home telephone number of: 
(a)  The owner; 
(b)  The legal agent designated by the owner, if any; 
(c)  The resident agent, individual partner, or managing member of any business entity. 
(2)  The number of rental units and the number and size of habitable sleeping rooms contained within each rental unit. 
(3)  A declaration of whether subletting by any tenant(s) is permitted. 
(4)  An agreement by the owner to permit the inspections required by this article in the manner permitted by this article. 
(5)  The street address(es) of the rental unit. 
(6)  The occupancy sought. 
(7)  The class of license sought. 
(8)  The applicant certifies that insurance coverage for structural loss or damage and premises liability for personal injury exists and shall be maintained on the licensed property. 
(9)  For a rental unit located in an historic district or a heritage neighborhood and undergoing or requiring exterior changes, a certificate of appropriateness issued by the historic district commission or an acknowledgment that one is not necessary. 
(10)  A floor plan and site plan to the extent required by section 1003.7. 
(11)  For a corporate owner and/or corporate legal agent, a copy of the most recent annual report filed with the State of Michigan. 
(12)  Any other information required by administrative rule approved by the city council. 
1003.3 Renewal application form and contents. An application for the renewal of a rental license shall contain the same information as an initial application except that: 
(1)  It may be signed by the owner or legal agent. 
(2)  If there have been no changes from the previous application, it may incorporate by reference the information previously submitted. 
1003.4 New owner application form and contents. An application for the new owner or prospective new owner of a previously or currently licensed rental unit shall contain the same information as an initial application, except for the following: 
(1)  It shall be signed by the new or prospective owner. 
(2)  It shall state the previous owner's name. 
(3)  It shall state whether the applicant or rental unit has been subject to terms and conditions or other license sanctions. 
(4)  It shall state the anniversary date of the current rental license. 
(5)  It shall state the date in which ownership of the property has or will be transferred. 
1003.5 Application acceptance. A rental unit license application shall not be accepted by the department unless it meets all requirements of this section, is signed in ink, is accompanied by the required rental license fee, is accompanied by the documents required by this article, and is accompanied by any delinquent city fees and charges due and payable to the city in conjunction with the property to be licensed. The department, within 30 days of receipt, shall notify the applicant of any deficiencies of the application which prevents its acceptance. 
1003.6 Reserved. 
1003.7 Submission of floor plans and site plan. For properties that have not been reviewed through submission and approval of a plan of development, an application for a rental unit license shall include a floor plan and a site plan with dimensions drawn accurately to scale in accordance with the requirements of this section. A request for a building or paving permit which alters an existing floor plan or site plan shall include a new floor plan or site plan in accordance with the requirements of this section. 
(1)  For class I, II, III, IV, and VI licenses, the floor plan shall show the number, size, and location of habitable and occupiable rooms in the rental unit, and the number, size, and location of non-habitable and non-occupiable rooms in the rental unit, as well as all exits, basement and attic egress windows, and entryways to the rental unit. For class V licenses, the floor plan submitted must represent, to the satisfaction of the chief code official, the same information as required for the other license classifications, provided, however, class V licenses may, in any event, satisfy the requirements of this subsection by submission of (a) a floor plan for each general type of rental unit (for example, efficiency, studio, one-bedroom unit, etc.); and (b) either a site plan as above described or a mortgage survey. 
(2)  The site plan shall show the boundaries of the property, the location of all structures, the location, number and size of parking spaces in conformance with the City Code, the location and size of driveways, curb cuts, the location, type, and dimension of construction materials used for parking spaces and driveways, the type of materials covering area abutting or adjacent to parking spaces, and the location of fences and significant plantings. The department may require submission of a legal survey to establish the boundaries of the rental unit. 
(3)  If the owner or legal agent has previously submitted a floor plan and site plan for the rental unit which is the subject of the application, the application may incorporate by reference the previously filed documents and certify that no material change to the rental unit has taken place in the prior license period. 
1003.8 Filing of license renewal applications. A rental license renewal application shall be filed no less than 120 days prior to the expiration of the rental license. A renewal application shall be forwarded to each licensee with each license issued. The department shall send a reminder notice to the owner and legal agent who has failed to file a renewal application within 90 days prior to expiration. 
1003.9 Owner's and legal agent's current address. The owner and legal agent, if any, shall notify the department of any change of the mailing address and telephone number of the owner within ten working days of the date of the change. 
1003.10 Change of legal agent. The owner shall notify the department of any change in their designated legal agent, including the name, mailing address, and telephone number within ten working days of the date of the change. 
SECTION 1004.0 INSPECTION OF RENTAL UNITS 
1004.1 Initial "all trades" inspection. Within 60 days following the acceptance of an application for an initial rental unit license, the proposed rental unit shall have an "all trades" inspection for compliance with the requirements of the property maintenance code. 
1004.2 Renewal inspection. Upon timely submission of a renewal rental unit license application the rental unit shall be inspected at least 60 days prior to the license anniversary date. The rental unit shall be inspected for compliance with the requirements of this Code. 
1004.2.1 Additional all trades inspections. When a city inspector concludes, during any inspection, that any of the conditions as set forth below exist on the property, that inspector shall notify the chief code official. The inspection shall not be considered to have been completed until the chief code official determines that all the conditions in subsection (1) or (2) below have been satisfactorily resolved and the chief code official determines that an all trades inspection is not necessary, or an all trades inspection has been completed. 
(1)  The number of violations which exist on the property for the property's licensing classification total the following in any one-year period: 
(a)  Property licensed as class I, II, III, IV-ten or more violations. 
(b)  Property licensed as class V-the greater of 15 violations or a number equal to four violations multiplied by the number of dwelling units inspected. 
(c)  Property licensed as class VI-1.5 violations for each licensed occupant. 
(d)  For purposes of this subsection, "violation" shall mean any distinct violation of the property maintenance code. Multiple violations of a single provision of the property maintenance code during an inspection shall be treated as a single violation. 
(2)  Violations are recognized by the inspector to exist on the property which, considering the nature and severity of the violation, the code official determines either (a) could threaten the health, safety or welfare of the occupants or (b) that trade inspection is needed either to properly determine the extent of the violations or the corrective action required to comply with the code. 
1004.2.2 Discretionary "all trades" inspection exception. Regardless of the applicability of 1004.2.1, the chief code official may order an all trades inspection when, considering the nature, number and severity of violations, the chief code official determines any of the following conditions are met: 
(1)  A violation constitutes an immediate hazard to the health, safety or welfare of the occupant; 
(2)  Sufficient violations exist which materially degrade the weather resistance, the structure or the plumbing, electrical, or mechanical equipment of the building; 
(3)  Appearance of the property creates a blighting condition for the area in which the building is located; 
(4)  There is a history of repeated or substantial numbers of code violations. 
1004.2.3 Notice. If the chief code official orders an all trades inspection, the chief code official shall send a notice to the owner and/or legal agent of the property by first class or electronic mail stating the basis upon which the all trades inspection was ordered and listing the types of inspectors that will perform the all trades inspection. 
1004.2.4 Review. The owner or legal agent of a property may request the city manager review a decision of the chief code official to require an "all trades" inspection. Such request shall be made within three days of the receipt of notice requiring an "all trades" inspection and shall be submitted in writing to the office of the city manager and the city council. The city manager shall, within 15 working days of receiving the request, review the decision of the chief code official and shall, by ordinary mail, communicate a decision to sustain, modify, or overturn the decision of the chief code official to the petitioner and to the city council. The petitioner may request a stay on conducting the "all trades" inspection during the city manager's review of the decision. 
1004.3 Additional inspections. In addition to the initial or renewal inspections, inspections may be scheduled on one or more of the following bases: 
(1)  By area, such that all rental units in a predetermined geographical area will be inspected simultaneously, or within a short period of time. 
(2)  By written complaint, such that written complaints of violations will be inspected within a reasonable time. 
(3)  By recurrent violations, such that any rental unit or the owner of any rental unit which has been found to have a high incidence of recurrent or uncorrected violations will be inspected more frequently. 
(4)  Whenever reasonable cause exists to believe that there is a violation of this chapter on any premises or other conditions which make the structure or premises unsafe, dangerous, or hazardous. 
(5)  For the purpose of auditing inspections. 
(6)  For the purpose of reinspection to ensure the correction of any violations in existence at a previous inspection. 
1004.4 Inspections of class V licensed dwellings. A minimum of 20 percent of the units contained in those properties with a class V license shall be inspected prior to renewal with a minimum of four units inspected per structure. The units to be inspected shall be randomly selected. The number of units inspected may be increased at the discretion of the department should significant code violations be found or should the inspector have reasonable cause to believe other violations exist in the uninspected units. 
1004.5 Inspection notification and presence of owner at inspection. Owners shall be notified of inspections in accordance with the following: 
(1)  Initial or renewal inspections. The owner, the owner's legal agent, or a designated owner's representative, if any, shall be notified of and is entitled to be present at all initial and renewal inspections. If the owner desires a representative other than a legal agent to be present, the owner shall notify the department of planning, building and development. 
(2)  Prior to conducting an inspection for an initial rental unit license application or renewal, the code enforcement department shall give the owner or, if designated, the owner's legal agent, reasonable notice by first class mail sent to the address on file. The notice shall contain the date and time of the inspection. 
(3)  Investigative inspections. For any inspection authorized by this article other than an initial or renewal inspection, the department shall attempt to give the owner or owner's legal agent reasonable notification of the date and time of the inspection unless the chief code official has probable cause to believe the lack of notice is necessary for the appropriate conduct of an investigation. 
1004.6 Inspection authorization. An application for a rental unit license shall authorize the entry upon and inspection of the premises at all reasonable times as required by this chapter to the extent permitted by law. The failure of an owner to permit an inspection of the rental unit after notice is given shall constitute a withdrawal of the rental unit license application and a reason for denial of an application. 
1004.7 Inspection reports. Within 30 days after an initial or renewal inspection has been conducted, the department shall notify the owner or the owner's legal agent of the results of the inspection. The notice shall be personally served or sent to the address on file, by first class or electronic mail and shall include a description of any deficiencies required to be corrected, the nature and extent of any violations of city ordinances found, and in the case of violations of chapter 3 through 9 of this code, a reasonable time limit within which the violations must be corrected. A copy of the report shall be mailed to the tenants. 
1004.8 Private inspections. In the performance of the requirements of this chapter, the city manager may contract for inspection services. All inspection and test methods shall conform to generally accepted standards by qualified inspectors. If there are no generally recognized and accepted inspection and test methods, the city code official shall determine inspection and test procedures. All inspections and tests shall be made by licensed "trade" inspectors or by an agency approved by the city manager. The department may require the submission of detailed drawings and surveys properly sealed by registered architects and engineers. Reports of inspections and tests shall be submitted to the department and shall be retained in accordance with record retention requirements. 
SECTION 1005.0 ISSUANCE OF RENTAL UNIT LICENSES 
1005.1 Licensing authority. 
(1)  City Council. Licensing authority is vested in the City Council upon recommendation of the Housing Commission for the following license applications: 
(a)  All initial license applications except for properties that have gone through a plan of development to become a licensed class V residential dwelling; 
(b)  All applications to change a license classification; 
(c)  All renewal applications made beyond 1 year after the date of expiration of the previous license; 
(d)  Class I license applications for prospective owners of currently licensed class I rental properties in cases where the initial class I license was applied for subsequent to December 27, 2006; 
(e)  Class I license applications by new or prospective owners of previously licensed class I properties where the license expired within one year of the date of application and where the initial class I license was applied for subsequent to December 27, 2006. 
(f)  All license applications referred to the Housing Commission by the Chief Code Official pursuant to the provisions of this Code. 
(2)  Chief Code Official. Unless the application is referred to the Housing Commission by the Chief Code Official pursuant to the provisions of this Code, licensing authority is vested in the Chief Code Official for the following license applications: 
(a)  Initial license applications for properties that have gone through a plan of development to become a licensed class V residential dwelling; 
(b)  All applications for license renewal made within one year of expiration; 
(c)  Class II, III, IV, V and VI license applications by prospective owners of currently licensed class II, III, IV, V and VI properties; 
(d)  Class II, III, IV, V and VI license applications by prospective owners of previously licensed class II, III, IV, V and VI properties where the license expired within one year of the date of application; 
(e)  Class I license applications by prospective owners of currently licensed class I properties in those cases where the initial class I license was applied for prior to December 27, 2006; 
(f)  Class I license applications by new or prospective owners of previously licensed class I properties where the license expired within one year of the date of application and where the initial class I license was applied for prior to December 27, 2006. 
1005.2 Types of licenses. There are two types of rental licenses for each rental license classification: 
(1)  Conditional rental unit license: A conditional rental unit license is issued to an applicant applying for an initial license, applying for a change in classification or applying for issuance of a license when corrective work, which in the opinion of the code official does not affect the health or safety of any tenant, is required to be completed before the rental unit is in compliance with all City Code requirements. 
(2)  Regular rental unit license: A regular rental unit license is issued when all timed conditions placed on a license have been complied with and there is compliance with all City Code requirements applying to the physical structure of the rental unit. A regular rental unit license may have permanent conditions. 
1005.3 Requirements for issuance of a rental unit license for which licensing authority is vested with the City Council. No rental unit license for which the licensing authority is vested with City Council shall be issued until authorized by the city council subsequent to review and recommendation by the housing commission. 
(1)  Scheduling of review: A housing commission review shall take place within 40 working days from the date the department certifies that all inspections required by this Code and other appropriate provisions of the City Code have been completed. 
(2)  Deferral: A review may be deferred once, until the next regularly scheduled meeting of the housing commission: 
(a)  Upon request of the housing official; or 
(b)  Upon request of the applicant; or 
(c)  If the applicant fails to appear at the scheduled review as set forth in ES-1005.3(4). 
(3)  Notice: At least ten working days prior to the review, the secretary of the housing commission shall have notices of the date, time, and place of the review sent to: 
(a)  The owner/applicant and legal agent, along with copies of all documents provided to the commission; 
(b)  All owners of record of real property within a 300-foot radius of the proposed rental unit; 
(c)  The neighborhood association whose boundaries encompass the real property of the owner(s) of record notified in (3)(b), if any; and 
(d)  Any person who has submitted written comment concerning issuance of the license. 
(4)  Owner's presence required: The owner must be present at the review unless a majority of the commission members present permit an authorized representative to substitute for the owner. Where the owner is a corporation, partnership, limited liability company, or trust, an individual with operational responsibilities of the rental unit is considered to be the owner. Failure of an owner to appear shall result in the hearing being adjourned. Failure of an owner to appear for two consecutive hearings shall constitute a withdrawal of the application. 
(5)  Scope of review: The commission shall consider and review: 
(a)  The application and supporting documentation including floor plans and site plans, when required; 
(b)  The inspection report(s); 
(c)  Any public comment and/or written communications; 
(d)  The recommendation(s) of the department; 
(e)  Any relevant documentation including any building and/or zoning variances either applied for or granted, any easements, any comments regarding application of the historic district code, any site plan or special use permit conditions and any recommendations of the planning or zoning personnel; 
(f)  The prior inspection and ticket history of the property; 
(g)  In case of a requested change in classification, the reason the change is requested; 
(h)  Any documentation or comment submitted by the owner or legal agent; 
(i)  The prior history of the property owner and legal agent with regard to the maintenance, control, regulation and use of other properties owned or managed by the applicant or applicant's legal agent; 
(j)  Information regarding control or authority over the property by a person other than the owner or legal agent. 
(6)  Commission procedures: The commission shall adhere to Robert's Rules of Order when conducting a review and deliberations. The review of any license may be adjourned without new notices as required by paragraph (3)(b), (c), and (d) if upon adjournment the date, place, and time for the new hearing is announced. 
(7)  Property review standards: No initial rental unit license, class I license subject to a review hearing by this section, or change in classification shall be permitted until the rental unit is found to be in compliance with the following: 
(a)  The rental unit is served adequately by essential public facilities and services. 
(b)  The use of the rental unit does not cause traffic congestion or movement or on-street parking demands out of proportion to those normally prevailing in the zone in which the rental unit is located. 
(c)  The use of the rental unit does not result in a population density on the rental property site greater than the zoning limitations of the district in which the rental unit is located. 
(d)  For "class IV" and "class VI" license applications, the property meets all of the construction requirements of the mechanical code, the electrical code, the plumbing code, and fire code as enforced by the City of East Lansing unless a variance has been granted by the building board of appeals. 
(e)  The rental unit conforms to the building height, area, and yard requirements of the zoning district in which it is located. 
(f)  The rental unit provides facilities for the on-site parking of motor vehicles in compliance with the requirements of this chapter and chapter 50 of the City Code, and it will not cause motor vehicles to be stored or used on-site in excess of those normally prevailing for similar uses in the neighborhood. 
(g)  The rental unit is not the situs of any continuing or unresolved public nuisance as defined by chapter 14, article II, Litter, and chapter 26, article VI, Nuisances, of this Code or state law. 
(h)  The owner and the legal agent demonstrate sufficient ability to maintain and monitor the use of the rental unit to ensure that the proposed rental unit does not deteriorate with regard to internal and exterior maintenance, does not accumulate trash or rubbish, or does not become the situs of public nuisance as defined by chapter 14, article II, Litter, and chapter 26, article VI, Nuisances, of this Code or state law. 
(i)  For class I rental license applications where an initial class I rental license was not applied for prior to December 27, 2006, the applicant has owned and resided in the property for at least 18 months prior to submission of the application. 
(8)  Owner review standards for all properties: No initial rental unit license, change in classification or issuance of a license upon transfer of the property shall be issued to any person who was an officer, director, or controlling shareholder of a corporation, limited liability company or other business entity; or to any corporation, limited liability company or other business entity whose officers, directors, or controlling shareholders; or to any corporation, limited liability company or other business entity partnership, or individual that has: 
(a)  Failed to comply with any order of a hearings officer issued to abate a dangerous building pursuant to chapter 6, Buildings and Building Regulations, of the City Code; or 
(b)  Been convicted or found responsible of a violation of the maximum occupancy provisions of chapter 50, Zoning, of the City Code, within one year of the date of application; or 
(c)  Been convicted or found responsible of a violation of this chapter or chapter 6, Buildings and Building Regulations, related to the illegal use of non-habitable or occupiable space for sleeping purposes within one year of the date of application; or 
(d)  Been found responsible of a violation of ES-1010.4 (false statements); ES-1010.5 (failure to correct violation); ES-1010.6 (coercive conduct) within one year of the date of application; or 
(e)  Had a rental unit license suspended or revoked within one year of the date of the application and is not currently subject to a license suspension. 
1005.4 Commission action on application. At the conclusion of the review hearing required by section 1005.3, the housing commission shall, by majority vote present, as applicable: 
(1)  Unless the applicant demonstrates through a prior history of satisfactory performance as a rental unit license owner the ability to manage a rental property in conformity with the requirements of this Code, recommend that city council authorize a conditional license for an initial rental unit or change in classification. All conditional licenses for an initial rental unit or change in classification shall have, at a minimum, the following conditions: 
(a)  The license shall be valid for one year or upon sale of the property, whichever occurs first; 
(b)  During the first year of licensure, the owner or legal agent shall not lease the property for occupancy prior to compliance with any conditions imposed by city council which require compliance prior to occupancy. No right to continue licensure, beyond the first year, accrues or vests in the owner, the owner's agent, or the property itself; 
(c)  The property shall have reinspections as established by city council upon recommendation of the housing commission, with inspections more frequent than annually if the housing commission recommends and city council determines there is a need for more frequent inspections based upon the information provided at the hearing; 
(d)  One hundred twenty days prior to the conclusion of the first year of licensure, the owner shall apply for a regular rental unit license upon receipt of which, the chief code official shall notify all residents within 300 feet of the property of the receipt of the application and request the residents to notify the chief code official if they have evidence that the property has deteriorated or otherwise not met the licensing conditions; 
(e)  Upon expiration of the conditional license, the licensee shall demonstrate that the property has not deteriorated and has remained in compliance with all code provisions in chapter 1 and 10 of this code and that any violations of chapter 3-9 were corrected within the time allotted in the corrective order; 
(f)  Failure to demonstrate compliance with the conditions placed on the license shall disqualify the property for licensure for a period of one year from the date of denial of a regular license and any application after the one-year period shall be processed as an initial license application. 
(2)  The commission may also recommend that city council: 
(a)  Place a condition on the license requiring that corrective work be completed within a specified period of time if such corrective work, in the opinion of the code official, does not affect the health or safety of any tenant. Such a condition shall provide: 
(i)  The time for the completion of the corrective work to be done, but no longer than 180 days from the date of issuance of the approval of the license or the change of classification unless extended pursuant to section 1005.6 (extensions to comply with license conditions); 
(ii)  Completion of corrective work within the required time period set forth in the condition shall preclude the license from expiring by operation of law provided that the code official has issued a certificate of completion to the licensee; 
(iii)  Failure to have the corrective work completed within the permitted time shall cause the license to expire by operation of law. 
(b)  Recommend that city council impose additional conditions necessary to ensure compliance with the performance standards of section 1005.3(7) (review standards for properties that have not gone through a plan of development). These conditions may include: 
(i)  Requiring that the property owner designate and retain a local legal agent. 
(ii)  Requiring an increased frequency of inspections for a specified period. 
(iii)  Requiring a lease provision limiting the tenants to the parking of no more than one vehicle on the property per tenant. 
(iv)  Requiring a contact person to be designated and available to respond to complaints of code violations by tenants within 24 hours. 
(v)  Extending the conditional license for not more than one additional year. 
(vi)  Any other condition which is necessary to ensure compliance with the performance standards or other applicable law. 
(c)  Recommend that city council impose any conditions agreed to by the property owner that the commission deems appropriate. 
(3)  Recommend that city council deny the license application. The commission shall specify the legal and factual basis for its recommendation. 
1005.4a City council action on application for initial license or change in classification. The city council may, by majority vote of the council members present and voting, accept or reject, in whole or in part, the recommendation of the housing commission and either authorize or deny the issuance of a conditional license. The council, if authorizing issuance of a conditional license, may impose conditions on the license in accordance with 1005.4 in addition to or in lieu of any recommended by the housing commission. The council shall state the reasons for its decision on the record. The decision shall be reduced to writing by the city clerk and forwarded to the applicant within 14 days of the hearing. 
1005.5 Applications for a License for Which Licensing Authority Is Vested in the Chief Code Official. Upon receipt of an application for a license for which licensing authority is vested in the Chief Code Official, the department with concurrence of the chief code official: 
(1)  For a renewal, may issue a regular rental unit license of appropriate classification and occupancy continuing all permanent conditions placed on the license by the city council when there is compliance with all of the requirements of this article and all of the timed conditions set forth in any conditional license issued for the property. 
(2)  For any license, may place a new condition on the license requiring that corrective work be completed within a specified period of time when the corrective work does not affect the health or safety of any tenant of the rental unit. Such condition shall provide: 
(a)  The corrective work shall be completed no later than 180 days from the date the license is issued unless the chief code official, for good cause shown, extends the time for compliance, not to exceed 90 additional days. 
(b)  Completion of the corrective work within the required time period shall operate to preclude the license from expiring by operation of law provided the code official issues a certificate of completion to the owner. 
(c)  The chief code official may require the posting of a cash deposit in an amount not less than ten percent of the estimated costs of any corrective work required. The collection, retention, and return of any cash deposit shall be subject to existing applicable City Code provisions and administrative regulations. 
(d)  Failure to have the corrective work completed within the designated time shall cause the license to expire by operation of law. 
(3)  May refer the license application to the housing commission for review when required by section ES-1008.2 (terms and conditions); section ES-1008.3 (suspension); section ES-1008.4 (summary suspension); or section ES-1008.5 (revocation) or for review of the submitted site plan if the opinion of the chief code official indicates that a license condition is not adequate to ensure compliance with the requirements of section ES-1005.3(6)(a), (b), (f), (g), (h) or (j) or for review of a determination as to whether the owner has shown compliance with the license conditions of section ES-1005.4(1) if, upon receipt of notice of the owner's application for a renewal license sent pursuant to section ES-1005.4(1)(d), any of those notified file legitimate complaints of property deterioration or of the owner's failure to otherwise meet the license conditions with the chief code official. 
(4)  Shall deny a license application if the review standards of section ES-1005.3(7) or conditions placed on a property have not been met. 
1005.6 Extensions to comply with license conditions. If the housing official refuses to extend the time for compliance with a corrective work condition of a license, the licensee may appeal that decision to the housing commission and the housing commission may grant an extension of time not to exceed 90 additional days for compliance with a license condition placed upon the license pursuant to section 1005.4(2) or section 1005.5(2) upon good cause shown. The commission may require the posting of a cash deposit in an amount not less than ten percent of the estimated costs of the corrective work required. The collection, retention, and return of any cash deposit shall be subject to existing applicable City Code provisions and administrative regulations. 
1005.7 Anniversary date. The anniversary date of each rental license shall be established by the department upon issuance. The department may change an anniversary date for administrative convenience. The code official shall give reasonable notice to the owner and legal agent and prorate fees accordingly upon an administrative change. 
1005.8 Standard rental unit license provisions. A rental unit license shall show the following: 
(1)  The date of issuance and expiration date; 
(2)  The maximum number of persons who may occupy the rental unit; 
(3)  The street address and unit number of the rental unit; 
(4)  Notification that the rental unit license is subject to the imposition of terms and conditions, suspension, summary suspension, or revocation based upon failure to comply with the requirements of the City Code; 
(5)  The name, telephone number, and address of the owner and owner's legal agent; 
(6)  The type and classification of the rental unit license; 
(7)  Any requirements or restrictions imposed by the commission and Council on the license pursuant to sections 1005.4(2) and 1005.4a; 
(8)  For provisional rental unit licenses, a description of the corrective work required and timeframe for completion. 
(9)  For class III, IV, and V licenses, a statement as follows: "Each dwelling unit is considered separately licensed for the purpose of imposition of rental unit license sanctions." 
1005.9 Continuation of rental unit license sanctions. The issuance of a renewal license or the transfer of ownership of a rental unit does not modify or alter any sanction imposed unless issued pursuant to section 1005.5(3). 
1005.10 Effective date of license. A license is effective on the date of issuance by the department. A license authorized for a prospective owner is effective on the date of the transfer of ownership only if the new owner notifies the department in writing of the exact date ownership was transferred within ten working days of that date. 
1005.11 Rental unit license display. No class II, class III, class IV, or class VI rental unit may be occupied unless a copy of the current rental unit license for the rental unit is displayed in an 8 1/2-inch by 11-inch frame securely affixed to the interior wall adjacent to the primary entrance door to the rental unit. A class V rental unit shall display the license in the same manner at the primary entrance to each building. 
SECTION 1006.0 LEASE REQUIREMENTS 
1006.1 Written lease requirement. Except for a class I or class II license, after July 1, 1998, every owner of a rental unit licensed under this code shall execute a written lease, rental agreement or statement of understanding with every tenant. Subtenants assuming occupancy under a lease shall execute an acknowledgment of the requirements of section 1006.3 (required lease clauses), and provide a copy to the owner upon occupancy. 
1006.2 Filing of lease. Upon a request by the department, the owner or owner's legal agent shall provide the department a copy of the current lease or the lease immediately preceding the current lease for the rental unit within ten working days. 
1006.3 Required lease clauses. After July 1, 1998, no owner of a rental unit shall execute a lease unless each lessee is provided, and signs, a lease addendum binding on the owner and the lessee, in a form approved by the city council and containing no less than the following information: 
(1)  Specific information and provisions required by ordinance, statute, and administrative rules pertaining to security deposits, tenant rights, truth in leasing and renting, equal housing opportunity and a reference to the civil rights secured by chapter 22, article II of the City Code; 
(2)  The maximum occupancy limit of the leased rental unit for class III, IV, or V rental unit licenses, the maximum occupancy of the individual dwelling unit, and identification of specific occupiable and non-habitable spaces/rooms that cannot be used for sleeping purposes; 
(3)  Specific information and provisions clearly establishing tenant responsibilities for the payment of utility charges, routine maintenance, including but not limited to, lawn care, rubbish storage and disposal, garbage storage and disposal, litter, servicing of owner-supplied facilities and mechanical or electrical equipment, the day of the week the rubbish and recycling is collected, and any agreed-upon responsibilities for other forms of property maintenance or improvement; 
(4)  Statements in substantially the following form: 
(a)  That, upon the execution of this lease, every person executing this document as a tenant shall be jointly and severally responsible for maintaining maximum occupancy limits established by the city for the rental unit to which this agreement applies. Violations of occupancy limits are major violations which can result in substantial dollar fines, and the suspension or revocation of rental licenses; and 
(b)  That every occupant of a rental property shall cooperate with the owner or owner's legal agent as required by the International Property Maintenance Code; 
(5)  Specific information and provisions for the periodic inspection of any rental unit, accessory structure and premises by the owner or legal agent and authorized employees of the city at reasonable times and in a reasonable manner to ensure general property maintenance and to prevent over-occupancy and/or over-crowding; 
(6)  Any responsibilities of the tenant relative to public utility hookups, a utility security deposit, disconnections, service charges, and periodic fees or charges for service; 
(7)  Responsibility for the maintenance of all exterior areas and common areas of every rental unit property, including snow removal, grass cutting, and leaf removal. The tenant may not be held responsible for snow shoveling, grass cutting, or leaf removal unless the owner supplies snow shovels, a lawn mower, and/or leaf rakes, as appropriate. The owner shall maintain owner-supplied tools and equipment in good and proper working condition, and the tenant shall exercise reasonable care in their use and operation; 
(8)  Information on current resources available to tenants regarding rental housing issues and information regarding how to obtain maintenance; 
(9)  The name of each tenant and the driver's license number or State of Michigan identification number of each tenant; 
(10)  Except for a class V rental unit, a listing of those chapters of the City Code applicable to general property maintenance, off-street parking restrictions, rubbish and rubbish collection, garbage and garbage collection, preventing and eliminating litter, preventing and eliminating public nuisances, servicing of owner-supplied facilities and mechanical or electrical equipment, payment of utilities, penalties for over-occupancy, tenant focused code enforcement, periodic inspection processes and fees, and equal and fair housing opportunity; 
(11)  Reference to those provisions of the City Code and administrative regulations applicable to the physical alteration of existing structures, including the construction of lofts and floors over floors, by tenants; 
(12)  References to how tenants can obtain published and oral information on the rights and responsibilities of tenants from appropriate public sources prior to the execution of any lease or other form of rental agreement; and 
(13)  Except for class V rental units, neighborhood profile data applicable to the area in which the rental property is sited and organizational information on the neighborhood association serving the area in which the rental property is sited. 
(14)  Any other information required by administrative rules approved by city council. 
1006.4 Information to be provided at occupancy. At the time occupancy is given to the tenant, the owner or owner's legal agent shall provide each tenant with specific information on how to register to vote and the requirements to register, notice that election information and further registration information is available on the Secretary of State's website as well as the City's website through the City Clerk department, and a copy of the State of Michigan Voter Registration Application. The failure of an owner or owner's legal agent to do any act required by this section shall not be construed to affect the validity of the lease or the enforcement of any of the lease provisions. A violation of this section shall be deemed a civil infraction. 
SECTION 1007.0 RENTAL UNIT PARKING ADMINISTRATION 
    (This section reserved for future regulations regarding rental unit parking.) 
SECTION 1008.0 RENTAL UNIT LICENSE SANCTIONS 
1008.1 Rental unit license sanctions. The following types of sanctions may be imposed upon a rental unit license: 
(1)  Terms and conditions for a period to be determined by the housing commission; 
(2)  Suspension of a rental unit license for no more than 180 days beginning no sooner than 30 days from the date of the hearing and no later than at the end of the current lease period; 
(3)  Summary suspension of a rental unit license for no more than 180 days beginning immediately upon the effective date of the ruling; 
(4)  Revocation. 
For class III, IV, or V rental unit licenses, the bases for the imposition of sanctions as well as the sanctions imposed shall apply to the individual dwellings within the rental unit as opposed to the entire rental unit. 
1008.2 Bases for imposition of terms and conditions. The chief code official shall refer any rental unit license to the housing commission for consideration of the imposition of terms and conditions for any of the following reasons, unless the chief code official and owner or owner's legal agent stipulate to the imposition of terms and conditions designed to correct the specific problems which would require imposition of terms and conditions, and the commission agrees to the stipulation: 
(1)  The owner, occupants, and/or their guest on five or more separate occasions within a period of 12 months from August 15 to August 14 the following year or, for class VI licenses, within any 12-month period, have violated and been issued court appearance tickets, complaints, or citations for any state law or local ordinance on the licensed premises unless the owner or person acting on behalf of the owner was the part reporting the violation or, unless the owner or owner's legal agent has evicted the tenants. 
(2)  The owner, occupants, and/or their guests on two or more separate occasions within a period of 12 months from August 15 to August 14 the following year, or for class VI licenses, within any 12-month period, have violated and been issued court appearance tickets, criminal or civil complaints, or citation for any of the following statutes or ordinances on the licensed premises, unless the owner or person acting on behalf of the owner was the party reporting the violation or unless the owner or owner's legal agent has commenced eviction proceedings against the tenants: 
(a)  Nuisance party violation contrary to City Code section 26-141; 
(b)  Party bill violation contrary to City Code section 26-111; 
(c)  Noise violation contrary to City Code section 26-81(c); 
(d)  Unlawful discharge of a firearm contrary to City Code section 26-52(3) or state statute; 
(e)  Public disturbance, fight, or brawl contrary to City Code section 26-52(9); 
(f)  Operation of establishment for prostitution, illegal sale of intoxicating liquor or controlled substances, gambling, or other illegal business or occupation contrary to City Code section 26-52(13); 
(g)  Assault of a police officer or firefighter contrary to City Code section 26-52(18); 
(h)  Violation of the maximum occupancy, overcrowding, or illegal use of space provisions of the City Code; 
(i)  Violations of section 1010.5 (failure to correct violations). 
(3)  The owner, occupants, and/or their guests on three or more separate occasions, or on two separate occasions in combination with any one or more of those offenses listed in subsection (2) within a period of 12 months from August 15 to August 14 the following year, or for class VI licenses, within any 12-month period, have violated and been issued court appearance tickets or citations for noise violations on the licensed premises contrary to City Code section 26-81(b), unless the owner or person acting on behalf of the owner was the party reporting the violation or unless the owner or owner's legal agent has commenced eviction proceedings or otherwise removed the tenants. 
(4)  Failure by the chief code official to resolve repeated conflicts involving neighbors and public nuisance allegations through voluntary cooperative agreements between any complainant, property owner, or group of tenants. 
(5)  Terms and conditions stipulated to by the owner or owner's legal agent and chief code official have been violated. 
1008.3 Bases for rental license suspension. The chief code official shall refer any license to the housing commission for the suspension of a rental unit license for any of the following reasons: 
(1)  One or more additional bases exist for terms and conditions within 12 months of license sanctions being imposed where the terms and conditions had not been stipulated to by the owner or owner's legal agent and the chief code official and the owner has not taken appropriate corrective action. 
(2)  An adjudication by the district court that the owner, owner's legal agent, or person acting on behalf of the owner has: 
(a)  Violated the maximum occupancy provisions of the City Code; 
(b)  Illegally used or allowed the illegal use of non-habitable or non-occupiable space; 
(c)  Illegally converted space to occupiable or habitable use; 
(d)  Violated the provisions of section 1010.6 (coercive conduct) or section 1010.2 (occupancy without a license). 
(3)  Failure of the owner to comply with terms and conditions where the terms and conditions had not been stipulated to by the owner or owner's legal agent and the chief code official. 
(4)  A violation of section 102.6(2)(c) where the owner or owner's agent encourages a tenant to refuse entry to an inspector or where an owner refuses entry. 
(5)  Provisions of an approved site plan, special use permit, parking exception, or conditions of a building or zoning variance, if any, are not complied with, and the owner has not taken appropriate corrective action. 
1008.4 Bases for rental unit license summary suspension. The chief code official shall refer any license to the housing commission for the summary suspension of a rental unit license for any of the following reasons: 
(1)  Failure by an owner to comply with any order of a hearings officer issued to abate a dangerous building pursuant to chapter 6 of the City Code. 
(2)  Declaration by the city manager that a dwelling or structure has been the situs of a nuisance party as defined by section 26-141 of the City Code within 12 months from the date in which terms and conditions or property management plan was imposed upon the license and the owner has not acted to abate the nuisance or taken corrective action following notice of such nuisance to the owner or the owner's legal agent. 
(3)  Formal declaration by the city manager that a dwelling, structure, or premises constitutes a continuing public nuisance in accordance with provisions of section 26-4 of the City Code, and the owner has not acted to abate the nuisance. 
(4)  Failure to comply with or maintain the permanent requirements and restrictions associated with a rental unit license pursuant to section 1005.4(3) after notification of a prior violation. 
(5)  If an additional violation of the statutes or ordinances listed in section 1008.2(2) occurs within 12 months of terms and conditions being imposed pursuant to section 1008.2(2) after the owner has been given notice of the violation and the owner has failed to take satisfactory corrective action. 
(6)  Failure by the owner or the owner's legal agent to correct major code violations that constitute a danger to the basic health or safety of occupants or the general public by the compliance date stated in any emergency order or corrective order. 
(7)  Formal declaration by the chief code official that all or part of an existing structure is dangerous or unfit for human habitation. 
(8)  Documented violations by the occupants of terms and conditions imposed on the rental unit license, and the owner has not taken corrective action. 
1008.5 Bases for license revocation. The chief code official may refer any license to the housing commission for the revocation of the rental license for any of the following reasons: 
(1)  Failure by an owner to comply with any emergency order issued in conjunction with the suspension of a license or violation notice and corrective order issued in conjunction with the suspension of a license. 
(2)  One or more bases for rental license suspension exist within two years of the license previously having been suspended. 
(3)  The owner or owner's legal agent is convicted or found responsible for making false statements on a rental license application or making false statements to an employee of the city contrary to section 1010.4. 
(4)  The owner or owner's legal agent has committed arson or attempted arson involving the rental unit. 
1008.6 Rental unit license sanction hearings. Rental unit license sanction hearings shall be conducted in conformance with the following procedures. Each hearing shall be conducted in two parts, usually at the same meeting: a findings hearing to determine whether a sufficient basis exists for the imposition of sanctions and, if there is a sufficient basis, a sanction hearing to determine the specific sanctions. 
(1)  Scheduling of hearings. The commission shall conduct a license sanction hearing to be held at a regular or special commission meeting as soon as practicable after the chief code official refers a recommendation for possible sanctions to the commission. 
(2)  Notice. At least ten working days prior to the hearing, the secretary of the housing commission shall have notices of the date, time, and place of the hearing sent to: 
(a)  The owner and legal agent, along with copies of all documents provided to the commission; 
(b)  The occupants of the premises; 
(c)  All owners or record of the dwellings within a 300-foot radius of the rental unit; 
(d)  The neighborhood association(s) whose boundaries encompass the properties of the owners of record noticed in subsection 2(c), if any; and 
(e)  Any person who has submitted written comment, filed complaint(s) regarding the rental unit, or who has requested notification. 
(3)  Part 1--Commission findings hearing. To determine whether a sufficient basis exists for the imposition of sanctions, the commission shall review: 
(a)  Any evidence establishing the bases for license sanctions presented by city employees, rental unit's occupants, or other persons; 
(b)  Any evidence or comment presented by the owner, legal agent, and/or representative; 
(c)  Commission procedures. The commission shall adhere to Robert's Rules of Order, Newly Revised when conducting hearings or deliberations. The owner or owner's representative and all commissioners are entitled to examine any person presenting evidence in support of a license sanction at the findings hearing. 
(4)  Commission findings. After hearing all evidence, the housing commission shall make a determination as to whether or not sufficient evidence has been presented to impose sanctions and, if so, the specific basis for the imposition of sanctions. The failure of the chief code official to refer a rental unit license to the housing commission for license sanctions shall not be a basis for the commission to fail to find a sufficient basis to impose license sanctions on a later referral. Neither a complaint and warrant which is dismissed or ruled invalid, nor an appearance ticket or complaint for which a copy was not provided to the owner or the owner's legal agent within ten days of its issuance shall be considered for the imposition of sanctions. 
(5)  Part 2--Commission sanction hearing. If the commission determines there is a basis for the imposition of sanctions, it shall review: 
(a)  The recommended sanction(s) by the chief code official and staff comment; 
(b)  Any public comment; 
(c)  Any comment presented by the owner, the owner's legal agent, and/or owner's representative; 
(d)  Any corrective action taken by the owner or owner's legal agent prior to referral; 
(e)  Any corrective action taken by the owner or owner's legal agent subsequent to referral and prior to the hearing; 
(f)  The degree of cooperation exhibited by the owner/legal agent in attempting to resolve the problems leading to the referral. A presumption of cooperation shall be made where the basis for sanctions is tenant behavior and the owner has, prior to referral: 
(i)  Requested the assistance of a community police officer, to conduct an informal conference with the tenants; or 
(ii)  Submitted a management plan signed by the tenants outlining action to be taken to resolve recurring problems; or 
(iii)  Successfully removed the tenant(s) or commenced eviction proceedings. 
(g)  The severity of each violation; 
(h)  The history of the property or owner as documented by the department. 
(6)  Commission action. At the conclusion of the sanction hearing, the commission shall render a decision to do one of the following: 
(a)  Impose specific terms and conditions onto the rental unit license designed to correct the specific problems that brought the license to the commission for sanctions including, but not limited to, at the direction of the commission, any or all of the following: 
(i)  A requirement for an increased frequency of inspections; 
(ii)  A requirement that the owner or legal agent and, when appropriate, the tenants file a property management plan; 
(iii)  A limit on the number of guests allowed on the premises; 
(iv)  If the violations are for illegal use of space, a reduction in the occupancy limit for the remainder of the term of the lease; 
(v)  A prohibition of alcohol use on the premises; or 
(vi)  The execution of a performance agreement including the posting of a cash deposit in an amount not less than ten percent of the estimated costs of any corrective work. The collection, retention, and return of any cash deposit shall be subject to existing applicable City Code provisions and administrative regulations; 
(b)  If recommended for suspension, impose specific terms and conditions or suspend the rental unit license; or 
(c)  If recommended for summary suspension, impose specific terms and conditions, suspend the rental unit license, summarily suspend the rental unit license; or 
(d)  If recommended for revocation, suspend or revoke the rental unit license; or 
(e)  Decline to impose any sanctions against the rental unit license. 
(7)  Notice of decision. The secretary of the housing commission shall serve, by certified mail, the decision of the commission on the owner or legal agent of the rental unit within ten working days from the date of the hearing along with notification of the right to appeal. 
1008.7 Emergency rental license suspension. The city manager may suspend a current rental unit license when, in the opinion of the city manager, there is actual and immediate danger to the safety or health of occupants due to structural damage and unsanitary conditions. The city manager is empowered to order and require the occupants to vacate all or part of the structure and premises in accordance with the provisions of section 104.9 Emergency Orders. Upon the issuance of a rental unit license suspension order, the department shall forward a copy of the order to the commission, and the commission shall schedule a review hearing to be held no later than 15 days from the date of the order, after which the commission shall affirm, modify, or dissolve the order. 
1008.8 Notice to occupants. The department shall serve, by first class mail, proper notice to every tenant of a rental unit of any license sanction and by posting the notice on the main entrance to the rental unit. 
1008.9 Reinstatement of suspended license. A suspended license shall be automatically reinstated upon completion of the suspension period unless the license expires during the term of suspension. Application for a renewal of a license that expires during the term of suspension may be made and shall be processed in the same manner as a renewal application. 
1008.10 Application for new license after revocation. For licenses that have been revoked, application for a new license may be made after one year from the date the revocation was effective. The application shall be processed in the same manner as an initial license application. 
SECTION 1009.0 APPEALS 
1009.1 Council appeal and review hearings; time limits.
