ARTICLE II. - LITTER 

Sec. 14-31. - Definitions. 
(a)  Where terms are not defined in this article and are defined in the housing, building or zoning codes, they shall have the same meanings ascribed to them as in those codes and other codes as adopted by the City of East Lansing. 
(b)  Where terms are not defined, through the methods authorized by this section, they shall have their ordinarily accepted meanings such as the context may imply. 
(c)  The following definitions shall apply to any interpretation of this article, except where the context clearly indicates that another meaning is intended. 
    Abandoned motor vehicles means a motor vehicle stored on or parked on any private premises without the consent of the owner or person in control of such private premises, or for a period of 48 hours or more after the consent has been revoked, or a motor vehicle left unattended on public property or on private property that does not display current year registration plates. 
    Garbage means putrescible animal and vegetable wastes resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking, and consumption of food. 
    Inoperable motor vehicle means motor vehicles which by means of dismantling, disrepair, lack of current registration and/or a valid registration tag conspicuously attached to the vehicle in the manner required by law, or other cause, not including being considered to be a "junk vehicle," are incapable of being propelled under their own power or legally operated by the owner. 
    Junk refers to all waste materials from normal household living conditions and business operations which cannot be readily classified under other definitions contained herein that are abandoned, in disuse, and otherwise not being utilized in accordance with their original design, intent, and purpose. "Junk" shall include household furniture and furnishings such as upholstered chairs and sofas and mattresses and carpeting which are not constructed or designed for outdoor use and which are located in yards or other areas open to the elements while not in actual use. 
    Junk vehicle means any motor vehicle which is inoperative because of being in a state of disassembly, disrepair, dismantled, stripped of major parts and components, undergoing major overhaul or body work, or in any manner fails to comply with the state Motor Vehicle Code or any other appropriate state or federal statutory requirements in connection with registration, licensing, and the operability of any of its component parts. 
    Litter means rubbish, refuse and garbage and trash or junk as hereinafter defined, and all other waste material which, if thrown or deposited as herein prohibited, tends to create a public nuisance as defined by chapter 26 of the City Code or which is detrimental to the public health, safety, and general welfare. 
    Motor vehicles means any wheeled vehicles which are self-propelled, or intended to be self-propelled, not operating on rails. 
    Party litter means bottles, cans, cups, kegs, food wrappers or containers, and other waste material which, if thrown or deposited as herein prohibited, tends to create a public nuisance as defined in chapter 26 of the City Code, or which is detrimental to the public health, safety and general welfare. 
    Private premises means any lot or parcel of land owned or occupied by any person whether or not improved with any dwelling, house, building, or other structure, whether inhabited, or temporarily or continuously uninhabited, or vacant, and shall include any yard, grounds, walk, driveway, porch, steps, vestibule, or mailbox belonging or appurtenant to any dwelling, house, building, or other structure erected thereon. 
    Public place means any and all streets, as defined in chapter 38, article II, pertaining to streets, of the City of East Lansing Code and all sidewalks, boulevards, alleys, or other public ways, and any and all public parks, plazas, squares, spaces, grounds, and buildings. 
    Refuse means all putrescible and nonputrescible solid wastes including garbage, rubbish, ashes, street cleanings, dead animals, abandoned or inoperable motor vehicles, junk, and solid market and industrial wastes. 
    Rubbish means all miscellaneous waste materials and matter resulting from normal household or living conditions, business operations and enterprises, general routine property use and maintenance, physical construction and installations related to general routine property use, waste materials from industrial and business operations, and waste materials from the construction or repair of buildings and structures. The term "rubbish" shall include all forms of nonputrescible solid wastes consisting of either type of the following wastes or any similar related combinations thereof: 
(1)  Combustible wastes, including but not limited to, paper products, cardboard, tobacco products, leaves, tree and plant trimmings, garden rubbish, yard clippings, discarded Christmas trees and wreaths, discarded plants and flowers, wood, wood products, rubber products such as vehicle tires, rags, discarded clothing, leather products, discarded furniture, furnishings and fixtures, excelsior, trash and junk, and other similar materials or matter. 
(2)  Noncombustible wastes, including but not limited to, concrete; rubble; gravel; stone; rock; residue from the burning of wood, coal, coke, and other combustible materials; plastic containers and products; materials or products comprised of steel, iron, aluminum and other noncombustible elements; metal frames and products; discarded furniture and fixtures; appliances and fixtures; glass; crockery; tin cans; mineral matter; scrap metal; parts from motorized and nonmotorized vehicles; discarded plastic and metal toys; household appliances; trash; and other similar materials or matter. 
    Rubble means rough, irregular and loose fragments of concrete, masonry or rock broken from larger bodies by natural processes or human actions. 
    Trash means parts that have been torn off, broken off, or stripped from natural and human-made combustible and noncombustible matter, including, but not limited to, trees, shrubs, plants, motorized and non-motorized vehicles, building materials, buildings and structures. 
(Code 1994, ch. 63, §§ 6.101, 6-102) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-7. 
Sec. 14-32. - Litter in public places. 
    No person shall throw or deposit litter in or upon any street, sidewalk, or other public place within the city, except in public receptacles, or in authorized private receptacles for collection. 
(Code 1994, ch. 63, § 6.103) 
Cross reference- Solid waste, ch. 36. 
Sec. 14-33. - Use of waste receptacles. 
    Persons placing litter in public receptacles or in authorized private receptacles shall do so in such a manner as to prevent it from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any street, sidewalk, or other public place, or upon private property. 
(Code 1994, ch. 63, § 6.104) 
Cross reference- Solid waste, ch. 36. 
Sec. 14-34. - Sweeping litter into gutter or street; duty to maintain sidewalk free of litter. 
(a)  Generally. No person shall sweep into or deposit in any gutter, street, or other public place within the city, litter from any building or lot or from any public or private sidewalk or driveway. Persons owning or occupying property shall keep the sidewalk and the area between the curb and sidewalk in front of their premises free of litter. 
(b)  Businesses. No person owning or occupying a place of business shall sweep into or deposit in any gutter, street, or other public place within the city, litter from any building or lot or from any public or private sidewalk or driveway. Persons owning or occupying places of business within the city shall keep the sidewalk and the area between the sidewalk and curb in front of their business premises free of litter. 
(Code 1994, ch. 63, §§ 6.105, 6.106) 
Cross reference- Solid waste, ch. 36; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 38. 
Sec. 14-35. - Litter on private property. 
    No person shall throw or deposit litter on any private premises within the city, whether owned by such person or not, except that the owner or person in control of occupied private premises may maintain authorized private receptacles for collection as prescribed by chapter 36, article III of the City Code and in such a manner that litter will be prevented from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any street, sidewalk, or other public place, or upon any private property. 
(Code 1994, ch. 63, § 6.107) 
Cross reference- Solid waste, ch. 36. 
Sec. 14-36. - Abandoned or inoperable motor vehicles. 
    No person shall store on, or place in, or permit to be stored on, or remain on, any private premises within the city, an abandoned or inoperable motor vehicle, part, or parts of a motor vehicle, unless said motor vehicle, part, or parts of a motor vehicle shall be kept in a wholly enclosed garage or other structure meeting the requirements of the City Code for such use. 
(Code 1994, ch. 63, § 6.108) 
Cross reference- Traffic and vehicles, ch. 44. 
Sec. 14-37. - Owner and occupant to maintain premises free of litter; recovery of costs by owner when violation is caused by occupant. 
(a)  The owner and occupant, as the case may be, shall at all times maintain the premises free of litter, including, but not limited to, the accumulation of any litter within yard areas, open accessory structures and along fence lines, provided, however, that this section shall not prohibit the storage of litter in authorized private receptacles for collection. 
(b)  The owner of a property who is found to be responsible for a violation of this article charged as a civil infraction has the right to recover in a civil action against the occupant who caused or allowed the violation, damages in the amount of any civil fine, costs or expenses assigned by the court. The owner of a premises may provide in a written agreement that the person who caused or allowed a violation of this article, when the violation is a civil infraction, shall indemnify the owner for any civil fine, costs and expenses imposed upon the owner for that civil infraction. 
(Code 1994, ch. 63, § 6.109) 
Sec. 14-38. - Enforcement generally; notice to abate. 
(a)  The chief of police is charged with the enforcement of this article for all properties within the City of East Lansing and may, for such purposes, assign enforcement to limited duty parking and property maintenance officers. Except as otherwise provided herein, the enforcing officer shall notify the owner and occupant, as the case may be, of any violation of this article in the manner provided by subsection 1-11(a)(1) and (2) of the East Lansing City Code, or by posting the notice in some conspicuous place on the land or attaching the notice to the entrance of the building or structure and shall specify a compliance time in the notice, such time not to be less than two days nor more than three days from the time said notice is served. 
(b)  In the case of a violation involving party litter, a notice issued to an occupant shall be complied with in no more than eight hours from the time the notice is served if served by being posted on the property and no more than two hours if personally served on an occupant. Where it is evident the party litter was generated by the occupants or guests of occupants of the property where the litter has accumulated, a municipal civil infraction citation may be issued to the occupants pursuant to section 14-40 without a prior notice to abate. If a municipal civil infraction citation is issued without a prior notice to abate pursuant to this section, a notice to abate shall also be issued pursuant to this section. Failure to abate the property within the time specified in the notice shall constitute a separate offense. 
(c)  In the case of a violation involving furniture or other bulk rubbish that has not lawfully been placed for collection in accordance with article III of chapter 36 of the City Code, a violation notice issued to an occupant or owner shall be complied with within two hours if personally served on an occupant or the owner or within eight hours if the violation notice has been served by posting the notice on the property. If the property is not owner occupied, the owner or owner's legal agent of the property may only be issued a citation under this provision if they have been personally served with the notice or if the notice has been posted and the owner or owner's legal agent has been notified of the posting by electronic mail or by telephone. If the violation is occurring on the public right-of-way, a municipal civil infraction may be issued to the owner or occupant of the adjacent property owner pursuant to the terms of this provision. If the property was leased on the date of the violation and the tenants were still occupying the property on that date, the owner may charge any fines and costs assessed as a result of a citation issued under this section to the tenant's security deposit if the lease or lease addendum advises the tenants of the ability of the landlord to make such charges and the tenants have initialed that portion of the lease or lease addendum. 
    With respect to this paragraph, compliance after notice of a violation shall mean one of the following: 
(1)  Removal or storage of the item(s) in a fully enclosed building. 
(2)  The placement of a bulk rubbish sticker issued by the city on the item(s) if the item(s) are otherwise properly in compliance with City Code requirements with respect to time, placement and location for bulk rubbish pick up. 
(Code 1994, ch. 63, § 6.110; Ord. No. 1011, 6-4-2002; Ord. No. 1260, 4-5-2011; Ord. No. 1300, 8-6-2013) 
Sec. 14-39. - Reinspections; continuing enforcement. 
    The enforcing officer shall conduct a reinspection to determine if the required corrective action has been completed to abate the public nuisance. In the event of noncompliance, continuing enforcement action shall take place in accordance with provisions of this article by the issuance of a citation for a municipal civil infraction and/or by abatement as provided in section 14-42. 
(Code 1994, ch. 63, § 6.111) 
Sec. 14-40. - Penalty; appearance tickets and citations. 
(a)  Except as provided herein and in section 14-44, any person found responsible for a violation of this article shall be responsible for a municipal civil infraction as defined by MCL 600.113 punishable as provided by section 1-13 of this Code. 
(b)  A person found responsible for a violation designated as a party litter violation issued with or without a prior notice shall be fined according to the following schedule: 
(1)  For a first offense, $50.00. 
(2)  For an offense committed after one prior offense, $100.00. 
(3)  For an offense committed after two prior offenses, $200.00. 
(4)  For an offense committed after three or more prior offenses $400.00 
(c)  For purposes of this section a prior offense means an occupant or owner of the property for which the current violation applies has had a judgment entered against them for a violation of section 14-37 for that property within the last 180 days. 
(d)  To charge a violation as a subsequent offense, the issuing officer shall note on the citation that it is a subsequent offense and all dates of the prior offenses and all of the names of all persons or entities to whom the prior citations were issued that make it a subsequent offense. 
(e)  Limited duty parking and property maintenance officers appointed by the city manager and assigned to enforcement of the provisions of this article under the supervision of the chief of police shall be authorized to issue and serve appearance tickets with respect to any violation of this article. Cases commenced under this article shall, to the extent applicable, be commenced by the issuance of a citation to the alleged violator in the manner provided by MCL 600.8709 and MCL 600.8711. 
(Code 1994, ch. 63, § 6.112; Ord. No. 1260, 4-5-2011) 
Sec. 14-41. - Public nuisance declaration. 
    Any litter which is detrimental to the public health, safety and general public welfare, is hereby declared a public nuisance as defined by chapter 26 of the City Code, and shall be so designated in the notice to abate. 
(Code 1994, ch. 63, § 6.113) 
Sec. 14-42. - Abatement by city. 
    If, at the expiration of the compliance time limit set forth in the notice to abate, the owner, person in charge, or occupant, as the case may be, has not complied with the requirements thereof, the city manager shall take such steps, as in his or her judgment, may be necessary to directly abate such nuisance in addition to invoking any other penalty or proceeding authorized by the City Code. The cost of abating such nuisance, including inspection, direct expenses associated with the removal of litter, and administrative expenses not to exceed 15 percent of all other costs, shall constitute a lien against the private premises and shall be charged to the owner thereof. If not paid within 60 days after the invoice for such costs are served, such charges may be collected as a single lot assessment against said premises in the manner provided by section 13.18 of the City Charter or in any other manner authorized for the collection of debts owed the city. 
(Code 1994, ch. 63, § 6.114) 
Sec. 14-43. - Emergency abatement. 
    For any public nuisance involving any land, building or structure other than occupied dwellings, the city manager, or designee, may abate any such public nuisance without giving notice if the public health or safety requires immediate action. The cost of abating such nuisance may be assessed against the property in the manner prescribed by section 14-42. 
(Code 1994, ch. 63, § 6.115) 
Sec. 14-44. - Entry on premises. 
    After notice and reinspection as provided by sections 14-38 and 14-39, the city manager or designee and any authorized inspector or representative are hereby empowered to enter upon any premises in the city for the purpose of removing or abating litter declared to constitute a public nuisance under this article, chapter 26, or any other applicable provisions of the City Code. No person shall deny entry to or otherwise obstruct, molest or interfere with the city manager or designee, while they are engaged in removing or abating litter as provided herein. Any person convicted of a violation of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and punished as provided by section 1-12 of the City Code. 
(Code 1994, ch. 63, § 6.116) 
Secs. 14-45-14-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - RODENT AND VERMIN CONTROL 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 14-71. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this article, the following terms shall have the meaning hereinafter ascribed. 
    Fumigation means the application of pesticide gases to or within enclosed buildings, structures, or other indoor areas used or meant for occupation by persons or domestic animals. 
    Fumigator means a person certified and currently licensed by the director of the department of agriculture as a "commercial applicator" under the provisions of Public Act No. 451 of 1994 (MCL 324.8301 et seq.), and certified as meeting the additional standards for "space fumigation" as provided in subdivision (b) of Rule 4 of Regulation 636 promulgated under Public Act No. 451 of 1994. 
    Pesticide means any substance, or mixture of substances, intended to prevent, destroy, repel, or mitigate pests, or used or intended as a plant regulator, defoliant, or desiccant. This term shall include insecticides directed against insects, herbicides directed against weeds and plants, fungicides directed against fungi, rodenticides directed against rodents or any other vertebrate animal and antibiotics or bactericides used against bacteria. 
(Code 1994, ch. 110, § 9.191) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-7. 
Secs. 14-72-14-90. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - FUMIGATION 

Sec. 14-91. - License required. 
    No person shall engage in the trade, work, or occupation of exterminating insects, vermin, rodents, or other pests, including germs, by the process of fumigation, in which process of fumigation is used hydrocyanic acid gas, any derivation of cyanide, any gas of the halogen group, carbon monoxide gas, or any other lethal gas, fumes, or vapors, except he be a licensed fumigator, or have a licensed fumigator in his employ. 
(Code 1994, ch. 110, § 9.192) 
Sec. 14-92. - Supervision of work. 
    No person shall fumigate any building, structure, or part thereof, or cause the same to be fumigated by the use of any such gases, fumes, or vapors, unless a licensed fumigator is in attendance and personally supervises all preparations and fumigation and the flushing and airing after fumigation, unless a permit is procured as hereinafter provided. 
(Code 1994, ch. 110, § 9.193) 
Sec. 14-93. - Permit. 
    No person shall use any such gases, fumes, or vapors in the fumigation of a building or structure or any part thereof, except a licensed fumigator, without first obtaining a permit as provided in this article. 
(Code 1994, ch. 110, § 9.194) 
Sec. 14-94. - Special permit required for fumigation of certain buildings. 
(a)  No person, whether or not he is a licensed fumigator, shall fumigate any building, structure, or any part thereof by the use of any such gases, fumes, or vapors, where the wall of any other building or structure adjoins it or is contiguous thereto, or is located within ten feet thereof, without first obtaining a special permit from the health officer or his authorized representative. No fee shall be charged for such permit. 
(b)  No special permit shall be issued until the health officer or his authorized representative shall determine that the proposed fumigation can be conducted without endangering health, life, or property. No fumigator shall fumigate any such building, structure, or part thereof except in strict compliance with the specifications and conditions of such permit. 
(Code 1994, ch. 110, § 9.196) 
Sec. 14-95. - Safety measures. 
    No fumigator shall fumigate any building, structure, or any part thereof by the use of such gases, fumes, or vapors, unless he shall comply with all the safety measures enumerated in this section: 
(1)  Notification of police and fire department. At least four hours before any such gases, fumes, or vapors are generated or liberated, the fumigator shall notify the office of the police chief and the fire chief of the proposed fumigation, the address of the place to be fumigated, the time it will start, and the type of fumigant to be used. 
(2)  Inspection and instructions to occupants. The fumigator shall personally inspect the premises before any fumigation is started and shall give the occupant thereof a printed list of precautions and instructions, which list shall include the following items of information in detail: 
a.  The dangerous characteristics of the fumigant to be used; 
b.  The time fumigation will start and the length of time it will continue; 
c.  The length of time the premises must remain vacant; 
d.  The items of food, drink, and material that must be removed; and 
e.  The warning concerning bed clothing and opening of bedroom windows. 
(3)  Personal inspection by fumigator required. Immediately before any fumigation is started, the fumigator shall, by a personal inspection determine the following: 
a.  That the entire building or structure of which any part is to be fumigated has been entirely vacated by human beings and domestic animals and that all ice and any food and drink likely to be affected by the fumigant has been removed; 
b.  That all openings through which gas may escape in dangerous quantities have been sealed; 
c.  That all entrances and doors, except one, have been securely locked and fastened in such a manner that they cannot be opened from the outside even though the proper keys be used in such effort; 
d.  That a suitable warning card has been securely affixed to each entrance, which card shall have printed thereon in English, with black letters, not less than three inches in height, the words, "DANGER-KEEP AWAY-POISON GAS," and shall also give the name, address, and telephone number of the fumigator. 
(4)  Locking and guarding exit door. Before any gases, fumes, or vapors are generated or liberated, the fumigator shall lock from the inside the door through which he will leave the building or structure after releasing the gas. Upon leaving, the fumigator shall securely fasten the exit door in such a manner that it cannot be opened by another person even though the proper key for that door be used. A responsible adult guard shall be posted on the premises at all times throughout the period of fumigation. 
(5)  Ventilation. At the conclusion of the period of fumigation, the fumigator shall release the gases, fumes, or vapors in a careful manner so that they are transmitted to the outside air in such a manner that health and life will not be endangered and so as to ventilate thoroughly and air the entire building or structure. The fumigator shall further see that all rooms and other enclosed areas are free of dangerous concentrations of gases, fumes, or vapors, and that no such dangerous concentrations remain at any place on the premises. 
(6)  Control of fumigants. No fumigants shall be dropped on the floor or left exposed where persons or domestic animals may come in contact with them. 
(Code 1994, ch. 110, § 9.197) 
Sec. 14-96. - Entry of persons into fumigated buildings. 
    No person, other than the fumigator, or a city officer or employee in the discharge of duty, shall enter any place where fumigation has been carried on until all traces of gases, fumes, or vapors have disappeared and the warning signs have been removed by the fumigator or the health officer and in no event shall any person enter, or be permitted to enter, any such premises until 12 hours after the ventilation thereof has been started; nor shall any aged, infirm, or convalescent adult nor any child under the age of six years enter, or be permitted on, such premises until 24 hours after ventilation has been started. The fumigator shall determine when re-entry may be made, and who may re-enter and occupy the premises, and shall not remove or permit the removal of warning signs until after the lapse of time herein prescribed, nor until after a re-inspection of the entire building or structure. The fumigator shall remove the warning sign, and all fumigants and equipment remaining on the premises, promptly after expiration of such 24-hour time limit. 
(Code 1994, ch. 110, § 9.198) 
Sec. 14-97. - Authority to make additional regulations. 
    The health officer is authorized and directed to make, publish, and enforce such rules and regulations relative to fumigation with gases, fumes, or vapors as are not in conflict with this article as he may deem necessary for the protection of life and health. No person shall violate any such rules and regulations. 
(Code 1994, ch. 110, § 9.199) 
Secs. 14-98-14-120. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - APPLICATION OF PESTICIDES 

Sec. 14-121. - Notice requirements. 
    No person shall apply, nor allow to be applied, any pesticide upon or within any yard or other unenclosed area or premises or within any enclosed building or structure within the city without posting or providing notice as follows: 
(1)  In the case of yard or lawn applications, the applicator shall place at conspicuous points and at common access points signs of a size, construction, and location calculated to provide notice to neighbors and passersby. The signs shall conform to specifications prescribed by the city clerk or conform to specifications prescribed by the director of the state department of agriculture under Public Act No. 451 of 1994 (MCL 324.8301 et seq.), shall be displayed with the bottom edge not less than 12 inches above grade and the top edge not more than 31/2 feet above grade, and shall be maintained in place for not less than 24 hours. 
(2)  In the case of applications by fogging, spraying, dusting, or any other method whereby any detectable amount of the material may be deposited beyond the applicator's property line, the applicator or person in control of the premises shall provide notice to occupants of abutting properties within adequate time prior to the application to allow occupants to take necessary precautions, which notice will describe by trade and generic name the pesticide to be applied and the expected time and location of application. In case of applications by persons required to be licensed under MCL 324.8301 et seq., the notice shall be delivered in writing. In the case of applications by property owners not required to be licensed under MCL 324.8301 et seq., the notice may be oral or written, but if the occupant of an abutting property is not available to receive oral notice, the notification shall be in writing and, if the occupant of an abutting property wishes to be notified in writing, he or she shall so inform the applicator in writing, and the applicator shall thereafter make all notifications in writing. 
(3)  If an applicator plans a regular program or schedule of applications by fogging, spraying, dusting, or any other method whereby any detectable amount of the material may be deposited beyond the applicator's property line, the applicator may notify the occupants of abutting properties by means of a single written notice which meets the requirement of subsection (2) of this section and which sets forth the planned dates of application. If, with respect to a given application, the applicator deviates from the planned program or schedule of applications, the applicator shall for that application comply with the requirements of subsection (2) of this section. 
(4)  In the case of application within any enclosed building or structure, the applicator shall provide and post at each point of entrance to the premises a decal showing the date of application. Such decal shall be in the form and carry the symbol and wordings prescribed by the city clerk to inform the users and public that pesticides have been applied within the premises. The decal shall have a space provided on which the date of application or the practice of continuous application is to be indicated. Each person in control of such premises shall cause the decal to remain posted until replaced at the time of the next application or 90 days have passed, whichever first occurs. 
(5)  In any case where a pesticide is directly discharged or drifts beyond the premises being treated, and prior notice under subsection (2) of this section has not been given to occupants of an affected abutting property, the applicator shall, before leaving the site, provide oral or written notice to the occupants of the affected property advising of the materials used and the time and circumstances of the discharge or drift. 
(6)  The requirements of this section shall not apply to the application of dormant oils, summer oils, and pesticidal soaps which do not contain insecticides with active toxic ingredients. 
(Code 1994, ch. 110, § 9.201) 
Sec. 14-122. - Method of application; safety requirements. 
    All persons applying pesticides shall at all times adhere to safe and proper application methods, shall use the application rates and methods, and follow the special instructions and precautions indicated on the product label. 
(Code 1994, ch. 110, § 9.202) 
Sec. 14-123. - Exceptions to notice requirements. 
    The notice requirements of this division shall not apply to the following persons or circumstances: 
(1)  Applications within enclosed buildings or structures by any person licensed as a fumigator by the Michigan Department of Agriculture pursuant to MCL 324.8301 et seq. 
(2)  Applications to yards and lawns which are completely enclosed by a fence or wall at least four feet in height with latched gates or doors, and by means which will prevent the drift or deposit of any detectible amount of pesticide upon abutting property or fixtures. 
(3)  Applications on plant or landscape material within an area not exceeding 50 square feet by means which will prevent the drift or deposit of any detectible amount of pesticide on abutting property or fixtures. 
(4)  Applications within any single-family or two-family dwelling or within any dwelling unit in a multiple-family dwelling structure. 
(Code 1994, ch. 110, § 9.203) 
Sec. 14-124. - Penalty. 
    Any person who is found to have violated section 14-121 or section 14-122 of this Code shall be deemed responsible for a civil infraction as defined by MCL 600.113(1)(c) punishable by a civil fine not to exceed $25.00 for a first violation and not less than $25.00 or more than $100.00 for a second or subsequent violation. Such violation shall be processed pursuant to the provisions of MCL 600.8709 and MCL 600.8711. 
(Code 1994, ch. 110, § 9.204) 
Sec. 14-125. - Enforcement. 
    The director of code enforcement and neighborhood conservation and his/her appointed officers and inspectors are authorized to issue and serve citations with respect to violations of section 14-121 and section 14-122 in the manner provided by MCL 600.8707. 
(Code 1994, ch. 110, § 9.205)

ARTICLE II. - FIRE PREVENTION CODE 

Sec. 16-31. - Adoption of code by reference. 
    Pursuant to the provisions of section 3(k) of Public Act No. 279 of 1909 (MCL 117.3(k)), and for the purpose of prescribing regulations governing conditions hazardous to life and property from fire or explosion, the NFPA Fire Protection Code, being NFPA 1, 2000 edition, and the NFPA Life Safety Code, being NFPA 101, 2000 edition, as published by the National Fire Protection Association, Inc., and the referenced publications identified as mandatory requirements of NFPA 1 in chapter 32 and NFPA 101 in chapter 2 are hereby adopted by reference, as modified herein, and as so adopted shall be known as the "East Lansing Fire Prevention Code" and shall replace the existing "East Lansing Fire Prevention Code" previously adopted which is hereby repealed. Whenever the words "authority having jurisdiction" are used in the fire prevention code, it shall mean the fire chief and his or her designees. Whenever the words "governing authority" are used, it shall mean the City of East Lansing. 
(Code 1994, ch. 109, § 9.111; Ord. No. 978, 8-21-2001) 
Sec. 16-32. - Savings clause. 
    Nothing in this article or the code amended by this article shall affect any offense or act committed or done, or any penalty or forfeiture incurred or accruing before the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived. 
(Code 1994, ch. 109, § 9.112) 
Sec. 16-33. - Amendments to fire prevention code. 
    The following articles or sections of the fire prevention code are hereby added, amended, or deleted as hereinafter set forth. Subsequent article, divisions and section numbers used in this section shall refer to the like numbered articles, divisions, and sections of the fire prevention code, unless specified otherwise. 
NFPA 1 
CHAPTER 1. ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT 
Section 1-4, Authority. 
    Sections 1-4.1.1 and 1-4.1.2 are added to read: 
1-4.1.1.  The chief shall appoint, with approval of the city manager, a member of the fire department to exercise the powers and perform the duties of fire marshal and who shall be head of the bureau of fire prevention. 
1-4.1.2.  The chief of the fire department may detail to the fire prevention bureau such members of the fire department as inspectors or otherwise as shall from time to time be necessary. The chief of the fire department may recommend to the administrator the employment of technical inspectors, who, when such authorization is made, shall be selected through an examination to determine their fitness for the position. The examination shall be open to members and nonmembers of the fire department. 
    Section 1-8, Board of appeals, and section 1-8.6, Means of appeal, are amended by amending sections 1-8.1 through 1-8.6, deleting sections 1-8.6.1 and 1-8.6.2, and adding sections 1-8.7, 1-8.8, and 1-8.9 as follows: 
1-8.1.  In order to determine the suitability of alternate materials and type of construction and to provide for reasonable interpretations of the provisions of this code, appeals shall be taken before the East Lansing Building Board of Appeals as provided in chapter 6, article II of the Code of the City of East Lansing. The board shall adopt reasonable rules and regulations for conducting its investigations and shall render all decisions and findings in writing to the fire chief, with a duplicate copy to the applicant, and may recommend to the city council such new legislation as is consistent therewith. 
1-8.2. Application for reconsideration. 
a.  Any person aggrieved by a notice or order of the fire chief or fire marshal issued in connection with any alleged violation of this chapter or of applicable rules and regulations issued pursuant thereto, may apply to the fire chief for a reconsideration of such notice or order, if said application is made within five working days after the notice or order has been issued. 
b.  The fire chief shall set a time and place for an informal conference on the matter within five working days of the receipt of such application, and shall advise the applicants of such time and place in writing. 
c.  At the informal conference, the applicant shall be permitted to present his/her grounds for believing that the notice or order should be revoked or modified. 
d.  Within five days following the close of the informal conference, the fire chief shall give notice to the applicant whether or not he/she will modify or set aside the appealed notice or order. 
1-8.3. Fire board of appeals. The East Lansing Building Board of Appeals shall sit as the appeals board for any appeal relating to violations of the chapter. 
1-8.4. Right of appeal. Any person, aggrieved by a notice or order issued in connection with any alleged violation of the provisions of the chapter or of any applicable rules and regulations pursuant thereto, may file with the board of appeals a petition setting forth his/her reasons for contesting the notice or order. 
1-8.5. Petition for appeal; filing. Such petition shall be filed within ten days after the notice or order is served on petitioner, except where the petitioner has made timely application to the fire chief for reconsideration, in which case the petition shall be filed within ten days after notice by the fire chief of his/her decision upon the informal conference. The petition shall be filed accompanied by a fee, as established by resolution of the city council. Late appeals may be granted, in the discretion of the board of appeals, upon good cause shown. 
1-8.6. Time of hearing of appeal; notice. Within 45 days after receipt of a valid petition, the board of appeals shall conduct a hearing, and at least ten days prior thereto it shall serve the petitioner with notice thereof in the manner provided for service of notices in section 1-19 of the East Lansing Fire Prevention Code. The fire chief shall also be given such notice as will enable him/her or his/her designee to appear and be heard at the hearing. 
1-8.7. Scope of hearing on approval. At the hearing, the petitioner shall be given an opportunity to show cause why the notice or order should be modified or withdrawn, or why the period of time permitted for compliance should be extended. 
1-8.8. Action of board of appeals. 
a.  The board of appeals shall have the power to reverse wholly or partly, or modify, any order, requirement, decision, or determination of the fire chief and may grant an extension of time for the performance of any act required of not more than three additional months, where the board of appeals finds that there is practical difficulty or undue hardship connected with the performance of any act required by the provisions of this chapter or by applicable rules or regulations issued pursuant thereto, and that such extension is in harmony with the general purpose of this chapter to secure the public health, safety, and welfare. 
b.  The board of appeals shall return a decision upon each case within 60 days after a request of appeal has been filed, unless a further time is agreed upon with the parties concerned. Notwithstanding the foregoing sentence, the board may, in appropriate cases, be permitted an extension of time after hearing the case, in which to make its decision, provided such extension shall not exceed 30 days. Any decision of the board shall not become final until the expiration of five days from the date of entry of such order, unless the board shall find that immediate effect of such order is necessary for the preservation of life, property, or personal rights and shall so certify on the record of its proceeding. 
c.  The concurring vote of four members of the board of appeals shall be necessary to reverse wholly or partly, or modify any order, requirement, decision or determination of the fire chief to decide in favor of the appellant any matter upon which they are required to pass, or to effect any variance in the provisions of this chapter. 
1-8.9. Stay. An appeal shall stay all proceedings in furtherance of the action appealed from, unless the fire chief certifies to the board of appeals, after the notice of appeal shall have been filed with him, that by reason of facts stated in the certificate, an emergency exists, in which case the proceedings shall not be stayed except by a restraining order which may be granted upon due cause shown, by the board of appeals or by the circuit court, following timely notice of application therefor to the fire chief. 
    Section 1-16, Permits and approvals, is amended by adding sections 1-16.10.1 and 1-16.16(37) as follows: 
1-16.10.1. Fees. All fees assessed or required under this chapter shall be established by resolution of the city council. 
1-16.16(37) Commercial cooking equipment. Installation, modification, and operation of all commercial cooking equipment. 
    Section 1-19, Notice of violations, penalties, is amended by adding sections 1-19.5, 1-19.6, 1-19.7, 1-19.8 and 1-19.9 as follows: 
1-19.5. Violations; abatement. 
a.  Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this code or fail to comply therewith, or who shall violate or fail to comply with any order made thereunder and from which no appeal has been taken, or who shall fail to comply with such an order as affirmed or modified by the board of appeals or by a court of competent jurisdiction, within the time fixed therein, shall severally for each and every such violation and noncompliance respectively, be guilty of a misdemeanor punishable as provided for in chapter 1 of the Code of the City of East Lansing. The imposition of one penalty for any violation shall not excuse the violation or permit it to continue; and all such persons shall be required to correct or remedy such violations or defects within a reasonable time; and when not otherwise specified, each day that prohibited conditions are maintained shall constitute a separate offense. 
b.  The application of the above penalty shall not be held to prevent abatement, by the city, of prohibited conditions. 
1-19.6. Appearance tickets. The East Lansing Fire Chief and Fire Marshal, and their appointed officers and inspectors, shall be authorized to issue and serve appearance tickets with respect to any violations of this chapter, in accordance with and pursuant to the provisions of section 9C(2) of Public Act No. 147 of 1968 (MCL 764.9c(2)). 
1-19.7. Fee established. There is hereby established a service fee, the amount of which is to be set, from time to time by resolution of city council, to be charged to any person or persons who require or necessitate the use of any emergency medical care or emergency services provided by the City of East Lansing. Said charge shall be for emergency medical or transportation services which occur within or without the corporate limits of the City of East Lansing. 
1-19.8. Payment. The treasurer shall bill the person or persons for the charge as established by council. Payment shall be due within 60 days of the date of such statement. 
1-19.9. Penalty for late payment. Any charge for emergency care or transportation services which remains unpaid for more than 60 days shall be subject to a late payment penalty of four percent of the invoice. The city may enforce payment by a suit in assumpsit for any invoice more than 60 days overdue, or may take such further action as provided by law. 
CHAPTER 2. DEFINITIONS 
    Section 2-1.112a, Open outdoor fires is added to read as follows: 
2-1.112a, Open outdoor fires. An outdoor fire that is neither a cooking fire contained in a grill designed for that purpose, nor a fire that is in a contained outdoor fireplace as defined herein. 
    Section 2-1.112b, Contained outdoor fireplace, is added to read as follows: 
2-1.112b, Contained outdoor fireplace. A fireplace no larger than three feet wide, three feet deep and three feet high (exclusive of legs and chimneys) which is capable of fully enclosing the fire by means of screening or other non combustible materials with sufficiently small openings to contain embers.

Chapter 18 - FLOODS[1] 
Footnotes:
