(b)  No person shall sell, deliver, transfer, or convey possession or control of a firearm, loaded or unloaded, or ammunition to any person who is under the influence of intoxicating liquor or controlled substances or a combination of same. 
(c)  No person who is under the influence of intoxicating liquor or a controlled substance or any combination thereof shall carry, possess, control, discharge, or use in any manner a firearm, loaded or unloaded, or ammunition in a public place, or in any city park or recreational facility. 
(d)  Any person who violates subsection (c) of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by imprisonment for not more than 93 days or a fine of not more than $100.00, or both. 
(Code 1994, ch. 106, § 9.84; Ord. No. 1020, ch. 106, § 9.85, 11-19-2002; Ord. No. 1214, 2-10-2009; Ord. No. 1223, 6-16-2009) 
Sec. 26-197. - Voluntary delivery to police department. 
(a)  If a person voluntarily and peaceably delivers and abandons to the East Lansing Police Department a pistol or other firearm or weapon, such delivery shall preclude the arrest and prosecution of such person on a charge of violating any provision of this division with respect to the weapon voluntarily delivered. Delivery under this subsection may be made at the headquarters of the police department or by summoning a police officer to the person's residence or place of business. Every weapon to be delivered and abandoned to the police department under this subsection shall be unloaded and securely wrapped in a package and, in the case of delivery to the police headquarters, the package shall be carried in open view. No person who delivers and abandons a weapon under this subsection shall be required to furnish photographs or fingerprints. No amount of money shall be paid for any weapon delivered or abandoned under this subsection. 
(b)  Whenever any pistol or other firearm or weapon is surrendered under subsection (a) of this section, the police department shall inquire of all law enforcement agencies whether such pistol, firearm, or weapon is needed as evidence and, if the same is not needed as evidence, it shall be delivered to the state police for disposition. 
(Code 1994, ch. 106, § 9.85; Ord. No. 1020, ch. 106, § 9.86, 11-19-2002) 
Sec. 26-198. - Applicability of other laws. 
    Nothing in this division shall be construed as limiting or otherwise altering the requirements of any other applicable law respecting the purchasing, selling, carrying or possession of firearms. 
(Code 1994, ch. 106, § 9.86; Ord. No. 1020, ch. 106, § 9.87, 11-19-2002) 
Secs. 26-199-26-230. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - OFFENSES INVOLVING PROPERTY RIGHTS 

Sec. 26-231. - Destroying, damaging or interfering with property. 
    No person shall willfully destroy or damage or in any manner deface, destroy, or injure any property not his/her own, or any publicly owned building, bridge, fire hydrant, alarm box, streetlight, street sign, or shade tree, or mark or post handbills on or in any manner mar the walls of any public building, or any fence, tree, or pole within the city, or take or meddle with any property belonging to the city or remove the same from the building or place where it may be kept, placed, standing, or stored, without authority from the city manager or other official custodian of said property. 
(Code 1994, ch. 108, § 9.102; Ord. No. 1010, ch. 108, § 9.102(7), 4-16-2002) 
Sec. 26-232. - Entering vegetable garden or orchard. 
    No person shall enter any enclosed or unenclosed vegetable garden or orchard located within the city without the consent of the owner or tenant, or his/her agent, and there cut down, injure, damage, destroy, eat, or carry away any portion of said garden, including any growing thing, crop, tree, timber, grass, seed, soil, fertilizer, water supply, tool, implement, fence or any other protective device or any other thing used for the development, cultivation, maintenance, and use of the aforesaid gardens or orchards. 
(Code 1994, ch. 108, § 9.102; Ord. No. 1010, ch. 108, § 9.102(20), 4-16-2002) 
Sec. 26-233. - Trespass. 
    No person shall trespass upon the premises of another or unlawfully remain upon the premises of another without permission or authority of the lawful occupants or an agent of the lawful occupants. 
(Code 1994, ch. 108, § 9.102; Ord. No. 1010, ch. 108, § 9.102(33), 4-16-2002) 
Sec. 26-234. - Graffiti. 
(a)  No person shall use any paint, spray paint, paint stick, pigment or similar means to injure, deface or destroy public property or the private property of another, including the making of any drawing, inscription, design, sign, motto, picture, pictograph, or other marking commonly referred to as "graffiti." 
(b)  No parent or guardian of any minor under the age of 18 years shall by negligent supervision, or by failure to exercise reasonable parental control, suffer, permit or allow such minor to injure, deface or destroy public property or the private property of another by graffiti. An adjudication that said minor has violated subsection (a) of this section shall be prima facie evidence that said parent or guardian failed to exercise reasonable parental control. A violation of this subsection shall be a civil infraction as defined by MCL 600.113(1)(c) punishable by a civil fine of not more than $500.00 plus costs to be determined by the court or magistrate, which costs may include all expenses, direct and indirect, which the city has incurred in connection with the infraction. In addition to the penalties provided herein, any parent or guardian found responsible for a violation of this subsection shall be liable for liquidated damages in an amount equal to the cost to restore or repair the defaced property. 
(Code 1994, ch. 108, § 9.102; Ord. No. 1010, ch. 108, § 9.102(34), (35), 4-16-2002) 
Sec. 26-235. - Retail fraud. 
(a)  A person who does any of the following in a store or in its immediate vicinity is guilty of retail fraud: 
(1)  While a store is open to the public, alters, transfers, removes and replaces, conceals, or otherwise misrepresents the price at which property is offered for sale, with the intent not to pay for the property or to pay less than the price at which the property is offered for sale, if the resulting difference in price is less than $200.00. 
(2)  While a store is open to the public, steals property of the store that is offered for sale at a price of less than $200.00. 
(3)  With intent to defraud, obtains or attempts to obtain money or property from the store as a refund or exchange for property that was not paid for and belongs to the store, if the amount of money, or the value of the property, obtained or attempted to be obtained is less than $200.00. 
(b)  Evidence that the property or money taken or attempted to be taken has a value equal to or greater than $200.00 shall not be a defense to this offense. 
(c)  A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by jail for not more than 93 days or a fine of not more than $500.00 or both jail and a fine. 
(Ord. No. 1081, 10-5-2004) 
Sec. 26-236. - Larceny generally. 
(a)  A person who commits larceny by stealing any of the following property of another person is guilty of a crime as provided in this section if the property stolen has a value of less than $200.00: 
(1)  Money, goods, or chattels. 
(2)  A bank note, bank bill, bond, promissory note, due bill, bill of exchange or other bill, draft, order, or certificate. 
(3)  A book of accounts for or concerning money or goods due, to become due, or to be delivered. 
(4)  A deed or writing containing a conveyance of land or other valuable contract in force. 
(5)  A receipt, release, or defeasance. 
(6)  A writ, process, or public record. 
(b)  Evidence that the property or money taken or attempted to be taken has a value equal to or greater than $200.00 shall not be a defense to this offense. 
(c)  A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by jail for not more than 93 days or a fine of not more than $500.00 or both jail and a fine. 
(Ord. No. 1081, 10-5-2004) 
Sec. 26-237. - Larceny from motor vehicle. 
(a)  A person who enters or breaks into a motor vehicle, house trailer, trailer, or semitrailer to steal or unlawfully remove property is guilty of larceny from a motor vehicle if the value of the property stolen or to be stolen or removed is less than $200.00. 
(b)  Evidence that the property or money taken or attempted to be taken has a value equal to or greater than $200.00 shall not be a defense to this offense. 
(c)  A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by jail for not more than 93 days or a fine of not more than $500.00 or both jail and a fine. 
(Ord. No. 1081, 10-5-2004) 
Sec. 26-238. - False pretenses with intent to defraud. 
(a)  A person who, with intent to defraud or cheat and by color of a false token or writing, by a false or bogus check or other written, printed, or engraved instrument, by counterfeit coin or metal that is intended to simulate a coin, or by any other false pretense does one or more of the following is guilty of the crime of false pretenses, punishable as provided in this section if the property stolen has a value of less than $200.00: 
(1)  Causes a person to grant, convey, assign, demise, lease, or mortgage land or an interest in land. 
(2)  Obtains a person's signature on a forged written instrument. 
(3)  Obtains from a person any money or personal property or the use of any instrument, facility, article, or other valuable thing or service. 
(4)  By means of a false weight or measure obtains a larger amount or quantity of property than was bargained for. 
(5)  By means of a false weight or measure sells or disposes of a smaller amount or quantity of property than was bargained for. 
(b)  Evidence that the property or money taken or attempted to be taken has a value equal to or greater than $200.00 shall not be a defense to this offense. 
(c)  A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by jail for not more than 93 days or a fine of not more than $500.00 or both jail and a fine. 
(Ord. No. 1081, 10-5-2004) 
Sec. 26-239. - Unlawful entry by intoxicated persons. 
(a)  No person who is under the influence of alcoholic liquor or a controlled substance shall enter, or attempt to enter, any dwelling without permission from the owner, lessee, or a person lawfully in possession or control thereof. 
(b)  It shall not be a defense to a charge brought under this section that the defendant believed they had permission to enter the premises where the lack of actual permission was a direct or indirect result of the defendant being under the influence of alcohol or controlled substances. 
(c)  It shall not be a defense to a charge brought under this section that the defendant did not intend to commit an offense while inside the dwelling. 
(d)  Dwelling as used in this section means a structure or shelter that is used permanently or temporarily as a place of abode including an appurtenant structure attached to that structure or shelter. Dwelling does not include structures such as unenclosed porches or patios intended to be accessible from the exterior of the property. 
(Ord. No. 1160, 10-17-2006) 
Sec. 26-240. - Unlawful entry upon library property. 
    No person shall willfully enter upon the lands or premises of the East Lansing Public Library without lawful authority after having been forbidden to do so by the library director, or his/her designated agent. No person being upon said lands or premises shall refuse or neglect to forthwith depart therefrom upon being requested to do so by the library director or his/her designated agent. 
(Ord. No. 1399, 2-28-2017) 
Secs. 26-241-26-260. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - OFFENSES ON SCHOOLGROUNDS 

Sec. 26-261. - Destruction of school property. 
    No person shall damage, destroy, or deface any public, private, or parochial school building or any building occupied by any public, private, or parochial school or the grounds, outbuildings, fences, trees, or other appurtenances or fixtures belonging thereto. 
(Code 1994, ch. 112, § 9.401) 
Sec. 26-262. - Disturbing the peace. 
    No person shall willfully or maliciously make, or assist in making, any noise, disturbance, or improper diversion, by which the peace, quietude, or good order of any public, private, or parochial school is disturbed. 
(Code 1994, ch. 112, § 9.402) 
Sec. 26-263. - Unlawful entry. 
    No person shall willfully enter upon the lands or premises of any public, private, or parochial school in the city without lawful authority after having been forbidden to do so by the principal, or his/her designated agent, except as provided in section 26-264. No person being upon said lands or premises may refuse or neglect to forthwith depart therefrom upon being requested to do so by the principal or his/her designated agent. Where signs at each school building entrance direct persons to any office or any place to obtain permission to enter and remain in said building, no person shall enter into nor remain in said building without complying with the order of the principal or his/her designated agent to obey said sign. 
(Code 1994, ch. 112, § 9.403) 
Sec. 26-264. - Freedom of speech. 
    Where any person engaged in the exercise of constitutionally protected freedoms of speech, press, assembly, and petition in any public school or on the surrounding school grounds is found to create a disturbance which interferes with the orderly conduct of the business of the school or its management of its property, such person shall leave immediately when so directed by the principal or by any other person designated by the principal. 
(Code 1994, ch. 112, § 9.404) 
Sec. 26-265. - Exemptions. 
    The requirements of section 26-263 shall not apply to students who are regularly enrolled in and attending said school, and have not been expelled or suspended therefrom, teachers or other employees of said school. 
(Code 1994, ch. 112, § 9.405) 
Sec. 26-266. - Alcoholic beverages. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to willfully violate any regulation regarding the use or possession of alcoholic beverages on school property which is lawfully adopted by the East Lansing Board of Education and posted upon the property regulated. Any violation of such regulation shall be punished as provided in section 1-12 of this Code. 
(Code 1994, ch. 112, § 9.406) 
Secs. 26-267-26-290. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - NUISANCES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 26-291. - Dangerous containers. 
    No person shall place, store, or otherwise maintain, either inside or outside of any building, dwelling, or structure, in a place accessible to children of a minor age, any discarded, unattended, or abandoned and airtight refrigerator, freezer, stove, clothes dryer, or washer, or any other similar appliance or container, such as a trunk, of any kind which has a snap latch or other locking device thereon without first removing the snap latch or other locking device or the doors. No person shall place, store, or otherwise maintain any major appliance or airtight container anywhere on the premises for storage, public or private rubbish, or trash collection, without first removing doors thereon to ensure that such container cannot be locked. Any container placed for public collection must be placed in accordance with the provisions of chapter 36, article III of the East Lansing City Code, pertaining to solid waste collection and disposal. 
(Code 1994, ch. 106, § 9.25) 
Sec. 26-292. - Permit for conducting tag day or selling tags, emblems or flags. 
    No person shall conduct a tag day or offer for sale or receive anything of value for any tag, emblem, or flag, on the streets or any other public place in the city, without first having obtained a permit for the same from the council. 
(Code 1994, ch. 106, § 9.30) 
Secs. 26-293-26-320. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - HANDBILLS AND BILLPOSTING 

Sec. 26-321. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1354, adopted Sept. 1, 2015, repealed former § 26-321, which pertained to distributing handbills, samples or dodgers, and derived from the 1994 Code, ch. 106, § 9.35. 
Sec. 26-322. - Billposting. 
(a)  No person shall attach, place, paint, write, stamp, or paste any sign, advertisement, or any other matter upon any lamppost, electric light railway, telegraph or telephone pole, shade tree, or fire hydrant, or box covering same; or any bridge, pavement, sidewalk or crosswalk, public building, or any article or thing within any park, provided that, this subsection shall not be construed to prevent any public officer from so doing for any purpose authorized by this Code or by the laws of the State of Michigan, and provided further, that this subsection shall not prohibit any person from placing, posting, or otherwise publishing any written or printed material relating to the election of a person to public office, a political party, a matter to be voted upon at a regular or special election, or to any other constitutionally protected noncommercial speech. 
(b)  No person shall attach, place, paint, write, stamp, or paste any sign, advertisement, or any other matter upon any house, wall, fence, gate, post, tree or tree box, without having first obtained the written permission of the owner, agent, or occupants of the premises. 
(c)  If a violation of subsections (a) and (b) of this section has been committed and the individual person committing the violation cannot be identified, the person, firm, or organization designated in the handbill, sign, or advertisement as being the sponsor of or primary benefactor of the event shall be deemed responsible for the violation. A violation charged under this subsection shall be deemed a municipal civil infraction as defined by section 113(1) of the Revised Judicature Act of 1961 (the "Act") punishable by a civil fine of not more than $500.00. Service of a citation charging a municipal civil infraction under this subsection may be made in the manner authorized by section 1-11 of this Code upon the corporate resident agent designated for service of process, the named applicant for any trade or business license or permit issued by the city clerk, or in the case where no agent or applicant is identified, upon any partner or officer of the organization or entity sponsoring or selling the event, activity, or goods or services advertised. Cases commenced under this subsection shall, to the extent applicable, be processed under the provisions of section 8709 and section 8711 of the Act. 
(Code 1994, ch. 106, § 9.36) 
Secs. 26-323-26-340. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - NOXIOUS WEEDS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Vegetation, ch. 48. 

Sec. 26-341. - Removal required. 
    No person who is the owner, possessor, or occupier of lands within the city shall fail to cut down or pull out all ragweed (Ambrosia elatior I.), Canada thistle (Circum arvense), dodders (any species of Cuscuta), mustards (charlock, black mustard, and Indian mustard, species of Brassica or Sinapis), wild carrot (Caucus carota), poison ivy (Rhus toxicodendron), poison sumac (Rhus vernix), or other noxious weeds, as defined by the State of Michigan or United States departments of agriculture, growing thereon or on the streets, alleys, or public areas between curbs and public sidewalks, as often in each year as shall be sufficient to prevent them from going to seed, and to prevent ragweed from going to blossom. 
(Code 1994, ch. 106, § 9.41) 
Sec. 26-342. - Declaration of nuisance. 
    Any lawn, tree, shrub, or plant, including weeds, which is not maintained according to the requirements of section 302.4 of the amendments to the International Property Maintenance Code set forth in section 6-175, or which endangers public property, interferes with the public right-of-way, the health or safety of the public, or which is detrimental to the general public welfare, is hereby declared to be a public nuisance. No person who is the owner, possessor, or occupier of lands shall commit, create, maintain, or allow directly or through negligent control a public nuisance as defined herein. A person who violates this section is responsible for a municipal civil infraction. 
(Code 1994, ch. 106, § 9.42) 
Sec. 26-343. - Notice. 
    The city manager shall give written notice to the owner or occupier of the premises upon which such nuisance is located, or which adjoins that portion of a street or alley where such nuisance is located, to remove, trim, or dispose of the same within five days after service of said written notice. Said notice shall be given in accordance with the provisions of section 1-11(a)(1) and (2) of the City Code or by posting the notice in some conspicuous place on the land or by attaching the notice to the entrance of the building or structure. 
(Code 1994, ch. 106, § 9.43) 
Sec. 26-344. - Abatement by city. 
    If, at the expiration of the time limit in said notice, the owner has not complied with the requirements thereof, the city manager shall take such steps as, in his or her judgment, may be necessary to abate such nuisance. The cost of such abatement and administrative expenses not to exceed 15 percent of all other costs shall be charged against the premises, and the owner thereof, in accordance with the provisions of chapter 13 of the Charter of the City of East Lansing. 
(Code 1994, ch. 106, § 9.44) 
Sec. 26-345. - Emergency abatement. 
    The city manager may abate any such public nuisance without giving notice if the public health or safety require immediate attention. The cost of abating such nuisance and administrative expenses not to exceed 15 percent of all other costs may be charged against the premises, in accordance with the provisions of section 13.18 of the Charter of the City of East Lansing. 
(Code 1994, ch. 106, § 9.45) 
Sec. 26-346. - Entry on premises. 
    The city manager and his authorized representatives are hereby empowered to enter upon any premises in the city for the purpose of destroying noxious weeds or trimming or removing uncontrolled plant growth under the provisions of this Code, and no person shall deny entry to or otherwise obstruct, molest, or interfere with the said city manager or his or her designee, while they are engaged in destroying weeds, as provided herein. Any person convicted of a violation of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and punished as provided by section 1-12 of the City Code. 
(Code 1994, ch. 106, § 9.46) 
Secs. 26-347-26-370. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - FALSE ALARMS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, ch. 16. 

Sec. 26-371. - Declaration of nuisance. 
    Any false alarm in excess of one in any calendar year is hereby declared to be a public nuisance. 
(Code 1994, ch. 106, § 9.50) 
Sec. 26-372. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Alarm system means any device or assembly of equipment and devices arranged to signal the presence of a condition requiring urgent attention and to which police officers or fire department personnel are expected to respond. In this division, the term "alarm system" shall include the terms "automatic hold-up alarm system," "burglar alarm system," "intrusion alarm system," "hold-up alarm system," "manual hold-up alarm system," "temperature fire alarm system," "manual fire alarm system," "fire alarm system," and "automatic sprinkler water-flow alarm system." 
    Alarm user means any person on whose premises an alarm system is maintained within the city except for alarm systems on motor vehicles. If, however, an alarm system on a motor vehicle is connected with an alarm system at a premises, the person using such system is an alarm user. Also excluded from this definition and from the coverage of this division are persons who use alarm systems to alert or signal persons within the premises in which the alarm system is located, of an attempted unauthorized intrusion, hold-up attempt, or fire hazard. If such a system, however, employs an audible signal emitting sounds or a flashing light or beacon designed to signal persons outside the premises, such system shall be within the definition of an alarm system and shall be subject to this division. 
    Direct dial alarm system means any device or assembly of equipment and devices arranged to signal the presence of a condition requiring urgent attention to which police officers or fire department personnel are expected to respond and which registers an alarm signal directly at the police or fire department. 
    False alarm means any alarm signal which is registered at the police department or elsewhere not resulting from criminal activity for which the alarm was intended, or in the case of a fire alarm any alarm signal which is registered at the police department or elsewhere not resulting from a fire or potential fire condition or life-threatening medical emergency. 
(Code 1994, ch. 106, § 9.51) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-7. 
Sec. 26-373. - False alarm fee established. 
(a)  The alarm user shall be required to pay to the city the sum of $10.00 for a second false alarm, and $25.00 for each additional false alarm in any given calendar year. No alarm user shall be required to pay said fee on the first occasion of a false alarm during any one calendar year, but shall be advised in writing of said false alarm and of the existence of this division. 
(b)  Alarms caused by the following extenuating circumstances shall not constitute a false alarm and no false alarm fee shall be charged by the city: 
(1)  Alarm system malfunctions if corrective measures have been instituted within a 72-hour period with notification to the police department, provided that the alarm user presents documentation of repair service having been performed by the alarm company to remedy a malfunction. 
(2)  Storm conditions. 
(3)  Alarms activated by persons working on the alarm system with prior notification to the police department. 
(4)  Alarms activated by disruption or disturbance of Michigan Bell Telephone Company facilities, or motor vehicle-utility pole accidents. 
In subsections (b)(1), (2), and (4) of this section, it shall be the responsibility of the alarm user to notify the police department by filling out the alarm card and returning it to the police department within five working days. Failure to notify the police department will result in an automatic billing to the user. 
(c)  At the direction of the police chief, an "alarm notification card" shall be designed and used as required by this division. 
(d)  On the first business day following the response of police officers to an alarm call, a representative of the police chief shall mail an alarm notification card to the alarm user. 
(e)  Within five working days of the date of receipt of the alarm notification card, the alarm user shall return the completed card to the East Lansing Police Department. Failure by the alarm user to return the card shall cause an automatic billing of the false alarm fee to be sent to the alarm user. 
(f)  If, upon receiving a false alarm fee notice, the alarm user wishes to request a waiver of the assessment of the fee due to extenuating circumstances, he/she may do so in writing within ten working days of the assessment date. The notice to the police department shall contain documentation of the extenuating circumstances involved. Within ten working days of the receipt of the waiver request by the police department, the police chief shall make a determination on the waiver request and shall notify the alarm user of the decision. 
(g)  In the event that the alarm user is not satisfied with the decision rendered by the police chief, an additional written request for waiver may be filed within ten working days with the city manager. Within ten working days of the receipt of the waiver request and documentation of extenuating circumstances, the city manager or his designated representative shall review the request, make a determination on the waiver, and shall notify the alarm user of the decision. 
(Code 1994, ch. 106, § 9.52) 
Sec. 26-374. - Authority to disconnect direct dial alarm systems. 
(a)  On the fifth occasion of a false alarm in any given calendar year resulting from a direct dial alarm system, the police chief may order the disconnection of the system after written notice to the alarm user. 
(b)  Written notice of disconnection shall contain documentation of the five false alarms within the calendar year and shall be mailed certified mail to the alarm user within five working days following the response of police officers to the fifth false alarm. 
(c)  Upon proof of receipt of written notice by the alarm user, the police chief may order the system disconnected by an alarm system contractor. 
(d)  The alarm user may appeal the police chief's decision to disconnect the direct dial alarm system to the city manager in writing within ten working days after the system is disconnected. The written appeal shall contain documentation of the extenuating circumstances which require the use of a direct dial alarm system. 
(e)  The city manager or his designated representative shall review the appeal, make a determination on the appeal, and shall notify the alarm user of the decision within ten working days. If the decision is to reconnect the system, the city manager, or his designated representative, shall within five days after the decision, direct an alarm system contractor to reconnect the system. 
(f)  Nothing contained in this section shall prevent the user of a direct dial alarm system from employing a different kind of alarm system after disconnection of the direct dial system. 
(Code 1994, ch. 106, § 9.53) 
Sec. 26-375. - Late charge and interest on unpaid false alarm fees; collection. 
    Any billing to an alarm user for a false alarm fee which remains unpaid for a period in excess of 20 days shall be assessed a late charge of ten percent and shall bear interest at the rate of six percent until paid, and shall be certified to the city assessor who shall place the same on the next tax roll and assess the fees, penalties, and interest against the real or personal property assessment of the user to be collected in the same manner as general city taxes pursuant to chapter 13 of the East Lansing City Charter. 
(Code 1994, ch. 106, § 9.54) 
Secs. 26-376-26-400. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - SMOKING AND DISTRIBUTION OF TOBACCO PRODUCTS 
Subdivision I. - In General 

Sec. 26-401. - Prohibited smoking declared nuisance; smoking prohibited in city facilities. 
(a)  No person shall smoke in a public place or in an office work place, except as permitted in this division. In addition to the penalties set forth in section 26-411, a violation of this prohibition is hereby declared to be a public nuisance. 
(b)  No person shall smoke in any city owned, managed, operated, and/or leased facility. 
(c)  No person shall smoke in any park, plaza, playground, tennis court, community center, outdoor athletic complex, aquatic center, linear park or trail owned or controlled by the city or in city parking lots when used for community events. 
(Code 1994, ch. 106, § 9.60; Ord. No. 1292, 2-5-2013; Ord. No. 1394, 12-13-2016) 
Sec. 26-402. - Definitions. 
    The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of this subdivision: 
    Authorized city official means a police officer, a code compliance officer, the city manager or his or her designee, or the fire chief or his or her designee. 
    Cigar means any roll of tobacco for smoking, irrespective of size or shape and irrespective of the tobacco being flavored, adulterated or mixed with any other ingredients, where such roll has a wrapper made chiefly of tobacco. 
    Cigar bar means an establishment or area within an establishment that is open to the public and is designated for the smoking of cigars, purchased on the premises or elsewhere. 
    Cigarette means any roll of tobacco for smoking, irrespective of size or shape and irrespective of the tobacco being flavored, adulterated or mixed with any other ingredients, where such roll has a wrapper made chiefly of paper or other material except tobacco. 
    City owned, managed, operated, and/or leased facility includes city hall, the city jail, the 54-B District Court and any other building owned, managed, operated and/or leased by the city, and all areas within, including, but not limited to, private lounges, libraries, mail rooms, elevators, supply/equipment storage areas, inside loading dock areas, park pavilions and shelters, reception areas, restrooms, hallways, stairways, garages, and all lobbies and enclosed entrances, all areas within 50 feet of all entrances, and any building managed and/or operated by authorities created pursuant to law, excluding, however, streets and sidewalks and open areas within city-owned parking ramps other than booths and offices within the ramp facilities. 
    Employee means any natural person who is employed by an employer in consideration for any direct or indirect monetary wages or other consideration. 
    Employer means any person who employs the services of another individual person. 
    Enclosed means closed in by a roof and four walls with appropriate openings for ingress and egress. 
    Exit means a continuous and unobstructed means of egress to a public way and shall include intervening aisles, doors, doorways, corridors, ramps, stairways, smokeproof enclosures, horizontal exits, and exit passageways. 
    Health facility means a health facility or agency licensed under article 17 of the Michigan Public Health Code, except a home for the aged, nursing home, county medical care facility, hospice, or hospital longterm care unit. 
    Office work place means any enclosed area of a structure or portion thereof intended for occupancy in a "place of employment" by two or more employees of any employer who will provide primarily clerical, professional, educational, or business services. 
    Place of employment means any enclosed area under the control of a public or private employer, including charitable, educational, or nonprofit organizations, school districts, and facilities maintained or operated by public agencies of the city or county, which employees normally frequent during the course of employment. 
    Public place means any of the following: 
(a)  An enclosed, indoor area owned or operated by a state or local governmental agency and used by the general public or serving as a meeting place for a public body, including an office, educational facility, home for the aged, nursing home, county medical care facility, hospice, hospital long-term care unit, auditorium, arena, meeting room, or public conveyance. 
(b)  An enclosed, indoor area that is not owned or operated by a state or local governmental agency, is used by the general public, and is any of the following: 
(1)  An educational facility. 
(2)  A home for the aged, nursing home, county medical care facility, hospice, or hospital long-term care unit. 
(3)  An auditorium. 
(4)  An arena. 
(5)  A theater. 
(6)  A museum. 
(7)  A concert hall. 
(8)  Any other facility during the period of its use for a performance or exhibit of the arts. 
(c)  Unless otherwise exempt under this Code, a place of employment. 
    A private residence is not a "public place" except when used as a licensed child care, foster care, or health care facility. 
    Smoke or smoking means the lighting, inhaling, exhaling, or burning, or carrying of any lighted cigar, cigarette, tobacco, weed, plant, or other similar article or combustible substance in any form. 
    Tobacco specialty retail store means an establishment in which the primary purpose is the retail sale of tobacco products and smoking paraphernalia, and in which the sale of other products is incidental. Tobacco specialty retail store does not include a tobacco department or section of a larger commercial establishment or any establishment with any type of liquor, food, or restaurant license. 
(Code 1994, ch. 106, § 9.61; Ord. No. 1292, 2-5-2013) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-7. 
Secs. 26-403, 26-404. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1292, adopted Feb. 5, 2013, repealed former §§ 26-403 and 26-404, which pertained to designation of smoking areas in public places and regulation of smoking in office work places, health facilities, child caring institutions and private practice offices; and derived from the 1994 Code, ch. 106, §§ 9.62, 9.63. 
Sec. 26-405. - Exceptions for existing tobacco specialty retail stores and cigar bars. 
    A tobacco specialty retail store or cigar bar in existence, doing business within the city limits, on the effective date of Ordinance 1292, that meets all of the requirements of MCL 333.12606a is exempt from the smoking prohibition of section 26-401 and may allow smoking on its premises. To qualify for this exemption, the tobacco specialty retail store or cigar bar must be located on premises that are physically separated from any areas of the same or adjacent establishments in which smoking is prohibited and where smoke does not infiltrate into those nonsmoking areas. As used in this subdivision, "physically separated" means an area that is enclosed on all sides by any combination of solid walls, windows, or doors that extend from the floor to ceiling. The tobacco specialty retail store or cigar bar must prohibit entry to a person under the age of 18 during the time the tobacco specialty retail store is open for business. A tobacco specialty retail store or cigar bar that does not meet the requirements of this section or violates this section is not exempt from the smoking prohibition of section 26-401 and shall immediately prohibit smoking on its premises. No new branches of an existing tobacco specialty retail store or cigar bar may open within the city and no tobacco specialty retail store or cigar bar in existence outside the city limits on the effective date of this section qualifies for this exemption. A tobacco specialty retail store or cigar bar in existence, doing business within the city limits, on the effective date of this section, that meets all of the requirements of MCL 333.12606a may, however, relocate from location within the city to another location within the city if the new location complies with this section. 
(Code 1994, ch. 106, § 9.64; Ord. No. 1292, 2-5-2013) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1292, adopted Feb. 5, 2013, changed the title of § 26-405 from "Exceptions for office work places, child caring institutions and health facilities" to "Exceptions for existing tobacco specialty retail stores and cigar bars." 
Sec. 26-406. - Posting of signs and other requirements. 
(a)  The owner, operator, manager, or person having control of a public place, a food service establishment, shall do all of the following: 
(1)  Clearly and conspicuously post "no smoking" signs or the international "no smoking" symbol at the entrances to and in every building or other area where smoking is prohibited under this act. 
(2)  Remove all ashtrays and other smoking paraphernalia from anywhere smoking is prohibited under this act. 
(3)  Inform individuals smoking in violation of this act that they are in violation of state law and subject to penalties. 
(4)  If applicable, refuse to serve an individual smoking in violation of this act. 
(5)  Ask an individual smoking in violation of this act to refrain from smoking and, if the individual continues to smoke in violation of this act, ask him or her to leave the public place, food service establishment, or nonsmoking area. 
(b)  The owner, operator, manager, or person in control of a hotel, motel, or other lodging facility shall comply with subsection (a) of this section and section 26-409. It is an affirmative defense to a prosecution or civil or administrative action for a violation of this section that the owner, operator, manager, or person in control of a hotel, motel, or other lodging facility where smoking is prohibited under this section made a good faith effort to prohibit smoking by complying with subsection (a). To assert the affirmative defense under this subsection, the owner, operator, manager, or person shall file a sworn affidavit setting forth his or her efforts to prohibit smoking and his or her actions of compliance with subsection (a). 
(Code 1994, ch. 106, § 9.65; Ord. No. 1292, 2-5-2013) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1292, adopted Feb. 5, 2013, changed the title of § 26-406 from "Posting of signs" to "Posting of signs and other requirements." 
Sec. 26-407. - Governmental agency cooperation. 
    The city manager shall request such governmental and educational agencies located within the City of East Lansing to establish local operating procedures to cooperate and comply with this division. In federal, state, and county offices within the City of East Lansing, the city manager shall urge enforcement of any existing no-smoking prohibitions and request cooperation with this division. 
(Code 1994, ch. 106, § 9.66) 
Sec. 26-408. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1292, adopted Feb. 5, 2013, repealed § 26-408, which pertained to general exemptions; granting of exceptions and modifications, and derived from the 1994 Code, ch. 106, § 9.67. 
Sec. 26-409. - Nondiscrimination. 
    No person or employer shall discharge, or in any manner discriminate against any employee because such employee exercises any rights afforded by this division. In addition to any other remedy or penalty provided by this division, any person who is aggrieved by any employer with respect to other terms or conditions of employment in the exercise of rights guaranteed hereunder may file a complaint with the East Lansing Human Relations Commission and such complaint shall be adjudicated, adjusted, or remedied in the same manner as a violation of a civil right which is declared or protected by this division. 
(Code 1994, ch. 106, § 9.68) 
Sec. 26-410. - Enforcement. 
(a)  The city manager shall be responsible for compliance with this division in facilities which are owned, operated, or leased by the City of East Lansing. 
(b)  The owner, operator, or manager of any public place or office work place shall post, or cause to be posted, all "no smoking" signs required by this division. Owners, operators, managers, or employees of the same shall be required to inform persons violating this division of the provisions thereof when such owner, operator, manager, or employee receives a request from a client, customer, or employee to inform persons who are in violation of this division. 
(c)  It shall be the responsibility of employers to disseminate information concerning the provisions of this division to all employees. 
(Code 1994, ch. 106, § 9.69) 
Sec. 26-411. - Penalty; citations. 
(a)  Any person who violates this division or who violates any provision of this division by smoking in a posted "no smoking" area or by failing to post, or cause to be posted, a "no smoking" sign or by failing to promulgate a written policy regarding smoking and non-smoking, or who fails to inform their customers or patrons of violations as required by this division shall be deemed responsible for a municipal civil infraction as defined by MCL 600.113(1)(c), and upon being found responsible therefor shall be subject to a civil fine of not more than $100.00 for a first offense and not more than $500.00 for each subsequent offense. 
(b)  The provisions of this division shall be enforced by an authorized city official. A municipal civil infraction under this section shall be commenced by the issuance by an authorized city official of a municipal civil infraction citation in the form and manner provided by MCL 600.8707 and 600.8709 directing the alleged violator to appear in court. 
(Code 1994, ch. 106, § 9.70) 
Sec. 26-412. - Public education. 
    The city manager, through the office of public affairs, shall engage in a continuing program to inform and clarify the purposes of this division to citizens affected by it, and to guide owners, operators, employers, and managers in their compliance. 
(Code 1994, ch. 106, § 9.71) 
Sec. 26-413. - Conflicts with collective bargaining agreements. 
    This division shall not require the adoption or enforcement of any smoking policy in a work place which is in conflict with any existing collective bargaining agreement during the remaining term of such agreement. 
(Code 1994, ch. 106, § 9.72) 
Secs. 26-414-26-429. - Reserved. 
Subdivision II. - Distribution of Tobacco Products 

Sec. 26-430. - Findings. 
(a)  The East Lansing City Council finds and declares that: 
(1)  The U.S. Surgeon General has identified cigarette smoking as the single most important preventable cause of premature morbidity and mortality. 
(2)  The Director of the National Institute on Drug Abuse has concluded that the majority of the 390,000 Americans who die each year from cigarette smoking became addicted to nicotine as adolescents before the age of legal consent. 
(3)  The selling, giving, or furnishing of tobacco products to a person under 18 years of age is prohibited in Michigan by Public Act No. 314 of 1988 (MCL 722.641 et seq.). 
(4)  Studies have shown that a significant number of children under the legal age to purchase tobacco products are still able to do so either directly or through vending machines. 
(b)  This division is hereby adopted to safeguard the public health by requiring a license to engage in the retail sale of tobacco by prohibiting the sale of tobacco products to minors and by regulating the use of tobacco vending machines. 
(Code 1994, ch. 106, § 9.73) 
Sec. 26-431. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this subdivision, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Person means an individual, partnership, cooperative, association, private corporation, personal representative, receiver, trustee, assignee, or any other legal entity. 
    Tobacco means any product made from the tobacco plant for the purpose of smoking, chewing, inhaling and other personal use including cigars, chewing tobacco, pipe tobacco, snuff, and cigarettes in any form. 
    Tobacco retailer means any person or governmental entity that operates a store, stand, booth, concession, or other place at which sales of tobacco are made to purchasers for consumption or use. In the case of vending machines, tobacco retailer shall mean the owner/operator of the location at which the vending machine is placed. 
    Vending machine means any automated self-service device which, upon insertion of money, tokens, or any other form of payment, dispenses cigarettes or other tobacco product. 
(Code 1994, ch. 106, § 9.75) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-7. 
Sec. 26-432. - Prohibited sales; signs required. 
(a)  No person shall sell, furnish, give, or deliver any cigarette, cigar, chewing tobacco, tobacco snuff, or tobacco in any other form to a person under 18 years of age. 
(b)  Signs informing the public of the age restrictions provided for herein shall be posted by every retailer at or near every display of tobacco products, at the point of sale and on or upon every vending machine which offers tobacco products for sale. Each such sign shall be plainly visible and shall state: "THE SALE OF TOBACCO PRODUCTS TO PERSONS UNDER EIGHTEEN (18) YEARS OF AGE IS PROHIBITED BY LAW." 
(Code 1994, ch. 106, § 9.76) 
Sec. 26-433. - Vending machine remote device. 
(a)  Except as provided in subsections (b) and (c) of this section, no person shall sell cigarettes or tobacco products through a vending machine in any premises unless said vending machine: 
(1)  Can only be operated by a functioning remote control device which is inaccessible to the purchaser and must be operated for each sale by the tobacco retailer or his/her adult employee. 
(2)  Must not be capable of being locked into an "on" position. 
(b)  A vending machine may be operated in a licensed liquor establishment if located fully within the premises, not less than 20 feet from all exits, and under the direct visual supervision of an adult employee. Provided further that should the establishment be open to persons under age 18, the machine shall be located within ten feet of the service bar. 
(c)  Vending machines may be operated in commercial buildings or industrial plants or portions thereof where the public is expressly prohibited and where such machines are strictly for the use of the employees therein; provided that the area must be signed as not open to the public and no minor employees are usually admitted. 
(Code 1994, ch. 106, § 9.77) 
Sec. 26-434. - Placement of tobacco products for sale. 
    No person shall display tobacco products for sale in a location or manner which allows delivery to the public without the assistance of an adult sales clerk. This section shall not apply to stores that deal exclusively in tobacco products and accessories, or to displays of tobacco products which are packaged for sale in cartons or packages containing five or more individual packaging units, smoking tobacco in packages of six ounces (170 grams) or more, cigars in packages of 50 or more, or to vending machines. 
(Code 1994, ch. 106, § 9.77A) 
Sec. 26-435. - Certain free distributions prohibited. 
    No person shall deliver cigarettes or tobacco products to any other person at no cost or at a nominal cost for product promotional purposes. This section shall not apply to delivery of a tobacco product as a gift to another person known to him/her or delivery and exchange for a manufacturer supplied coupon. 
(Code 1994, ch. 106, § 9.78) 
Sec. 26-436. - Licensing of retailers. 
(a)  License required; exception. No person shall sell or deliver tobacco or tobacco products at retail unless that person possesses a valid tobacco retailer's license from the city clerk for each location where tobacco sales are conducted. The license shall be issued for a three-year term. This subsection shall not apply to distribution by an individual to family members or acquaintances on private property that is not open to the public. 
(b)  License application and issuance. Application for a tobacco retailer's license shall be submitted in the name of the person proposing to conduct retail sales of tobacco and shall be signed by such person or his/her agent. All applications shall be submitted on a form supplied by the city clerk and accompanied by the required license fee. The application form shall contain at least the following information: 
(1)  The name, home address, home telephone number, date, place of birth, and social security number of the applicant if the applicant is an individual. 
(2)  The names, addresses, telephone numbers, and social security numbers of any partners or corporate officers. 
(3)  The business name, address, and telephone number of the establishment where tobacco is retailed. 
(c)  Nontransferability. A tobacco retailer's license is nontransferable, except if a tobacco retailer changes location, a new tobacco retailer's license will be issued for the new address upon receipt of an application for change of location. The license will retain the same expiration date as that previously issued. 
(d)  License display. A current tobacco retailer's license shall be displayed in a conspicuous place in each location where tobacco sales are conducted. In the case of tobacco vending machines, a current tobacco retailer's license shall be conspicuously displayed on each vending machine. 
(e)  License suspension or revocation. A tobacco retailer's license shall be suspended or revoked by the city manager for cause as provided by section 8-67 and section 8-68 of this Code if the licensee fails to comply with the provisions of this division. These sanctions are in addition to the monetary penalties provided for in section 26-411. A license shall be suspended or revoked as follows: 
(1)  In the case of a first and single violation of this division, the licensee shall be given notification, in writing, of provisions for license suspension or revocation in the event of additional or further violations. 
(2)  In the case of two violations within a single three-year licensing term, the license shall be suspended for 30 days. 
(3)  In the case of three violations within a single three-year licensing term, the license shall be suspended for 90 days. 
(4)  In the case of four violations within a single three-year licensing term, the license shall be revoked for one year. 
(5)  The city manager may, in appropriate cases, giving due consideration to financial hardship, the nature of the violations and other peculiar circumstances of time and place, reduce the sanction to the next highest level or limit the sanction to particular tobacco products or classes of tobacco products or both. 
(6)  Decisions of the city manager may be appealed to the East Lansing Human Relations Commission in the manner provided by section 26-408(c). Such appeal shall be filed within ten days after the order is served on the licensee. An appeal shall stay all proceedings until a final decision by the commission. 
(f)  Injunctive proceedings. Notwithstanding the existence and pursuit of any other remedy, the city manager or his/her designee, without posting bond, may maintain an action in a court of competent jurisdiction for an injunction or other process against any person to restrain or prevent a violation of this division. 
(Code 1994, ch. 106, § 9.79) 
Chapter 28 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Environment, ch. 14; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 38; vegetation, ch. 48. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 28-1. - Definitions. 
(a)  For purposes of this chapter, "park," "public park" or "city park" shall mean any park, playground, tennis court, community center, outdoor athletic complex, aquatic center, linear park or trail owned or controlled by the City of East Lansing. 
(b)  For purposes of this chapter "parks and recreation director" means that person designated by the city manager as the director of the department of parks and recreation. 
(Ord. No. 1141, 12-5-2006) 
Sec. 28-2. - Applicability. 
    Unless otherwise provided, this chapter applies to all parks, recreation areas, recreation facilities and open space belonging to the City of East Lansing or within the possession and control of the city, whether located within or without the corporate boundaries of the city. 
(Ord. No. 1141, 12-5-2006) 
Sec. 28-3. - Park hours. 
    All parks are closed to the public between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. The city manager may establish different closing hours than herein specified provided that adequate notice of such closing is posted. It shall be unlawful for any person, except those persons authorized by the city manager to enter upon, cross through or remain within any park outside of the established hours. 
(Ord. No. 1141, 12-5-2006) 
Sec. 28-4. - Department of public works. 
    Nothing contained in this chapter shall make it a violation for department of public works (DPW) or other city employees or law enforcement officers to enter within and perform work in parks at the times and in the manner required in the course of their official duties. 
(Ord. No. 1141, 12-5-2006) 
Secs. 28-5-28-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - USE OF PARKS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1141, adopted Dec. 5, 2006, amended article II in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former article II, §§ 28-31-28-43, pertained to similar subject matter, and was derived from Code 1994, ch. 35, §§ 3.1-3.12. 

Sec. 28-31. - Damaging property; obstructing walks or drives; misdemeanor violation. 
(a)  No person shall obstruct any walk or drive in any public park or playground. 
(b)  No person shall injure, mar, remove, deface, or damage in any manner, any building or structure monument, plaque, ornament, fence, bridge, seat, picnic table, tree, fountain, shrub, flower, playground equipment, grills or other public property upon any park. 
(c)  No person shall destroy or damage the surface or sod on any playing field, tennis court or practice area. No person shall remove dirt, sand, sod, or shredded bark from any park. 
(d)  Any person who commits a violation of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished as provided in section 1-12 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 1141, 12-5-2006) 
Sec. 28-32. - Dogs and animals. 
    Except as permitted by rules or regulations adopted pursuant to section 28-40 of this chapter: 
(1)  No dogs are permitted in any park unless on a leash that does not exceed eight feet in length held by a responsible person. Dogs in violation of this section may be impounded and the owner shall be in violation of this Code; 
(2)  No person except law enforcement officers acting in the course of their official duties shall ride or lead horses in any park. No dangerous or vicious animals shall be permitted in any park; and 
(3)  Limited duty parking and property maintenance officers appointed by the city manager and assigned to enforcement of the provisions of this section under the supervision of the chief of police shall be authorized to issue and serve appearance tickets with respect to violations of this section and section 28-33 of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1141, 12-5-2006) 
Cross reference- Animals generally, ch. 4. 
Sec. 28-33. - Waste to be deposited in containers; household waste; animal feces; yard waste. 
    No person shall place or deposit any garbage, glass, glass bottles, cans, plastic, paper, or miscellaneous waste in any park, except in containers provided for that purpose. No person shall deposit household waste in park refuse containers. No person shall bring any dog or animal feces into any park for disposal in any park container, or otherwise. No person shall place or deposit any lawn clippings, leaves or other yard waste in any park. 
(Ord. No. 1141, 12-5-2006; Ord. No. 1324, 3-4-2014) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1324, adopted March 4, 2014, changed the title of § 28-33 from "Waste to be deposited in containers; household waste; animal feces" to read as herein set out. 
Cross reference- Solid waste generally, ch. 36. 
Sec. 28-34. - Restrictions. 
    While in a park, no person shall: 
(1)  Hunt, trap or attempt to trap any animal except for persons acting under the direction of the State of Michigan or City of East Lansing as part of a wildlife control protocol approved by the City Council of the City of East Lansing; 
(2)  Build or maintain any fire except in grills and fixtures provided for that purpose; 
(3)  Camp overnight; 
(4)  Drive or park any motor vehicle except in roads and parking areas designated for the public; 
(5)  Play or practice golf or archery; 
(6)  Possess or ignite fireworks; 
(7)  Erect any tent, net, or structure in a park unless done pursuant to a written permit from the city manager or his/her designee under the rules adopted pursuant to section 28-40. 
(Ord. No. 1141, 12-5-2006; Ord. No. 1358, 2-23-2016) 
Sec. 28-35. - Loudspeakers. 
    Except as provided by section 26-83 of this Code, no person shall individually, or in concert with others use or employ any loudspeaker, amplifier, or other device to amplify any noise in any city park without a written permit issued by the city manager or his designee pursuant to the rules adopted under section 28-40. 
(Ord. No. 1141, 12-5-2006) 
Sec. 28-36. - Alcoholic beverages. 
    No person shall possess or consume any alcoholic beverage in a city park except that beer and wine may be possessed and consumed in Patriarch Park with a permit issued by the city manager or his or her designee under the rules adopted pursuant to section 28-40. 
(Ord. No. 1141, 12-5-2006; Ord. No. 1239, 5-5-2010; Ord. No. 1290, 2-5-2013) 
Sec. 28-37. - Sales of goods, services, food or refreshments. 
    No person shall sell or solicit sales of any goods, services, food or refreshments in a city park without a permit issued by the city manager or his designee under the rules adopted pursuant to section 28-40. 
(Ord. No. 1141, 12-5-2006) 
Sec. 28-38. - Permits for certain activities conducted at events. 
    Permits may be issued under the rules adopted pursuant to section 28-40 only for activities to be conducted in parks designated by the city manager as available for reservation, and only for activities to be conducted at an event for which a park has been properly reserved under said rules adopted pursuant to section 28-40. No activity in a park shall be permitted for any period extending beyond the time set forth in any permit issued pursuant to this section. 
(Ord. No. 1141, 12-5-2006) 
Sec. 28-39. - Reservation of parks or facilities. 
    A specific group or organization may reserve city parks or particular facilities therein (to the exclusion of the general public) as may, from time to time, be designated as available for reservation by the city manager pursuant to the rules adopted under section 28-40. Reservations shall be processed in accordance with the said rules. 
(Ord. No. 1141, 12-5-2006) 
Sec. 28-40. - Authority of city manager to make rules. 
    The city manager is hereby empowered to make such rules and regulations subject to the approval of the city council, pertaining to the conduct, use, and reservations of parks and public grounds as are necessary to administer the same and to protect public property and the safety, health, morals, and welfare of the public. The city manager may cause all or part of such rules and regulations to be posted in the city parks, and no person shall fail to comply with such rules and regulations. 
(Ord. No. 1141, 12-5-2006) 
Sec. 28-41. - Municipal civil infractions. 
    Except as provided in section 28-31 any person who violates a provision of this chapter or any rule promulgated and posted by the city manager pursuant to section 28-40 shall be responsible for a municipal civil infraction and shall be subject to the penalties provided in section 1-13 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 1141, 12-5-2006) 
Sec. 28-42. - Additional penalty for certain violations. 
    In addition to the penalties provided by section 1-12 of this Code, any person convicted of a violation of section 28-31 shall be liable to reimburse the city in an amount up to three times the amount of the damage as determined by the court. If the defendant is a minor, the judgment for liquidated damages as provided in MCL 600.2915 shall be entered against his or her parents. 
(Ord. No. 1141, 12-5-2006) 
Chapter 30 - SECONDHAND GOODS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 8. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 30-1-30-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SECONDHAND GOODS AND JUNK DEALERS 

Sec. 30-31. - License required. 
    No person shall engage in the business of secondhand dealer or junk dealer without first obtaining a license therefor. No such license shall be granted until the mayor shall find that the proposed business will not tend to create a hazard to the public health or tend to depreciate property in the area unduly, or retard the natural development of the area, or be a violation of any provisions of this Code. 
(Code 1994, ch. 78, § 7.141) 
Sec. 30-32. - Licensing generally; license fee; adoption of state law. 
    Licenses under this article shall be issued by the mayor for a period of one year from the date of issuance unless sooner revoked for cause and shall otherwise be subject to the provisions of Public Act No. 350 of 1917 in all respects. Except as otherwise provided in Public Act No. 350 of 1917, the provisions of chapter 8, article II, division 2 of this Code shall be applicable to licenses issued hereunder and the fee for such license shall be as prescribed in chapter 8, article II, division 3 of this Code. Section 1 to section 7 of Public Act No. 350 of 1917 (MCL 445.401-445.407), and section 1 and section 2 of Public Act No. 231 of 1945 (MCL 445.471 and 445.472), relating to secondhand dealers and junk dealers, and section 1 through section 5 of Public Act No. 95 of 1981 (MCL 445.481-445.485), relating to precious metal and gem dealers, are hereby expressly incorporated into and made a part of this Code by reference, and no person shall violate any such law, rule, or regulation. 
(Code 1994, ch. 78, § 7.142) 
Sec. 30-33. - Pawning and security transactions prohibited. 
    No licensee hereunder shall receive, in the course of his/her business, any article by way of pledge or pawn, nor shall he/she loan or advance any sum of money or the security of any article or thing. 
(Code 1994, ch. 78, § 7.143) 
Sec. 30-34. - Loitering by minors prohibited. 
    No minor under the age of 17 years shall loiter, nor be permitted to loiter, about the premises of any licensee. 
(Code 1994, ch. 78, § 7.144) 
Sec. 30-35. - Hours restricted. 
    No person shall be permitted upon the premises of such licensee during the period from 7:00 p.m. until 7:00 a.m., except a necessary watchman. 
(Code 1994, ch. 78, § 7.145) 
Secs. 30-36-30-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SECONDHAND AUTOMOBILES 

Sec. 30-61. - License required. 
    No person shall engage in the business or occupation of dealing in secondhand automobiles without first obtaining a license therefor. No such license shall be granted except upon certification of the chief of police and the fire chief. 
(Code 1994, ch. 79, § 7.151) 
Sec. 30-62. - Bond required. 
    No license shall be issued under this article until the applicant therefor has filed with the city clerk a corporate surety bond in the amount specified in chapter 8, article II, division 3. Said bond shall run to the people of the City of East Lansing for the use of and may be sued on by the city or any person or persons who may have a cause of action against the licensee under this Code or the laws of the State of Michigan, in connection with the operation of the licensed business. Such bond shall be conditioned that said obligor will faithfully conform to, and abide by, the provisions of this article and the laws of the State of Michigan pertaining to used automobile dealers, and will pay to the city and to any such person or persons any and all moneys that may become due or owing to the city or to such person or persons from said licensee under, and by virtue of, the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1994, ch. 79, § 7.152) 
Sec. 30-63. - Purchases from minors, thieves or receivers of stolen goods prohibited. 
    No licensee shall purchase or receive any automobile or automobile part or accessory from any person known or suspected to be a thief or receiver of stolen property, or from any person under the age of 17 years, without the written consent of the parent or guardian of such person. 
(Code 1994, ch. 79, § 7.153) 
Sec. 30-64. - Record of business to be kept. 
    No licensee shall fail to keep a daily record of all vehicles coming into his/her possession, together with the disposition of each, and the names of persons from whom purchased or received and to whom sold or otherwise disposed. Nor shall any licensee fail to report the same weekly, and within three days following the end of each week, to the chief of police on forms prescribed by the chief of police. The chief of police shall at all times have access to such daily records. 
(Code 1994, ch. 79, § 7.154) 
Chapter 32 - SIGNS[1] 
Footnotes:

Former ch. 32 consisted of §§ 32-1-32-8, 32-31-32-34, 32-51-32-55, 32-71-32-80, and 32-101-32-115, pertained to the same subject matter and derived from the 1994 Code; Ord. No. 984, adopted March 6, 2001; Ord. No. 1016, adopted August 20, 2002; Ord. No. 1122, adopted July 19, 2005; Ord. No. 1103, adopted September 20, 2005; Ord. No. 1130, adopted November 1, 2005; and Ord. No. 1155, adopted September 5, 2006. 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 6; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 38; zoning, ch. 50. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1328, adopted May 6, 2014, amended art. I in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former art. I, §§ 32-1-32-8, pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Ord. No. 1218, adopted April 21, 2009; Ord. No. 1234, adopted Nov. 4, 2009; and Ord. No. 1310, adopted Oct. 15, 2013. 

Sec. 32-1. - Applicability. 
    This chapter shall apply to all persons, firms, associations, and corporations owning, occupying, or having control or management of any premises located within the city limits of the City of East Lansing. 
(Ord. No. 1328, 5-6-2014) 
Sec. 32-2. - Conflict with other laws. 
    In any case where a provision of this chapter is found to be in conflict with a provision of any zoning, building, housing, fire, safety, or health ordinance or code of the City of East Lansing existing on the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived, the provision which establishes the higher standard for the promotion and protection of the health and safety of the people shall prevail. In any case where a provision of any other ordinance or code of the City of East Lansing existing on the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived establishes a lower standard for the promotion and protection of the health and safety of the people, the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed to prevail, and such other ordinances or codes are hereby declared to be repealed to the extent that they may be found in conflict with this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1328, 5-6-2014) 
Sec. 32-3. - Definitions. 
    The following definitions will apply in the interpretation, administration, and enforcement of this chapter: 
    A-frame sign means a portable sign with two panels, typically connected at the top of the panels, forming an "A" shape. 
    Agricultural premises means premises used or occupied for the cultivation of field crops, truck crops, nurseries, orchards, greenhouses, woodlots, pastures, or the husbandry of livestock, poultry or small animals, or any activities of a similar nature. 
    Awning sign means a sign which is attached directly to, or painted, or otherwise inscribed upon, an awning. Awnings must be supported entirely from the exterior wall of a building. Awnings shall have noncombustible frames but may have combustible coverings. 
    Backlit illuminated means a reversed channel letter with an open or translucent back so that light from the letter is directed against the surface behind the letter, producing a halo lighting effect around the letter. 
    Banner means a sign constructed of canvas, paper, cloth, nylon or other similar non-rigid fabric-like material without an enclosing structural framework. 
    Billboard means any sign in excess of 120 square feet of display area on any single face. 
    Building official means the officer or officers charged, pursuant to this Code, with the administration and enforcement of this chapter and/or their duly appointed deputies, agents, employees, and inspectors. 
    Business center means any group of six or more commercial establishments having a development area of not less than two acres which: 
(a)  Are under one common ownership or management; or 
(b)  Have a common arrangement for the maintenance of the grounds and are connected by the party walls, partitions, covered canopies or other structural members to form one continuous structure; or 
(c)  Share a common parking area; or 
(d)  Otherwise present the appearance of one continuous commercial area. 
    Channel letters means a fabricated or formed three-dimensional letter that may accommodate a light source. 
    Clearance of a sign means the vertical distance from the lowest part of the face of the sign to the average ground level at the base of the sign. 
    Commercial premises means premises used or occupied for transportation, retail sales, or service businesses; restaurants; wholesale sales facilities; apartment hotel, tourist homes or motels; or commercial recreation. 
    Construction zone means any area of construction activity that requires or causes to require a valid building permit resulting in a certificate of occupancy. 
    Curbline means the back line of the curb. 
(1)  Existing curbline means the curbline of an existing curb. 
(2)  Future curbline means the future design curbline (as determined by the city engineer) of a four-lane roadway. For the purpose of determining permitted sign locations according to this chapter, the "future curbline" shall be the point of reference for signs permitted along Coolidge Road, Lake Lansing Road, Hagadorn Road north of Saginaw Street, and Abbot Road north of Lake Lansing Road. 
    Development entry sign means one or more signs located at or near the entrance of a development consisting of multiple structures, which was approved under a single development plan such as a shopping center, cluster development plan, neo-traditional neighborhood redevelopment plan, subdivision, condominium, or planned unit development, and which is harmonious in appearance with that vicinity. 
    Directly illuminated signs means a sign that is illuminated by a light source that is directed towards and shines on the face of the sign. 
    Dissolve effect means a mode of message transition on an electronic display sign accomplished by varying the light intensity or pattern, in which the old message gradually appears to dissipate and lose legibility with the gradual appearance and increase in legibility of the new message. 
    Downtown development authority (D.D.A.) district is an area defined by Ordinance 1106, adopted June 6, 2006 by the City of East Lansing. 
    Electronic display sign means any sign or portion thereof that displays changeable messages through different combinations of light emitting diodes, fiber optics, light bulbs or other illuminations as part of the sign proper through computer controls. 
    Freestanding sign means a sign, the principal support of which is independent of any building. 
    Ground sign means a freestanding sign with an overall height of no more than ten feet and no visible support structure. 
    Height of sign means the maximum vertical distance from the uppermost extremity of a sign or sign support to the average ground level at the base of the sign. 
    Indirectly illuminated sign means a sign illuminated with a light source so shielded as to illuminate only the surface of the sign. 
    Institutional premises includes such premises or portions thereof upon which is situated a public utility or other publicly owned, operated, or administered facility; any public, private, or commercial-vocational school; a cultural facility, including a museum, art gallery, library, or auditorium; or a religious or charitable facility. 
    Joint sign means a freestanding sign for more than one commercial premises and where at least one of the commercial premises is not permitted a freestanding sign on their own, due to lack of frontage. 
    Limited access highway means every highway, street, or roadway in respect to which owners or occupants of abutting lands and other persons have no legal right of access to or from the same except at such points only, and in such manner as may be determined by the public authority having jurisdiction over such highway, street or roadway and to which pedestrian, bicycle and other nonmotorized traffic are prohibited pursuant to MCL 257.679a. 
    Major street means an expressway, regional thoroughfare, or major arterial as identified in the major street plan adopted by the City of East Lansing as part of the comprehensive plan. 
    Marquee sign means a sign which is attached directly to, or painted, or otherwise inscribed upon a marquee. Marquees shall be permanently roofed structures attached to and supported by the building and projecting over public property. 
    Multiple-family residential premises means premises used or occupied as residences for three or more families or as group housing. 
    Permanent sign means a sign installed on a support structure which is not intended or designed to be moved or removed, but to remain for an indefinite period of time. 
    Permitted sign means any sign requiring a sign permit, sign license, and associated fees. 
    Pole sign means a freestanding sign with a visible support structure. 
    Portable sign means any temporary sign, which by its description or nature, may be, or is intended to be, moved from one location to another. 
    Premises means a unit of contiguous real property under common ownership. 
    Projecting sign means any sign attached to a building which extends more than 12 inches beyond the vertical surface of the building which supports it. 
    Recreational premises means premises used or occupied for recreational purposes, including parks, play areas, indoor or outdoor swimming pools, bathing beaches, boating and fishing areas, winter recreational areas, nature study areas, community halls and fairgrounds. 
    Roof sign means a sign which is attached to a building and any part of which extends more than one foot above either the top line or any portion of the roof surface. 
    Sign means any display, illustration, surface, or device (including its structure and component parts) which is affixed to, painted on, or otherwise placed directly or indirectly upon a building, structure, or land; and which directs attention to an object, product, place, activity, person, institution, organization, or business; and which is visible from public street, right-of-way, sidewalk, alley, park, or other area open to the public. 
    Sign band means a horizontal band extending the full width of the building facade and located between the highest first floor window and a horizontal line six feet above that point. 
    Surface display area of a sign means the area expressed in square feet, within a single continuous rectilinear perimeter of straight lines enclosing the extreme limits of writing, representations, emblems, or figures of a similar character, together with all material or color forming an integral part of the display or used to differentiate the sign from the background against which it is placed, provided that: 
(a)  In the case of a sign designated with more that one exterior face, the area shall be computed as including only the maximum single displayed surface which is visible from the ground position; 
(b)  The supports, uprights, or structure on which any sign is supported shall not be included in determining the surface display area unless such supports, uprights, or structure is designed in such a manner as to form an integral background of the display; and 
(c)  The areas of lamps, neon tubing, or artificial illumination on walls of any structure shall be counted as part of the total allowable sign area.
