Secs. 44-373-44-400. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 10. - SNOWMOBILES AND BICYCLES 
Subdivision I. - Snowmobiles 

Sec. 44-401. - Definitions.(10.1) 
    As used in this chapter: 
(1)  Operator means any person who operates or is in actual physical control of a snowmobile. 
(2)  Owner means any of the following: 
(a)  A person who holds the legal title to a snowmobile. 
(b)  A vendee or lessee of a snowmobile which is the subject of an agreement for conditional sale or lease with the right of purchase upon performance of the conditions stated in the agreement and with an immediate right of possession vested in the conditional vendee or lessee. 
(c)  A person renting a snowmobile or having the exclusive use of a snowmobile for more than 30 days. 
(3)  Operate means to ride in or on and be in actual physical control of the operation of a snowmobile. 
(4)  Person means an individual, partnership, corporation, the state and any of the agencies or subdivisions, and any body of persons whether incorporated or not. 
(5)  Snowmobile means any motor-driven vehicle designed for travel primarily on snow or ice of a type which utilizes sled type runners or skis, or an endless belt tread or any combination of these or other similar means of contact with the surface upon which it is operated, but is not a vehicle which must be registered under the Michigan Vehicle Code, Public Act No. 300 of 1949, Public Act No. 821 of 1994, and Public Act No. 451 of 1994, being MCL 257.1-257.923. 
(6)  Dealer means any person engaged in the sale, lease, or rental of snowmobiles as a regular business. 
(7)  Highway or street means the entire width between the boundary lines of every way publicly maintained if any part thereof is open to the use of the public for purposes of vehicular travel. 
(8)  Roadway means that portion of a highway or street improved, designated, or ordinarily used for vehicular travel. If a highway or street includes two or more separate roadways the term "roadway" refers to any such roadway separately, but not to all such roadways collectively. 
(9)  Shoulder means that portion of a highway or street, on either side of a roadway, which is normally snowplowed for the safety and convenience of vehicular traffic. 
(10)  Act means the Natural Resources and Environmental Protection Act, being MCL 324.30101 et seq. 
(11)  Conviction means a final conviction, the payment of a fine, a plea of guilty or nolo contendere if accepted by the court, or a finding of guilt or probate court disposition on a violation of this Act, regardless of whether the penalty is rebated or suspended. 
(12)  Law of another state means a law or ordinance enacted by another state or by a local unit of government in another state. 
(13)  Probate court disposition means the entry of a probate court order of disposition for a child found to be within the provisions of chapter XIIA of Public Act No. 288 of 1939 (MCL 712A.1-712A.28). 
(14)  Prosecuting attorney means the East Lansing City Attorney. 
(Code 1994, ch. 126, § 10.1) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-7. 
Sec. 44-402. - Registration required; exceptions.(10.11) 
(1)  A snowmobile shall not be operated within the corporate limits of the city unless and until the owner first obtains a certificate of registration and a registration decal pursuant to the Act, being MCL 324.30101 et seq., except that the following snowmobiles may be operated without being registered: 
(a)  A snowmobile operated exclusively on lands owned by or under the control of the snowmobile owner. 
(b)  A snowmobile used entirely in an approved safety education and training program conducted by a certified snowmobile safety instructor authorized under section 4c of the Act. 
(c)  A snowmobile that is exclusively operated in a special event of limited duration which is conducted according to a prearranged schedule under a permit from the city. 
(2)  A person who is convicted of a violation of this section shall be fined not more than $50.00. 
(Code 1994, ch. 126, § 10.11) 
Sec. 44-403. - Brakes.(10.21) 
    A snowmobile shall not be operated unless it is equipped with brakes which are capable of one of the following while the snowmobile travels on packed snow and carries an operator who weighs 175 pounds or more: 
(a)  Stopping the snowmobile in not more than 40 feet from an initial steady speed of 20 miles per hour. 
(b)  Locking the snowmobile traction belt or belts. 
(Code 1994, ch. 126, § 10.21) 
Sec. 44-404. - Lights.(10.22) 
    A snowmobile shall not be operated unless it has at least one headlight and one taillight. The lights shall be lighted when the snowmobile is being operated between the hours from one-half hour after sunset to one-half hour before sunrise. 
(Code 1994, ch. 126, § 10.22) 
Sec. 44-405. - Operating snowmobile under influence of intoxicating liquor or a controlled substance.(10.34) 
(1)  A person shall not operate a snowmobile in the city if either of the following applies: 
(a)  The person is under the influence of intoxicating liquor or a controlled substance, or both. 
(b)  The person has a blood alcohol content of 0.10 percent or more by weight of alcohol. 
(2)  The owner of a snowmobile or a person in charge or in control of a snowmobile shall not authorize or knowingly permit the snowmobile to be driven or operated by a person who is under the influence of intoxicating liquor or a controlled substance, or both, or who has a blood alcohol content of 0.10 percent by weight of alcohol. 
(3)  A person shall not operate a snowmobile when, due to the consumption of an intoxicating liquor or a controlled substance, or both, the person's ability to operate the snowmobile is visibly impaired. If a person is charged with violating subsection (1), a finding of guilty under this subsection may be rendered. 
(Code 1994, ch. 126, § 10.34) 
Sec. 44-406. - Penalties for violation of section 10.34.(10.34a) 
    If a person is convicted of violating section 10.34 [section 44-405] they shall be punished pursuant to the pertinent provisions of section 15b and section 15c of the Act in accordance with the charge and their history of prior convictions. 
(Code 1994, ch. 126, § 10.34a) 
Sec. 44-407. - Operation near dwellings.(10.35) 
    A person shall not operate a snowmobile within 1,000 feet of a dwelling at a speed greater than the minimum required to maintain forward movement of the snowmobile. 
(Code 1994, ch. 126, § 10.35) 
Sec. 44-408. - Operation by persons 12 to 16 years of age.(10.41) 
(1)  A person who is at least 12 but less than 17 years of age may operate a snowmobile if any one of the following requirements is met: 
(a)  He/she is under the direct supervision of a person who is not less than 21 years of age. 
(b)  He/she has in his/her immediate possession a snowmobile safety certificate issued to him/her. 
(c)  He/she is on land owned or under the control of his/her parent or legal guardian. 
(d)  He/she possesses a snowmobile safety certificate issued to the person under the authority of a law of another state or province of Canada. 
(2)  A person who is operating a snowmobile pursuant to subsection (1)(b) shall present the snowmobile safety certificate to any peace officer upon demand. 
(3)  An operator of a snowmobile who is at least 12 years of age but less than 17 years of age may cross a highway or street only if he or she has a valid snowmobile safety certificate in his/her immediate possession. 
(Code 1994, ch. 126, § 10.41) 
Sec. 44-409. - Arrest without warrant; procedures.(10.75) 
    If a person is arrested without warrant for a violation of this chapter, except a violation of section 10.34 [section 44-405] of this code, the arresting officer shall follow the procedures provided in section 2.10 of this code. 
    If a person is stopped, detained and/or arrested for a violation of section 10.34 [section 44-405] of this code, the officer, prosecuting attorney, and court shall follow the procedures provided in section 15 through section 29 and section 33, section 37, section 41 and section 43 of the Act. 
(Code 1994, ch. 126, § 10.75) 
Sec. 44-410. - Penalties for operation by person ordered not to operate snowmobile.(10.76) 
(1)  A person who is ordered not to operate a snowmobile and who has been notified of the order by personal service or first class mail shall not operate a snowmobile. A person shall not knowingly permit a snowmobile owned by the person to be operated by a person who is subject to such an order. A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor punishable as follows; 
(a)  By imprisonment for not more than 90 days and/or by fine of not more than $500.00; and 
(b)  The court shall order cancellation of the certificate of registration for the snowmobile, unless the snowmobile was stolen or permission to use the snowmobile was not knowingly given. 
(Code 1994, ch. 126, § 10.76) 
Sec. 44-411. - Impoundment of snowmobile.(10.77) 
(1)  When a person is convicted under section 10.76 [section 44-410] the snowmobile, if it is owned by that person, shall be ordered impounded for not less than 30 or more than 120 days from the date of judgment. 
(2)  An order of impoundment issued pursuant to subsection (1) is valid throughout the state. Any peace officer may execute the impoundment order. The order shall include the implied consent of the owner of the snowmobile to the storage for insurance coverage purposes. 
(3)  The owner of a snowmobile impounded pursuant to this section is liable for expenses incurred in the removal and storage of the snowmobile whether or not the snowmobile is returned to him/her. The snowmobile shall be returned to the owner only if the owner pays the expenses for removal and storage. If redemption is not made or the snowmobile is not returned as provided in this section within 30 days after the time set in the impoundment order for return of the snowmobile, the snowmobile shall be considered abandoned. 
(4)  Nothing in this section affects the rights of a conditional vendor, chattel mortgagee or lessor of a snowmobile registered in the name of another person as owner who becomes subject to this Act. 
(Code 1994, ch. 126, § 10.77) 
Secs. 44-412-44-430. - Reserved. 
Subdivision II. - Bicycles 

Sec. 44-431. - Bicycles on sidewalks.(10.88) 
(1)  A person operating a bicycle upon and along a sidewalk shall have all the rights and duties applicable to a pedestrian. 
(2)  A person riding a bicycle across a roadway upon a crosswalk shall not exceed a walking or pedestrian speed. 
(3)  A person operating a bicycle upon a sidewalk, pedestrian mall, or across a roadway upon a crosswalk, shall yield the right-of-way to any pedestrian and shall give an audible signal before overtaking and passing such pedestrians. 
(4)  Beginning October 15, 1999, a person shall not operate a bicycle upon a sidewalk, a pedestrian mall, or across a roadway upon a crosswalk located on or adjacent to that portion of the north one-half of Grand River Avenue between Abbott Road and Collingwood Drive, except a police officer, parking enforcement officer or other authorized city official acting within the scope of his or her law enforcement duties. 
(Code 1994, ch. 126, § 10.88) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 38. 
Secs. 44-432-44-460. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 11. - OFF-ROAD VEHICLES 

Sec. 44-461. - Definitions.(11.1) 
    For purposes of this chapter an "off-road vehicle" shall be alternately designated as an "ORV" as defined in section 1 of Public Act No. 451 of 1994 (MCL 324.81101 et seq.). All other definitions contained therein shall be applicable in this chapter where appropriate. 
(Code 1994, ch. 126, § 11.1) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-7. 
Sec. 44-462. - Compliance with laws.(11.2) 
    A person may operate an off-road vehicle within the city, provided that, such operation strictly complies with all applicable laws and the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1994, ch. 126, § 11.2) 
Sec. 44-463. - Registration and equipment requirements; impoundment.(11.3) 
    No person shall operate an off-road vehicle which fails to meet the registration and equipment requirements set forth in the law of the State of Michigan. A police officer may impound any ORV operated in his/her presence which does not display a registration decal in compliance with the ORV registration provisions of Public Act No. 451 of 1994. 
(Code 1994, ch. 126, § 11.3) 
Sec. 44-464. - Supervision of minors under age 12; exception; incompetency; operation by minor between ages 12 and 16; conditions.(11.4) 
(1)  A parent or legal guardian shall not permit a child under 12 years of age to operate a vehicle without the supervision of an adult, except on land owned by, or under the control of, the parent or legal guardian. 
(2)  The owner or person in charge or in control of a vehicle shall not knowingly permit: 
(a)  The vehicle to be operated by a person under the age of 12 without direct supervision of an adult. 
(b)  The vehicle to be operated by a person who is incompetent to operate the vehicle because of mental or physical disability; or because the person is under the influence of intoxicating liquor; a controlled substance as defined by section 7104 of Public Act No. 368 of 1978 (MCL 333.7104); or a combination of intoxicating liquor and a controlled substance. 
(3)  A person who is at least 12, but less than 16 years of age may operate an ORV if that person satisfies any of the following: 
(a)  Is under the direct supervision of a person who is 18 years of age or older. 
(b)  Is on land owned or under the control of a parent or legal guardian. 
(c)  Has in immediate possession an ORV safety certificate issued pursuant to Public Act No. 451 of 1994. 
(d)  Possesses an ORV safety certificate issued under the authority of another state or province of Canada. 
(4)  When operating an ORV under subsection (c) or (d), that person shall present the ORV safety certificate to a police officer upon demand. 
(5)  Notwithstanding any other provision of this section, an operator who is under 12 years of age shall not cross a highway or street. An operator who is at least 12 years of age, but less than 16 years of age, may cross a highway or street to operate on the right-of-way or shoulder of designated access routes pursuant to section 18 if the operator has a valid ORV safety certificate in immediate possession. 
(Code 1994, ch. 126, § 11.4) 
Sec. 44-465. - Operating restrictions.(11.5) 
(1)  A person shall not operate an ORV: 
(a)  On the private real property of another person, unless such operator has the written consent of the owner of such property for such use. 
(b)  Upon public property within the city, except as provided by section 11.5a [section 44-466] and as otherwise specifically permitted by law. 
(c)  On private real property, in a reckless or negligent manner, or in a manner so as to cause injury or damage or be likely to cause injury or damage, to any person or property, or so as to constitute a nuisance under chapter 26 of the City Code, or so as to disturb the quiet, comfort or repose of persons in any dwelling, hotel, hospital, or other type of residence or of any persons in the vicinity. 
(d)  On private real property, within 1,000 feet of any dwelling unit unless such person is traveling to or from his/her residence in a manner otherwise consistent with the terms of this chapter, and at a speed no greater than that required to maintain forward movement of the vehicle. 
(e)  At a rate of speed greater than is reasonable and proper or in a careless manner having due regard for conditions then existing. 
(f)  While under the influence of intoxicating liquor, a controlled substance, or a combination of intoxicating liquor and controlled substance. 
(g)  During the hours of one-half hour after sunset to one-half hour before sunrise without displaying a lighted headlight and lighted taillight. 
(h)  Unless equipped with a braking system which may be operated by hand or foot, capable of producing deceleration at 14 feet a second on level ground at a speed of 20 miles per hour; a brake light, brighter than the taillight, visible when the brake is activated to the rear of the vehicle when the vehicle is operated during the hours of one-half hour after sunset and one-half hour before sunrise; and a throttle so designed that when the means used to advance the throttle is removed, the engine speed will immediately and automatically return to idle. 
(i)  On the frozen surface of public waters within 100 feet of a person not in or upon a vehicle, or within 100 feet of a fishing shanty or shelter, or an area which is cleared of snow for skating purposes, except at the minimum speed required to maintain controlled forward movement of the vehicle, or as may be authorized by permit in special events. 
(j)  Unless the vehicle is equipped with a spark arrester type muffler, in good working order and in constant operation. Exhaust noise emission shall not exceed 86 dB(A) or 82 dB(A) on a vehicle manufactured after January 1, 1986, when the vehicle is under full throttle, traveling in second gear, and measured 50 feet at right angles from the vehicle path with a sound level meter which meets the requirement of ANSI SI.4-1983, using procedure and ancillary equipment therein described; or 99 dB(A) or 94 dB(A) on a vehicle manufactured after January 1, 1986, or that level comparable to the current sound level as provided for by the environmental protection agency when tested according to the provisions of the current SAE J1287, June 86 test procedure for exhaust levels of stationary motorcycles, using procedures and ancillary equipment therein described. A vehicle subject to this Act, manufactured or assembled after December 31, 1982 and used, sold, or offered for sale in this state shall conform to the noise emission levels established by the environmental protection agency under the Noise Control Act of 1972, Public Law 92-574, 86 Stat. 1234, except in an officially authorized special event. 
(k)  Unless the person and any passenger in or on the vehicle is wearing on his/her head a crash helmet and protective eyewear approved by the United States Department of Transportation. This subsection shall not apply if the vehicle is equipped with a roof that meets or exceeds standards for a crash helmet and the operator and each passenger is wearing a properly adjusted and fastened safety belt. 
(l)  On or across a cemetery or burial ground, or land used as an airport. 
(m)  Within 100 feet of a slide, ski, or skating area, unless the vehicle is being used for the purpose of servicing the area. 
(n)  On an operating or non-abandoned railroad or railroad right-of-way, other than for the purpose of crossing at a clearly established site intended for vehicular traffic, except railroad, public utility, or law enforcement personnel while in performance of their duties. 
(o)  In or upon the waters of any stream, except for the purpose of crossing the stream over a bridge, culvert, or similar structure, or by operating the vehicle at the minimum speed required to maintain controlled forward movement of the vehicle and crossing in the most direct manner from and to an established trail so as to negate erosive damage to the bed and banks of the stream or river or as may otherwise be authorized by the director of the department of natural resources on state-owned land. 
(p)  On private real property within the city, other than a snowmobile as defined in section 10.007 of this chapter, from and including November 16 of any year to and including May 1 of the succeeding year. 
(q)  In a manner so as to leave behind litter or other debris. 
(r)  In a manner contrary to operating regulations on public lands. 
(Code 1994, ch. 126, § 11.5) 
Sec. 44-466. - Operation of off-road vehicles upon public property within city by permanently disabled persons.(11.5a) 
(1)  A permanently disabled person may operate an ORV upon public property within the city subject to the following requirements: 
(a)  When operating upon a sidewalk or other area open to pedestrian traffic, the vehicle shall be driven at a speed no greater than five miles per hour and the driver shall yield the right-of-way to any pedestrian and shall give an audible signal before overtaking and passing such pedestrian. 
(b)  When operating upon city streets the operator shall: 
(i)  Obey all state Motor Vehicle Code and East Lansing traffic code regulations governing the operation of vehicles, except those provisions regulating equipment, licensing, registration or financial responsibility for motor vehicles. 
(ii)  Comply with all state Motor Vehicle Code regulations and East Lansing ordinances and regulations governing the operation of ORVs. 
(iii)  Operate the vehicle only on those streets with a 25 mile per hour or less speed limit unless the vehicle can be safely driven at a sufficient speed so as not to impede the flow of traffic or endanger persons or property. 
(2)  For purposes of this section a "permanently disabled person" is a person who has one or more characteristics as defined by MCL 324.81101 which is expected to continue indefinitely. 
(3)  Prior to operation of the vehicle upon city streets, the operator shall demonstrate to the satisfaction of the chief of police or his/her designate that the person is a "permanently disabled person" and that such vehicle can be operated by the operator safely upon city streets. The chief's written determination shall be provided to the operator and published to all members of the police department. 
(4)  The transportation commission is hereby empowered to make such additional rules and regulations, subject to the approval of the city council, pertaining to the operation of ORVs on public property by permanently disabled persons. 
(Code 1994, ch. 126, § 11.5a) 
Sec. 44-467. - Operating under influence of liquor or controlled substance.(11.6) 
    If a police officer has reasonable cause to believe that a person was, at the time of an accident, the driver of an ORV involved in the accident and was operating the ORV while under the influence of an intoxicating liquor; a controlled substance as defined in section 7104 of Public Act No. 368 of 1978 (MCL 337.7104); or a combination of intoxicating liquor and a controlled substance, the police officer may arrest the alleged driver of the ORV without a warrant. 
(Code 1994, ch. 126, § 11.6) 
Sec. 44-468. - Violation, misdemeanor.(11.7) 
    A person who violates a provision of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1994, ch. 126, § 11.7) 
Sec. 44-469. - Accidents, notice to police.(11.8) 
(1)  The operator of an ORV involved in an accident resulting in injuries to, or death of, a person, or resulting in property damage in an estimated amount of $100.00 or more, shall immediately, by the quickest available means of communication, notify a police officer. The police agency receiving the notice shall complete a report of the accident on forms prescribed by the director of the department of state police, and forward the report to the department of state police. 
(2)  The operator of a vehicle involved in an accident upon public or private property, resulting in an injury to or death of a person, shall immediately stop at the scene of an accident and shall render to any person injured in the accident reasonable assistance in securing medical aid or transportation. 
(Code 1994, ch. 126, § 11.8) 
Sec. 44-470. - Violations, appearance tickets, presumptions.(11.9) 
(1)  Law enforcement officers may issue appearance tickets for violations of this Act, pursuant to MCL 324.101 et seq. 
(2)  In a proceeding for a violation of this Act involving prohibited operation or conduct, the registration number or numbered decal or VIN displayed on an ORV shall constitute prima facie evidence that the owner of the vehicle was the person operating the vehicle at the time of the offense, unless the owner identifies the operator to law enforcement officials, the vehicle was reported as stolen at the time of the violation, or that the vehicle was stolen or not in use at the time of the violation. 
(Code 1994, ch. 126, § 11.9) 
Sec. 44-471. - Failure to obey officer or identify self.(11.10) 
(1)  An operator of an ORV, who is given by hand, voice, emergency light, or siren a visual or audible signal by a law enforcement officer acting in the lawful performance of his/her duty directing the operator to bring the vehicle to a stop, and who willfully fails to obey the signal by increasing speed, extinguishing lights, or otherwise attempting to flee or elude the officer, is guilty of a misdemeanor. The officer giving the signal shall be in uniform, and the officer's vehicle shall be easily identifiable as an official law enforcement vehicle. 
(2)  The operator of a vehicle on the private premises of another, when visibly hailed by the owner or the owner's authorized agent, shall bring the vehicle to an immediate stop and provide personal identification. Refusal to obey such a request to stop, or subsequent escape, or attempt to escape, is a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1994, ch. 126, § 11.10) 
Secs. 44-472-44-520. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Off-street parking requirements, § 50-811 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 44-521-44-540. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CITY PARKING SYSTEM 

Sec. 44-541. - Supervision of system. 
    The automobile parking of the city shall be under the supervision and direction of the city manager. 
(Code 1994, ch. 26, § 2.121) 
Sec. 44-542. - Rates. 
    The rates for parking in metered spaces on any street and for parking in off-street parking lots and structures, operated as a part of the automobile parking system, shall be established by resolution of the city council, from time to time, upon recommendation of the city manager. Such rates need not be uniform throughout the system, but shall be based upon demand for parking in the area which the lot or structure serves and such other considerations as the council shall deem pertinent. The rates and charges in effect upon the date of the adoption of this article shall remain in effect until thereafter changed as herein provided. 
(Code 1994, ch. 26, § 2.122) 
Sec. 44-543. - Vehicles to be parked in designated areas. 
    No person shall park any motor vehicle in any parking lot or structure or in any metered space on any street other than within the boundaries of the space designated as allocated for the parking of a single motor vehicle by appropriate lines or other markings. Any person parking any motor vehicle in any parking lot or structure, or in any metered space on any street otherwise than as herein prescribed, shall be guilty of a violation of this article. 
(Code 1994, ch. 26, § 2.123) 
Sec. 44-544. - Garage and nonmetered lot parking. 
    Every person who parks a motor vehicle in any nonmetered parking lot or garage of the automobile parking system shall pay the rates duly established for such parking before removing said vehicle from the parking lot or structure. 
(Code 1994, ch. 26, § 2.124) 
Sec. 44-545. - Metered parking lots and on-street metered parking. 
(a)  In parking lots and in metered spaces on any street of the system where parking charges are collected by means of parking meters installed adjacent to the parking spaces, no person shall: 
(1)  Park a motor vehicle in any metered space without placing a United States coin of proper denomination in the meter in accordance with the regulations posted on said meters during the hours the said regulations require the payment of parking charges. 
(2)  Permit a motor vehicle in his/her custody, or owned by him/her, to remain in any metered zone except while lawful parking time appears on the meter regulating the space occupied by such motor vehicle. 
(3)  Deface, injure, open, or tamper with any parking meter installed on any such parking lot, except as authorized by the city manager. 
(b)  A person who violates subsections (a)(1) and (2) of this section is responsible for a civil infraction and subject to a civil fine not to exceed $100.00 plus costs assessed by the court. 
(Code 1994, ch. 26, § 2.125) 
Sec. 44-546. - Vehicle abandonment. 
(a)  Any motor vehicle parked for more than 24 consecutive hours in any parking lot or structure of the system shall be deemed abandoned, and may be removed by the city and impounded. 
(b)  Any motor vehicle otherwise parked in violation of this article may be removed by the city from the parking lot or structure in which it is parked and impounded. Any vehicle so impounded by the city shall not be released to the owner until all parking charges, storing, and towing charges shall have been paid by the owner. The procedure for disposing of impounded vehicles shall be as specified in this chapter. The abandonment of a vehicle as herein defined shall constitute a violation of this article. 
(Code 1994, ch. 26, § 2.126) 
Sec. 44-547. - Presumption regarding responsibility for violation. 
    In any proceeding for violation of the provisions of this article relating to parking, proof that the particular vehicle described in the complaint was parked in violation of this article, together with proof that the defendant named in the complaint was at the time of such parking the registered owner of such vehicle, shall constitute in evidence a presumption that the registered owner of such vehicle was the person who parked or placed such vehicle at the point where, and for the time during which, such violation occurred. 
(Code 1994, ch. 26, § 2.127) 
Sec. 44-548. - Authority to make additional regulations. 
    The city manager is hereby empowered to make such additional rules and regulations, subject to the approval of city council, pertaining to the conduct, use, and occupancy by the public of the city public parking lots and structures as are necessary to protect the public and private property and the safety, health, and welfare of the public. Such rules shall not prohibit the exercise of constitutionally protected freedoms of speech, press or petition. A person who fails to bring his/her conduct into compliance with a rule or regulation adopted hereunder after having been informed by a police officer or a lot attendant and the penalty for a violation thereof and having been given a reasonable opportunity to comply shall be punished in the manner provided by section 1-12 of this Code. 
(Code 1994, ch. 26, § 2.128) 
Secs. 44-549-44-570. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - BICYCLES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 44-571. - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases as defined in this article and as herein enumerated when used in this article shall, for the purpose of this article, have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this article. 
    Bicycle includes every vehicle propelled solely by human power upon which any person may ride, having one, two, or three wheels, all of which are 14 inches, or greater, in diameter. 
    Business district means the territory contiguous to a highway when 50 percent or more of the frontage thereon for a distance of 300 feet or more is occupied by buildings in use for business. 
    Central business district means all highways, streets, and portions of highways and streets within the area which is zoned B-3. 
    Controlled (limited) access highway means every highway, street, or roadway in respect to which owners or occupants of abutting lands and other persons have no legal right of access to or from the same, except at such points only, and in such manner, as may be determined by the public authority having jurisdiction over such highway, street, or roadway. 
    Crosswalk means: 
(1)  That part of a roadway at an intersection included within the connections of the lateral lines of the sidewalks on opposite sides of the highway measured from the curbs, or in the absence of curbs, from the edges of the traversable roadway, and in the absence of a sidewalk on one side of the roadway, that part of a roadway included within the extension of the lateral lines of the existing sidewalk at right angles to the centerline. 
(2)  Any portion of a roadway at an intersection or elsewhere distinctly indicated for pedestrians crossing by lines or other markings on the surface. 
    Cyclist means a person who is not afoot and is riding or is in actual physical control of a bicycle. 
    Department means the Police Department of the City of East Lansing acting directly or through duly authorized employees and/or representatives. 
    Freeway means a divided arterial highway or street for through traffic with full control or access and with all crossroads separated in grade from pavements for through traffic. 
    Highway or street means the entire width between the property lines (right-of-way) of publicly maintained ways when any part thereof is open to the use of the public for purposes of vehicular travel. 
    Identifying number means the combination of numbers, words, and/or letters which is stamped, etched, or embossed by the department and is unique to a particular bicycle. 
    License means an adhesive-backed reflective print or reflective plate issued under the provisions of this article at the time of registration. 
    Pedestrian means any person afoot, including a person not astride the seat and walking beside a bicycle. 
    Roadway means that portion of a highway improved, designed, or ordinarily used for vehicular travel, exclusive of the sidewalk, berm, shoulder, or bikeway, even though such areas are used by persons riding bicycles. In the event a highway includes two or more separate roadways, the term "roadway" shall refer to any such roadway separately, but not to all such roadways collectively. 
    Shall and may are defined as "shall" being mandatory and "may" being permissive. 
    Sidewalk means that portion of a highway or street between the curblines, or the lateral lines of a roadway, and the adjacent property lines intended for the use by pedestrians. 
    Title, certificate of, means a document issued by the department which states: 
(1)  The name, address, and telephone number of the owner, the registration number and identifying number. 
(2)  A description of the bicycle, including the make, model, manufacturer's serial number, frame type, and color. 
    Usable path for bicycles means a public way for the exclusive use of cyclists. 
(1)  Bike lane means a bicycle-only facility parallel to and part of the roadway. 
(2)  Bikeway means a bicycle-only facility parallel and adjacent to a roadway. 
(3)  Bikepath means a bicycle-only facility not adjacent to a roadway but connected to a public way. 
    Vehicle means every device in, upon, or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a highway or street, excepting devices used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks. 
(Code 1994, ch. 127, §§ 10.31-10.50) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-7. 
Sec. 44-572. - Rights and duties of persons riding bicycles. 
    Every person riding a bicycle upon a roadway shall have all the rights and all of the duties applicable to the driver of any other vehicle as set forth in this chapter, except as to special regulations in this article and except as to those provisions which by their nature can have no application. 
(Code 1994, ch. 127, § 10.55) 
Sec. 44-573. - Severability. 
    If any provision, section, subsection, sentence, clause, or phrase of this article is for any reason held to be unconstitutional or void, said ruling shall not affect the validity of the remaining parts of this article. 
(Code 1994, ch. 127, § 10.57) 
Sec. 44-574. - Public notice of regulations. 
    Public notice of all rules, regulations, and provisions of this article which are made hereunder shall become effective when notice of the same shall have been given by publication in a newspaper of general circulation within the city. 
(Code 1994, ch. 127, § 10.111) 
Sec. 44-575. - Repealer. 
    All other provisions or parts of ordinances of the City of East Lansing in conflict with this article are hereby repealed. 
(Code 1994, ch. 127, § 10.112) 
Sec. 44-576. - Authority to make additional regulations. 
    The East Lansing City Council is hereby empowered to establish, by resolution, policy (rules and regulations) and fees consistent with the provisions of this article regarding the titling and registration of bicycles as defined herein, and the operation of any bicycle on any public way or publicly owned property within the city. 
(Code 1994, ch. 127, § 10.110) 
Sec. 44-577. - Violations. 
(a)  It shall be a misdemeanor for any person to ride a bicycle on any highway, street or public way in this city which does not contain those parts or is not equipped with such lamps and other equipment in proper condition and adjustment as required in this article, or which is equipped in any manner in violation of this article, or for any person to do any act forbidden or fail to perform any act required under this article. 
(b)  It shall be a misdemeanor for the parent or guardian of any minor to authorize or knowingly permit any such minor to violate any provisions of this article. 
(Code 1994, ch. 127, § 10.56) 
Secs. 44-578-44-600. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

Sec. 44-601. - Responsibility for administration and enforcement. 
    The department of this city shall be responsible for enforcing and administering all the provisions of this article. The department shall establish procedures which ensure the timely and efficient performance of its responsibilities as defined herein. 
(Code 1994, ch. 127, § 10.65) 
Sec. 44-602. - Bicycle inspections. 
    A uniformed police officer or authorized employee of the department, having reasonable cause to believe that a bicycle is unsafe or not equipped as required by law or the provisions of division 3 of this article or division 4 of this article or that its equipment is not in proper adjustment or repair, may require the person in control of such bicycle to submit the bicycle to an inspection and such tests as may be necessary to determine compliance with those provisions. 
(Code 1994, ch. 127, § 10.66) 
Sec. 44-603. - Impoundment. 
(a)  The department may take into its custody and impound any bicycle from a public way or publicly owned property within the city limits when: 
(1)  It is unregistered, improperly registered, or not displaying a license as required in division 3 of this article; 
(2)  It is being ridden and is deemed to be in an unsafe condition as described in division 5 of this article or not properly equipped as required in division 4 of this article; 
(3)  It is deemed to have been abandoned; 
(4)  It is improperly parked and creating a hazard as described in division 5 of this article. 
(b)  A person feeling aggrieved by the impoundment of his/her bicycle shall be entitled to a hearing before the mayor, or his/her designate. The mayor, or his/her designate, shall have the authority to affirm, set aside, or alter any act of the chief of police taken under this section. Such hearing shall be held in a manner consistent with the provisions of the Michigan Administrative Procedures Act of 1969, where applicable. A written request for a hearing shall act as a stay of any order issued by the chief of police until a final determination and written opinion is rendered by the mayor. 
(Code 1994, ch. 127, § 10.67) 
Sec. 44-604. - Disposition of impounded bicycles. 
    When a bicycle is impounded and the department knows or is able to ascertain the owner thereof, the department shall within ten days give notice to such owner of the fact of impoundment and reasons thereof. 
(1)  An untitled bicycle shall not be released prior to a certificate of title being issued to the rightful owner by the department. 
(2)  A bicycle shall not be released prior to the receipt of an impoundment fee of $0.50 per day or a maximum impoundment fee of $5.00. 
(3)  Unclaimed bicycles and parts of such bicycles shall, 30 days following notification of impoundment, become the property of the City of East Lansing, and may be sold at public sale in substantially the same manner as provided for motor vehicles in MCL 257.252. 
(4)  If written application is made within ten days of sale by the former owner of the bicycle sold, any surplus received at the sale shall be returned to such former owner. Such surplus shall be determined by deducting the impoundment fee and the charges of the East Lansing Police Department and costs of the sale. 
(Code 1994, ch. 127, § 10.68) 
Sec. 44-605. - Penalties; appearance tickets. 
(a)  Civil infractions. Violations of provisions of this article deemed to be civil infractions under the provisions of Public Act No. 300 of 1949 shall be enforced as civil infractions in the same manner as provided in section 2.10a through section 2.10i of the Uniform Traffic Code, and shall be punished only by a fine and costs as provided in section 1-13 of this Code. 
(b)  Misdemeanors. All other violations shall be deemed to be misdemeanors and shall be enforced according to section 2.10 of the Uniform Traffic Code, and shall be punished as provided in section 1-12 of this Code. 
(c)  Issuance of appearance tickets. Employees of the East Lansing Police Department, other than sworn police officers, who are duly appointed and acting as "bicycle safety patrollers" shall be authorized to issue and serve appearance tickets with respect to any violation of this article pursuant to section 9(c)(2) of Public Act No. 147 of 1968 (MCL 764.91(c)(2)). 
(Code 1994, ch. 127, § 10.105) 
Secs. 44-606-44-630. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - TITLING AND LICENSE 

Sec. 44-631. - Certificate of title required. 
    A resident shall apply for a certificate of title within five days of acquiring a new or used bicycle. The forms and procedures for the titling of such bicycle shall be provided by and be under the administration and control of the department. 
(Code 1994, ch. 127, § 10.95) 
Sec. 44-632. - Issuance of capital area license. 
    The department shall issue a capital area license upon receiving proper application and the proper application and the prescribed registration fee, except that a license shall not be issued unless the bicycle is properly equipped as required in division 4 of this article. 
(Code 1994, ch. 127, § 10.96) 
Sec. 44-633. - Capital area license required. 
    No person shall ride or park a bicycle upon any public way or publicly owned property within the city limits unless such bicycle has a valid capital area license issued to the current registered owner and attached to the seat tube of such bicycle. 
(Code 1994, ch. 127, § 10.97) 
Sec. 44-634. - Expiration of capital area license. 
    Capital area licenses shall expire on March 31 of 1981 and every third year thereafter. 
(Code 1994, ch. 127, § 10.98) 
Sec. 44-635. - Bicycle rental. 
    A bicycle shall not be offered for rent nor rented within the city unless it is registered and a valid capital area license is attached thereto and the bicycle is equipped as required in division 4 of this article. 
(Code 1994, ch. 127, § 10.99) 
Sec. 44-636. - Replacement of license or certificate of title. 
    In the event the original license or certificate of title is lost, stolen, removed, defaced, or destroyed, a replacement shall be issued by the department upon receiving proper application and payment of the prescribed fee. 
(Code 1994, ch. 127, § 10.100) 
Sec. 44-637. - Destruction of license, identifying number or certificate of title. 
    No person shall willfully or maliciously remove, destroy, mutilate, or alter the license and/or identifying number or certificate of title of a bicycle. 
(Code 1994, ch. 127, § 10.101) 
Sec. 44-638. - Reporting of bicycle transactions. 
    Every business located within the city which is engaged in the business of selling new or secondhand bicycles shall report such transactions weekly to the department upon forms prescribed by the department. 
(Code 1994, ch. 127, § 10.102) 
Secs. 44-639-44-660. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - EQUIPMENT 

Sec. 44-661. - Brakes. 
    Brakes are required at all times. A bicycle shall be equipped with a brake or brakes which will enable a cyclist to stop such bicycle within 25 feet from a speed of ten miles per hour on dry, clean, level pavement. 
(Code 1994, ch. 127, § 10.75) 
Sec. 44-662. - Reflective materials. 
    Reflective materials are required at all times. A bicycle shall be equipped with: 
(1)  Pedal reflector. Reflective pedal elements which may be colorless or amber and shall be visible from the front and from the rear during nighttime from a distance of 200 feet when directly in front of lawful lower beams of headlamps on a motor vehicle. 
(2)  Rear reflector. A red reflector which shall be visible during the nighttime from a distance of 600 feet to the rear when directly in front of lawful lower beams of headlamps on a motor vehicle. 
(3)  Side reflectors. May either be tires which have integral reflective sidewalls forming a continuous circle, or wide angle prismatic spoke or frame reflectors. Reflectors attached to the front wheel shall be colorless or amber, and reflectors attached to the rear wheel shall be colorless or red. Side reflectors shall be visible at a right angle during the nighttime from 600 feet when directly in front of lawful lower beams of headlamps on a motor vehicle. 
(Code 1994, ch. 127, § 10.76) 
Sec. 44-663. - Headlamps. 
    Headlamps are required at night or during insufficient natural light. A bicycle while in motion upon any public way or publicly owned property within the city limits at any time from one-half hour after sunset to one-half hour before sunrise and at any other time when natural light is insufficient for safe travel shall be equipped with a lamp on the front emitting a white light visible from a distance of at least 500 feet to the front of such bicycle. 
(Code 1994, ch. 127, § 10.77) 
Sec. 44-664. - Sirens and whistles. 
    A bicycle shall not be equipped with, nor shall any person upon a bicycle use, any siren or whistle. 
(Code 1994, ch. 127, § 10.78) 
Sec. 44-665. - Attachment of trailer or semi-trailer. 
    Attaching a trailer or semi-trailer to a bicycle is permitted if that trailer or semi-trailer has been designed for such attachment, does not hinder the safe operation of the bicycle and is equipped with reflectors as required in section 44-662(2) and (3). 
(Code 1994, ch. 127, § 10.79) 
Secs. 44-666-44-690. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - OPERATION 

Sec. 44-691. - Manner of riding. 
(a)  No bicycle shall be used to carry more persons at one time than the number for which it is designed or equipped, except that an adult cyclist may carry a child securely attached to his/her person in a backpack or sling. 
(b)  No person riding a bicycle shall carry any package, bundle, or article which prevents the use of both hands in the control and operation of such bicycle. 
(c)  No person shall ride a bicycle in a careless, reckless, or acrobatic manner upon any public way or publicly owned property within the city. A person riding a bicycle shall keep one hand on the handlebars at all times. 
(d)  No person riding upon a bicycle shall attach the same or himself/herself to any other vehicle upon a roadway. 
(Code 1994, ch. 127, § 10.85) 
Sec. 44-692. - Riding on controlled or limited access highways or freeways restricted. 
    A person shall not ride a bicycle on any controlled (limited) access highway or freeway within the city limits. However, they may be operated on paths constructed separately from the roadway and designated for their use. 
(Code 1994, ch. 127, § 10.86) 
Sec. 44-693. - Riding on roadways. 
(a)  Every person riding a bicycle upon a roadway, except when otherwise required in section 44-696 and section 44-697, shall ride as near to the right side of the roadway as practicable, and shall exercise due care when passing a standing vehicle or one proceeding in the same direction. 
(b)  Persons riding bicycles upon a roadway shall not ride more than two abreast. Persons riding a one-wheel or two-wheel bicycle two abreast shall not impede the flow of traffic and, on a multi-laned roadway, shall ride within a single lane. 
(c)  Persons riding a three-wheel bicycle or a bicycle with a trailer/semi-trailer attached to it shall ride in single file. 
(Code 1994, ch. 127, § 10.87) 
Sec. 44-694. - Overtaking and passing other vehicles. 
    A person riding a bicycle shall comply with all the rules applicable to the driver of any other vehicle when overtaking and passing a vehicle and shall not pass between lanes of traffic or between an outside lane of traffic and the curb or edge of the roadway. 
(Code 1994, ch. 127, § 10.89) 
Sec. 44-695. - Required positions and methods of turning. 
(a)  Right turns. Both the approach for a right turn and the right turn shall be made as close as practicable to the righthand curb or edge of the roadway with the following exception: A bicycle shall remain in single file with all other vehicles preceding it and shall not travel between an outside lane of traffic and the curb or edge of the roadway. 
(b)  Left turns. 
(1)  A cyclist intending to turn left shall approach the turn in the extreme lefthand lane lawfully available to traffic moving in the same direction as the cyclist. Whenever practicable, the left turn shall be made so as to leave the intersection in the extreme lefthand lane lawfully available to traffic moving in the same direction as the cyclist; or 
(2)  At the cyclist's discretion, shall approach the turn as close as practicable to the right curb or edge of roadway. After riding across the intersecting roadway, the turn shall be made as close as practicable to the curb or edge of the roadway on the far side of the intersection. After turning, the cyclist shall comply with any official traffic control device or police officer regulating traffic on the highway along which the cyclist intends to proceed; or 
(3)  At the cyclist's discretion, shall approach the turn as close as practicable to the right curb or edge of the roadway. Upon reaching the intersection, the cyclist shall stop, dismount, and proceed as a pedestrian across the intersecting roadway. Upon reaching the other side, the cyclist shall then proceed as a pedestrian across the previously travelled roadway. 
(c)  Two-way left turns. Where a special lane for making left turns by drivers proceeding in opposite directions has been indicated by official traffic control devices: 
(1)  A left turn as described in subsection (b)(1) of this section shall not be made from any other lane; 
(2)  A bicycle shall not be ridden in the lane except when preparing for or making a left turn from the roadway or when preparing for or when making a lawful U-turn. 
(Code 1994, ch. 127, § 10.90) 
Sec. 44-696. - Parking. 
(a)  Unless prohibited or restricted by an official traffic control device, a person may park a bicycle on a sidewalk and secure a bicycle to any publicly owned pole or post (except a tree, fire hydrant, police or fire callbox) in any manner so as not to obstruct or present a safety hazard to pedestrians or other traffic. 
(b)  A bicycle may be parked on the roadway at any angle to the curb or edge of the roadway at any location where parking is allowed. 
(c)  A bicycle may be parked on the roadway abreast of another bicycle or bicycles near the side of the roadway at any location where parking is allowed. 
(d)  A person shall not park a bicycle in such a manner as to obstruct the departure of another legally parked vehicle or the passage of pedestrians. 
(e)  In all other respects, bicycles parked anywhere shall conform with the provisions regulating the parking of vehicles. 
(Code 1994, ch. 127, § 10.91) 
Sec. 44-697. - Racing. 
(a)  Bicycle racing on the highways is prohibited, except as authorized in this section. 
(b)  Bicycle racing on a highway shall be lawful when a racing event has been approved by the East Lansing City Council. Approval of bicycle highway racing events shall be granted only under conditions which assure reasonable safety for all race participants, spectators, and other highway users, and which prevent unreasonable interference with traffic flow which would seriously inconvenience other highway users. 
(c)  By agreement with the approving authority, participants in an approved bicycle highway racing event may be exempted from compliance with any traffic laws otherwise applicable thereto, provided that traffic control is adequate to assure the safety of all highway users. 
(Code 1994, ch. 127, § 10.92) 
Secs. 44-698-44-720. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - SKATEBOARDS 

Sec. 44-721. - Use on city parking lots and ramps. 
(a)  No person shall use a skateboard on, or in any, parking ramps leased or owned by the City of East Lansing for the purpose of parking motor vehicles. The term "skateboard" when used in this article shall include coasters and similar devices. 
(b)  A person using a skateboard on surface lots leased or owned by the City of East Lansing for the purpose of parking of motor vehicles shall not interfere with the parking of motor vehicles. 
(Code 1994, ch. 127, § 10.115) 
Sec. 44-722. - Use on pedestrian facilities. 
    A person using a skateboard on, or in, a pedestrian facility including a sidewalk, alley, pedestrian walkway, or easement shall yield the right-of-way to other pedestrians at all times. 
(Code 1994, ch. 127, § 10.116) 
Sec. 44-723. - Use on streets and other public places in City Center commercial district. 
    No person shall use a skateboard for any purpose on any of the public streets, sidewalks, alleys, plazas or other public places within the City Center commercial district, zoned B-3. 
(Code 1994, ch. 127, § 10.117) 
Sec. 44-724. - Use on private property. 
    No person shall use a skateboard on the private property of another which is posted with signs prohibiting skateboards without first obtaining and carrying the written consent of the owner of said private property. Failure of a person who has been using a skateboard on posted private property to produce such written permission on the request of an enforcement officer shall constitute prima facie evidence that said person is in violation of this section. 
(Code 1994, ch. 127, § 10.118) 
Sec. 44-725. - Signs. 
    The department of public works shall erect signs at the street entrances to the City Center commercial district advising of the prohibition of skateboards in the area. 
(Code 1994, ch. 127, § 10.119) 
Sec. 44-726. - Penalty; citations. 
    Any person who shall violate section 44-721, 44-722, 44-723, or 44-724 shall be responsible for a municipal civil infraction as defined by MCL 600.113, punishable by a civil fine of not less than $5.00 nor more than $20.00. Citations charging a violation of the provisions of sections 44-721, 44-722, 44-723, and 44-724 may be issued by a police officer, including a limited duty or parking enforcement officer, of the East Lansing Police Department. 
(Code 1994, ch. 127, § 10.120) 
Chapter 46 - UTILITIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; buildings and building regulations, ch. 6; businesses, ch. 8; environment, ch. 14; floods, ch. 18; historic preservation, ch. 20; manufactured homes and trailers, ch. 24; solid waste, ch. 36; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 38; subdivisions and other land divisions, ch. 40; underground wiring for subdivisions, § 40-112; telecommunications, ch. 42; trimming permits for public utilities, § 48-39. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 46-1. - Definitions. 
    Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the meanings of terms used in this chapter shall be as follows: 
    Authorized Enforcement Agency means the director of public works/city engineer or designees. 
    Clean Water Act means the federal Water Pollution Control Act (33 U.S.C. 1251 et seq.) and any subsequent amendments thereto. 
    Construction activity means activities subject to NPDES construction permits. Currently these include construction projects resulting in land disturbance of one acre or more. Such activities include but are not limited to clearing and grubbing, grading, excavating, and demolition. 
    Engineer means the city director of public works. 
    Hazardous materials means any material, including any substance, waste, or combination thereof, which because of its quantity, concentration, or physical, chemical, or infectious characteristics may cause, or significantly contribute to a substantial present or potential hazard to human health, safety, property, or the environment when improperly treated, stored, transported, disposed of or otherwise managed. 
    Industrial activity means activities subject to NPDES industrial permits as defined in 40 CFR, Section 122.26 (b) (14). 
    National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) Storm Water Discharge Permit means a permit issued by MDEQ that authorizes the discharge of pollutants to waters of the United States, whether the permit is applicable on an individual, group, or general area-wide basis. 
    Person means any individual, association, organization, partnership, firm, corporation, or other entity recognized by law and acting as either the owner of a premises or the owner's agent. 
    Pollutant means anything which causes or contributes to pollution. Pollutants may include, but are not limited to: paints, varnishes, and solvents; oil and other automotive fluids; non-hazardous liquid and solid wastes and yard wastes from commercial landscape operations; refuse, rubbish, garbage, litter or other discarded or abandoned objects, ordinances and accumulations, so that same may cause or contribute to pollution; floatables; pesticides, herbicides, and fertilizers; hazardous substances and wastes; sewage, fecal coliform and pathogens; dissolved and particulate metals; animal wastes; wastes and residues that result from constructing a building or structure; and noxious or offensive matter of any kind. 
    Premises means any building, lot, parcel of land, or portion of land whether improved or unimproved including adjacent sidewalks and parking strips. 
    Uncontaminated industrial wastes means water which has not come into contact with any substance used in or incidental to industrial processing operations. 
    Wastewater means any water or other liquid, other than uncontaminated storm water, discharged from a facility. 
(Code 1994, ch. 25, § 2.101; Ord. No. 1182, 11-7-2007) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-7. 
Sec. 46-2. - Basis of water and sewer charges. 
    All water service shall be charged for on the basis of water consumed, as determined by the meter installed in the premises of water or sewage disposal service customers by the department. All sewage disposal service shall be charged for on the basis of water consumed. No free water service or sewage disposal service shall be furnished to any person. 
(Code 1994, ch. 25, § 2.102) 
Sec. 46-3. - Water rates. 
    The rates to be charged for water service shall be as follows: 
Rates generally; readiness-to-serve charge; minimum monthly charge. All water used shall be charged at such rate or rates as are annually established by resolution of the East Lansing City Council through adoption of the annual city budget. In addition, all customers shall be charged a readiness-to-serve charge in an amount established annually by resolution of the East Lansing City Council. A minimum monthly charge shall be one-third of the quarterly readiness-to-serve charge. 
(Code 1994, ch. 25, § 2.103; Ord. No. 1317, 11-6-2013) 
Sec. 46-4. - Water and sewer service to city. 
    The city shall pay for all water and sewer service used by it at the rates herein established, except that for fire hydrant service, the city shall pay no charge beginning July 1, 1987. Charges against the city shall be quarterly (three-month) installments from the current funds of the city or from the proceeds of taxes which the city, within constitutional limitations, is hereby authorized and required to levy in an amount sufficient for that purpose. 
(Code 1994, ch. 25, § 2.104) 
Sec. 46-5. - Water connection charges. 
(a)  (1)  The cost of water service connections from the city's water mains to private premises shall be paid by the owner of the premises served. For each connection hereafter made to a city water main, there shall be paid in advance to the city the sum in the amounts established by resolution of the East Lansing City Council in accordance with the size of the service along with any additional charges for connections between December 1 and April 1. 
(2)  Upon such payment, the city shall proceed to make the connection and shall furnish all labor and material necessary to connect such water main with the premises at the nearest property line. In cases where an extraordinary amount of labor and material will be required, then the above charge shall be increased to compensate the city for the extra cost. 
(b)  (1)  Provided, however, in cases where the property to be connected to the water main has not participated (other than by payment of the city's general property tax) in the cost of or been assessed by special assessment for such water main serving said property, additional capital charges in the amount of $0.49 per square foot of floor area shall be paid prior to the making of any service connection in that area of the city described as the east one-half of Section 2, T4N, R2W, Lansing Township, Ingham County, Michigan, lying north of Lake Lansing Road and east of the U.S. 127 right-of-way, excluding the east 662 feet of the south 1,926 feet (more or less). 
Any addition to a building or additional buildings constructed on a premises connected to the city water main in the area described in this subsection (b)(1) shall be deemed an additional connection and be subject to the additional capital charge imposed by this subsection upon issuance of the building permit. 
(2)  The entire fee shall be paid in advance at the time of connection. 
(3)  The said amount so collected shall be placed in the capital improvement fund for future extensions or improvements to the water system. 
(c)  Further provided, however, in those areas of the city described in section 1.02 of the 1984 PA 425 Agreement between the city and the Charter Township of DeWitt dated May 5, 1998, as Area 1 and that portion of Area 2 lying north of the abandoned New York Central Railroad right-of-way the following additional capital charges shall be paid prior to the making of any service connection: 
(1)  Per single-family house ..... $450.00 
(2)  Per manufactured house ..... 320.00 
(3)  Per multifamily dwelling unit ..... 230.00 
(4)  Per acre of office or commercial development ..... 2,670.00 
(d)  Further provided, however, that in cases where the property to be connected to the water main has not participated (other than by payment of the city's general property tax) in the cost of or been assessed by special assessment for such water main serving said property, in those additional areas of the city described in section 1.02 of the amended 1984 PA 425 Agreement between the City of East Lansing and DeWitt Charter Township dated June 11, 2001, described as Areas 3 and 4, and all that portion of Area 5 lying east of Coolidge Road, and in all other areas of the city not described in subsections (b), (c) and (e) of this section, the following additional capital charges shall be paid prior to the making of any service connection for such property: 
(1)  Per single-family house ..... $450.00 
(2)  Per manufactured house ..... 320.00 
(3)  Per multifamily dwelling unit ..... 230.00 
(4)  Per acre of office or commercial development ..... 2,670.00

(f)  The water connection charges may be adjusted by resolution of the city council by adoption of the annual budget. 
(Code 1994, ch. 25, § 2.105; Ord. No. 962, 1-4-2000; Ord. No. 1022, 12-3-2002; Ord. No. 1080, 9-7-2004; Ord. No. 1168, 1-16-2007; Ord. No. 1317, 11-6-2013) 
Sec. 46-6. - Sewer rates. 
(a)  Charges for sewage disposal service shall be levied upon all premises having any sewer connection with the public sewers. 
(b)  Charges for sewage disposal services to each premises within the city having metered water service shall, for each quarterly (three-month) period, be a percentage of the charges made for water furnished by the city's water supply system to such premises for such period as measured by the water meter installed on such premises, which percentage shall be such amount as shall be established annually by resolution of the East Lansing City Council. 
(c)  The charge for sewage disposal service to the premises without metered water service shall be $7.00 per month, or such rate or rates as may be annually established by the East Lansing City Council by resolution through adoption of the annual city budget, provided that, in any case where the amount of sewage from such premises appears to be disproportionate to such charge, the city manager is authorized to furnish a meter, and install it upon the private water supply system, and bill the owner of the premises for such installation cost, and in such case, the charges of sewage disposal service to such premises shall be computed on the basis of water consumption at the same rates as if the premises were connected to the city's water supply system. 
(d)  Charges for sewage disposal services furnished to premises outside of the city shall be fixed by the council, but shall not be less than those above set forth. 
(e)  If the character of sewage from any manufacturing or industrial plant, or from any building or premises, is such that it imposes an unreasonable additional burden upon the sewage disposal system of the city, or any other sewage disposal system through which it flows, then an additional charge shall be made over and above the regular rates, or it may be required that such sewage be treated by the person, firm, or corporation responsible, before being emptied into any public drain or sewer, or the right to so empty said sewage may be denied if necessary for the protection of any such disposal system or the public health or safety. 
(Code 1994, ch. 25, § 2.106) 
Sec. 46-7. - Sewer connection charges. 
(a)  The cost of sewer connections from the city's sewers to private premises shall be paid by the owner of the premises served. In cases where the city has previously installed a sewer connection from a trunkline or interceptor sewer line to the private premises, the current capital cost as established by resolution of the East Lansing City Council shall be made prior to connecting said private premises to said existing connection. 
(b)  (1)  Provided, however, in cases where the property to be connected to the sewer line has not participated (other than by payment of the city's general property tax) in the cost of or been assessed by special assessment for such sewer line serving said property, additional capital charges of $0.40 per square foot of floor area shall be paid prior to the making of any service connection in that area of the city described as the east 1/2 of Section 2, T4N, R2W, Lansing Township, Ingham County, Michigan, lying north of Lake Lansing Road and east of the U.S. 127 right-of-way, excluding the east 662 feet of the south 1,926 feet (more or less). 
Any addition to a building or additional buildings constructed on premises in the area described in this subsection (b)(1) shall be deemed an additional connection and be subject to the additional capital charge imposed by this subsection upon issuance of the building permit. 
(2)  The entire fee shall be paid in advance at the time of connection. 
(3)  The said amount so collected shall be placed in the capital improvement fund for future extensions or improvements to the sewer system. 
(c)  Further provided, however, in those areas of the city described in section 1.02 of the 1984 PA 425 Agreement between the city and the Charter Township of DeWitt dated May 5, 1998, as Area 1 and that portion of Area 2 lying north of the abandoned New York Central Railroad right-of-way the following additional capital charges shall be paid prior to the making of any service connection: 
(1)  Per single-family house ..... $710.00 
(2)  Per manufactured house ..... 510.00 
(3)  Per multifamily dwelling unit ..... 355.00 
(4)  Per acre of office or commercial development ..... 4,260.00 
(d)  Further provided, however, that in cases where the property to be connected to the sewer main has not participated (other than by payment of the city's general property tax) in the cost of or been assessed by special assessment for such sewer main serving said property, in those additional areas of the city described in section 1.02 of the Amended 1984 PA 425 Agreement between the City of East Lansing and DeWitt Charter Township dated June 11, 2001, described as Areas 3 and 4, and all that portion of Area 5 lying east of Coolidge Road, and in all other areas of the city not described in subsections (b), (c), (e) and (f) of this section, the following additional capital charges shall be paid prior to the making of any service connection: 
(1)  Per single-family house ..... $710.00 
(2)  Per manufactured house ..... 510.00 
(3)  Per multifamily dwelling unit ..... 355.00 
(4)  Per acre of office or commercial development ..... 4,260.00 
(e)  Further provided, however, that in cases where the property to be connected to the sewer main has not participated (other than by payment of the city's general property tax) in the cost of or been assessed by special assessment for such sewer main serving said property in those areas of the city described in section 1.02 of the Amended 1984 PA 425 Agreement between the City of East Lansing and DeWitt Charter Township dated June 11, 2001, described as that portion of Area 2 lying south of the abandoned New York Central Railroad right-of-way and that portion of Area 5 lying west of Coolidge Road, the following additional capital charges shall be paid prior to the making of any service connection for such property based upon a cost per acre (calculated to the nearest one-hundredth (1/100th) of an acre) of $29,045.00 per acre. 
(f)  Further provided, however, that in cases where the property to be connected to the city's sewer system is ultimately connected to and/or serviced by the 36-inch diameter combined sewer constructed in 2012 in Albert Avenue from Charles Street to Grove Street, the following additional sanitary flow portion and storm flow portion capital charges shall be paid prior to the making of any service connections: 
Sanitary flow portion of connection fee = $3,042.00 × 1.03 (t) × increase in EM 
Storm flow portion of connection fee = $73,026.00 × 1.03 (t) × increase in CA 
For purposes of these calculations, the following apply: 
(1)  1.03 (t) means 1.03 to the power of (t). The power of (t) is calculated as follows: Present year - 2012 = t. For example, present year = 2017, t = 2017-2012 = 5 so it would be 1.03 (5) . 
(2)  Increase in EM refers to the increase in the "Equivalent Water Service Meter Size" in accordance with the following table: 
5/8 × 3/4 inch meter-EM=1.0 
1 inch meter-EM=2.5 
11/2 inch meter-EM= 5.0 
2 inch meter-EM=8.0 
3 inch meter-EM=22.5 
4 inch meter-EM=50.0 
6 inch meter-EM=100.0 
For example, increasing from a one-inch meter with an EM of 2.5 to a two-inch meter with an EM of 8.0 would result in an increase in EM of 5.5 (8.0-2.5). Using 2017 as the example year, the entire calculation would be $3,042.00 × 1.03 (5) × 5.5 for a sanitary flow portion of the connection fee of $19,395.81. 
(3)  CA means the total area of the parcel in acres ("A") times the average percent increase of the imperviousness of that parcel ("C"). For example a two-acre parcel that increases in average imperviousness by 25 percent would equal a CA of .5 (2x.25). Using 2017 as the example year, the entire calculation would be $73,026.00 × 1.03 (5) × .5 for a storm flow portion of the connection fee of $42,328.57. 
(g)  The sewer connection charges may be adjusted by resolution of the city council by adoption of the annual city budget. All or a portion of the sewer connection charges may be waived by city council in an approved development agreement upon a showing by the applicant that a comparable or greater contribution to the city's infrastructure was or will be made and paid for by the applicant during construction of the project. 
(Code 1994, ch. 25, § 2.107; Ord. No. 962, 1-4-2000; Ord. No. 1022, 12-3-2002; Ord. No. 1080, 9-7-2004; Ord. No. 1168, 1-16-2007; Ord. No. 1317, 11-6-2013; Ord. No. 1398, 3-7-2017) 
Sec. 46-8. - Billing for water and sewer service. 
    No free service shall be furnished by the system to the city or to any person. Charges for services furnished by the system shall be billed and collected quarterly (every three months) or more often, as shall be determined by the council, but not less than approximately one-third in amount of such charges shall become due each month. Such charges shall become due on the 15th day of the month following the reading of the water meter, or if water furnished to the premises be not metered, then on the 15th day of the month following the date of the sewage disposal bill. If such charges are not paid on or before such due date, then a carrying charge of five percent shall be added thereto. In the event that the charges for any such service furnished to any premises shall not be paid within 30 days after the due date thereof, then the city water supply to such premises shall be cut off and shall not be restored until all sums then due and owing shall be paid, plus a shut-off charge of $25.00 and a turn-on charge of $100.00 when the turn-on is requested on Saturdays, Sundays, legal holidays, or at times other than between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m. Commencing in fiscal year 2003, the shut-off and turn-on charges may be adjusted by resolution of the city council by adoption of the annual city budget. 
(Code 1994, ch. 25, § 2.108; Ord. No. 1022, 12-3-2002) 
Sec. 46-9. - Collection of water and sewer charges. 
    The city manager is hereby authorized to enforce the payment of charges for water service to any premises by discontinuing the water service to such premises and the payment of charges for sewage disposal service to any premises may be enforced by discontinuing either the water service or the sewage disposal service to such premises, or both, and an action of assumpsit may be instituted by the city against the customer. The charges for water service and sewage disposal service, which, under the provisions of Public Act No. 94 of 1933 (MCL 141.101 et seq.), are made a lien on the premises to which furnished, are hereby recognized to constitute such lien, and the city manager shall, annually, on April 1, certify all unpaid charges for such services furnished to any premises which, on March 31 preceding have remained unpaid for a period of six months, to the city assessor who shall place the same on the next tax roll of the city. Such charges so assessed shall be collected in the same manner as general city taxes. In cases where the city is properly notified in accordance with said Public Act No. 94 of 1933, that a tenant is responsible for water and sewage disposal service charges, no such service shall be commenced or continued to such premises until there has been deposited with the department, a sum sufficient to cover three times the average quarterly bill for such premises as estimated by the city manager. Where the water service to any premises is turned off to enforce the payment of water service charges or sewage disposal service charges, the water service shall not be recommended until all delinquent charges have been paid and a deposit as in the case of tenants is made. 
(Code 1994, ch. 25, § 2.109) 
Sec. 46-10. - Conformity with revenue bond ordinance. 
    Nothing contained in this article shall be deemed to alter or repeal any of the provisions of Ordinance No. 133, adopted November 18, 1963, providing for the issuance of sewage disposal system revenue bonds, with respect to the obligations of the city and the security of the bondholders thereunder. This article is intended to be in conformity with said Ordinance No. 133 and should there be any conflict whereby the security of the bondholders or the obligations of said bonds is impaired, then with respect to such conflict, the provisions of Ordinance No. 133 shall prevail. 
(Code 1994, ch. 25, § 2.110) 
Sec. 46-11. - Hardship deferrals for special assessment and utility capital connection fees. 
(a)  The city manager may grant a deferment of the annual installment payments due on special assessments for street and sidewalk and utility improvements on properties in case of hardship, subject to the following: 
(1)  The payment of special assessment installments may be deferred for individual owners who meet the terms and conditions of this section annually for a period not to exceed ten years or until the property is sold or until one year after the owner's death, however, the death of a spouse shall not terminate deferral of an assessment on property owned jointly by a husband and wife. The gross amount of any annual special assessment installment eligible for deferment under this section shall not be less than $300.00. 
(2)  To receive deferment, the owner shall annually certify to the city manager on or before July 15 that his or her annual household income does not exceed the annual household income threshold for the full Michigan homestead property tax credit. The city manager shall require as a condition of eligibility that the owner annually provide a copy of his or her most recent filed MI-1040CR to verify the eligibility requirements of this subsection. 
(3)  The owner shall execute and deliver to the city clerk a lien on the property in recordable form in favor of the city in the amount of the annual special assessment installment deferred, plus interest as provided in subsection (d). 
(4)  The payment of special assessment installments deferred under this section which are subsequently made by the owner or owner's estate shall include interest computed at the rate of one-half of one percent (0.005) per month or fraction of a month from the date the deferred installment was first billed by the city to the date of payment. 
(5)  The city treasurer shall not report as delinquent any special assessment installment which is deferred under this section for which a lien has been recorded in favor of the city, until such time as the term of the deferment expires as provided in subsection (a) above. 
(6)  A hardship deferment shall not be granted by the city manager where the owner of homestead property is eligible for a deferment of special assessments on that homestead pursuant to 1976 PA 225, MCL 211.761, et seq.
